content:
TITLE: Implementing Poll Adaptive Card JSON for Microsoft Teams DESCRIPTION: JSON structure for creating an interactive poll in Microsoft Teams using adaptive cards. The card includes a title, header, description, poll question, and multiple choice options with a submit button. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/create-adaptive-cards.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: JSON CODE: ``` { "$schema": "http://adaptivecards.io/schemas/adaptive-card.json", "type": "AdaptiveCard", "version": "1.0", "body": [ { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Poll Request", "id": "Title", "spacing": "Medium", "horizontalAlignment": "Center", "size": "ExtraLarge", "weight": "Bolder", "color": "Accent" }, { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Header Tagline Text", "id": "acHeaderTagLine", "separator": true }, { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Poll Header", "weight": "Bolder", "size": "ExtraLarge", "spacing": "None", "id": "acHeader" }, { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Integer vestibulum lorem eget neque sollicitudin, quis malesuada felis ultrices. ", "id": "acInstructions", "wrap": true }, { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Poll Question", "id": "acPollQuestion" }, { "type": "Input.ChoiceSet", "placeholder": "Select from these choices", "choices": [ { "title": "Choice 1", "value": "Choice 1" }, { "title": "Choice 2", "value": "Choice 2" }, { "title": "Choice 3", "value": "Choice 3" } ], "id": "acPollChoices", "style": "expanded" } ], "actions": [ { "type": "Action.Submit", "title": "Submit", "id": "btnSubmit" } ] } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Important Note About Business Process Flow Creation DESCRIPTION: Markdown note highlighting that business process flows can no longer be created from Power Automate outside of solution explorer as of August 2022. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/create-business-process-flow.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` >[!IMPORTANT] > As of August 2022, you can no longer create or manage business process flows from Power Automate outside of the solution explorer. Business process flows and instances continue to be supported through the solution explorer, Power Apps, and Dataverse table views. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Initializing Boolean Variable in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Example of how to initialize a boolean variable in Power Automate. This snippet demonstrates the JSON structure for setting the name, type, and initial value of a boolean variable. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/create-variable-store-values.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "name": "myBooleanVariable", "type": "Boolean", "value": false } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: String Manipulation Functions in Power Automate Expression Language DESCRIPTION: Illustrates various string manipulation functions available in Power Automate, including StartsWith, EndsWith, Contains, and IsEmpty checks. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/variable-manipulation.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: Power Automate Expression Language CODE: ``` %StartsWith(arg1,arg2,arg3)% %NotStartsWith(arg1,arg2,arg3)% %EndsWith(arg1,arg2,arg3)% %NotEndsWith(arg1,arg2,arg3)% %Contains(arg1,arg2,arg3)% %NotContains(arg1,arg2,arg3)% %IsEmpty(arg1)% %IsNotEmpty(arg1)% ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using OR Expression in Power Automate Conditions DESCRIPTION: Example of using the 'or' expression in Power Automate, which takes two boolean arguments and returns true if either argument is true. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/use-expressions-in-conditions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: PowerFx CODE: ``` or(greater(1,10),equals(0,0)) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Invoking Cloud Flow via Runtime Widget Using JavaScript DESCRIPTION: Shows how to trigger a Power Automate cloud flow by calling widget.notify() with the 'triggerFlow' action and passing an object containing the 'flowName' and optional 'implicitData'. This snippet exemplifies invoking a runtime widget action to execute a specific cloud flow. Dependencies include the Widget JS SDK and a properly initialized widget handle. Inputs are the 'triggerFlow' string and a parameter object with 'flowName' and (optionally) 'implicitData'. No return value is shown; handles interaction through the widget system. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/developer/embed-flow-dev.md#2025-04-23_snippet_15 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` widget.notify('triggerFlow', { flowName: flowName, implicitData:implicitData }); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Generating Run URLs for Desktop Flows in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: These code snippets demonstrate the various formats for generating URLs to trigger desktop flows in Power Automate. They include options for specifying workflow name, workflow ID, and environment ID. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/run-desktop-flows-url-shortcuts.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: plaintext CODE: ``` "ms-powerautomate:/console/flow/run?workflowName=[workflowName]" "ms-powerautomate:/console/flow/run?workflowId=[workflowId]" "ms-powerautomate:/console/flow/run?environmentId=[environmentId]&workflowId=[workflowId]" "ms-powerautomate:/console/flow/run?environmentId=[environmentId]&workflowName=[workflowIName]" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Extracting Text from PDF in Power Automate Desktop DESCRIPTION: This action extracts text from a specified PDF file. It allows selection of specific pages and includes options for password-protected files and optimization for structured data. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/pdf.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## Extract text from PDF You can extract text from a PDF file by using the "Extract text from PDF" action. In the action properties you can define the source PDF file and the pages that text should be extracted from. Under the advanced action properties you can define a password in case the PDF file is protected and if the engine should optimize for structured data or not. ### Input parameters |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |PDF file|No|[File](../variable-data-types.md#files-and-folders)||The PDF file to extract text from. Enter a file path, a variable containing a file or a text path| |Page(s) to extract|N/A|All, Single, Range|All|Specifies how many pages to extract: All pages, a single page or a range of pages| |Single page number|No|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)||The number of the single page to extract text from| |From page number|No|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)||The first page number from the range of pages to extract text from| |To page number|No|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)||The last page number from the range of pages to extract text from| |Password|Yes|Direct encrypted input or [Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The password of the PDF file. Leave this blank if the PDF isn't password protected| |Optimize for structured data|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|False|Specify whether to detect formatted layout in the document and extract text accordingly| ### Variables produced |Argument|Type|Description| |-----|-----|-----| |ExtractedPDFText|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)|The extracted text| ### Exceptions |Exception|Description| |-----|-----| |PDF file doesn't exist|File doesn't exist on the given path| |Invalid password|The given password is invalid| |Failed to extract text|Error while trying to extract text| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Focusing Web Input Field - Power Automate Desktop Low-Code DESCRIPTION: Sets focus to a specified input field on a web page by referencing a UI element within an existing web browser instance. Dependencies include a Web browser instance variable and a valid UI element. Major parameters allow you to control waiting for page load, timeout duration, and specify behavior if pop-ups arise. The action does not yield output variables and throws precise exceptions for element-not-found or failed focus attempts. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/webautomation.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: Power Automate Desktop CODE: ``` Action: Focus text field on web page Parameters: Web browser instance: [Variable Required] UI element: [UI Element Required] Wait for page to load: [Boolean, Default=True] Timeout for webpage to load: [Numeric, Default=60] If a pop-up dialog appears: [Option, Default='Do nothing'] Dialog button to press: [Text, Default='OK'] Output: None Exceptions: - Element with specified CSS selector not found - Failed to set input focus on web page text field ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using EMPTY Expression in Power Automate Conditions DESCRIPTION: Example of using the 'empty' expression in Power Automate to check if an object, array, or string is empty. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/use-expressions-in-conditions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: PowerFx CODE: ``` empty('') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using EQUALS Expression in Power Automate Conditions DESCRIPTION: Example of using the 'equals' expression in Power Automate to compare if two values are equal, returning true if they match. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/use-expressions-in-conditions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: PowerFx CODE: ``` equals(parameters('parameter1'), 'someValue') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating and Initializing a Custom Object - Power Automate Expression DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create an empty custom object and initialize a custom object with specific properties and values using Power Automate Desktop expressions. Requires the 'Set variable' action in Power Automate Desktop. 'Property1', 'Property2', etc., are the property names, and their corresponding values are defined as shown. The output is a variable of custom object data type, which can be further manipulated or used within desktop flows. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/variable-data-types.md#2025-04-23_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: Expression CODE: ``` %{{ }}% ``` LANGUAGE: Expression CODE: ``` %{ 'Property1': 'Value1', 'Property2': 'Value2', 'Property3': 'Value2' }% ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Boolean Value Variable in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to create a boolean value variable using the Set variable action in Power Automate desktop flows. The input parameter is populated with %True% or %False%, or a complex logical expression using variables and the percentage notation. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/variable-data-types.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: PowerAutomate CODE: ``` Set variable BooleanVariable to %True% ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Set XML Element Attribute in Power Automate Desktop Flows DESCRIPTION: This action sets the value of an attribute in an XML element. It requires an XML document, the attribute name to set, and the new value. An optional XPath query can be provided to locate the specific element. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/xml.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: XML CODE: ``` |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |XML document|No|[XML node](../variable-data-types.md#xml)||The XML document or XML element to set its attribute| |XPath query|Yes|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The XPath expression to locate the subelement and set its attribute| |Attribute name|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The name of the attribute to set its value| |Attribute value|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The new value for the attribute| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Retrieving a Variable's Value - Power Fx - Power Fx DESCRIPTION: Retrieves the value of a variable named variableName. The expression requires that the variable be previously initialized before usage, adhering to Power Fx's requirements. Used to inject or reference existing variable values within expressions or action inputs. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/power-fx.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Power Fx CODE: ``` "= variableName" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Populating Text Fields using JavaScript in Power Automate Desktop - JavaScript DESCRIPTION: These snippets define an ExecuteScript function intended to be run via Power Automate Desktop's 'Run JavaScript function on web page' action to populate a text field on the current web page. The first variant assigns a value to the 'value' property (suitable for input elements), while the second sets the 'innerText' property (useful for other element types). Both require the user to replace 'CSS-selector' with the actual query selector for the target element and 'value-to-populate' with the desired input. No external dependencies are required beyond standard DOM APIs. The input is the selector and value to set, and the main limitation is that the selector must uniquely identify the field to populate. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/populate-text-fields-click-links-javascript.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: JavaScript CODE: ``` function ExecuteScript() { document.querySelectorAll('CSS-selector')[0].value="value-to-populate"; } ``` LANGUAGE: JavaScript CODE: ``` function ExecuteScript() { document.querySelectorAll('CSS-selector')[0].innerText="value-to-populate"; } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using OR Logic in Trigger Conditions in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to use OR logic in trigger conditions when multiple filter conditions are optional. It uses the @or function to combine multiple test conditions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/triggers-introduction.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` @or (test1, test2, test3) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Input and Output Variables - Markdown Documentation DESCRIPTION: Markdown documentation detailing the process of creating and managing input and output variables in Power Automate desktop flows. Includes information about variable types, naming conventions, and configuration options. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/manage-variables.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` > [!NOTE] > The **Variable name**, **Data type**, and **External name** fields are required to create an input variable. > [!NOTE] > Input variables of instance type (Browser, Excel, Word, Outlook, or Access) don't support default values. ``` LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` > [!IMPORTANT] > If you choose an existing flow variable name for a new input variable, Power Automate will prompt you to confirm the merging of the two variables. Unintentional merging may affect the functionality of your flow and cause errors. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accessing Datatable Items in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to access specific items in a datatable using row and column index notation in Power Automate desktop flows. The notation %VariableName[RowNumber][ColumnNumber]% is used to retrieve individual items. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/variable-data-types.md#2025-04-23_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: PowerAutomate CODE: ``` Set variable CellValue to %ExcelData[1][0]% ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a flow with Copilot using natural language prompt DESCRIPTION: Example of using Copilot to create a scheduled flow by typing a natural language prompt that specifies the schedule and email details. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/run-scheduled-tasks.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` **Create a flow that runs Monday every week starting 04/14/2025 which sends an email to contoso@gmail.com that their MPR doc is due.** ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Reading Text from File - Power Automate Actions - Markdown DESCRIPTION: Documents the parameters and operation details for the 'Read text from file' action in Microsoft Power Automate. Describes input options such as file path, output format, and encoding, along with output variables and exception handling. Structures the requirements and outcomes using markdown tables for clear configuration reference. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/file.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Markdown CODE: ``` ## Read text from file\n\nRead the contents of a text file.\n\n### Input parameters\n\n|Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description|\n|-----|-----|-----|-----|-----|\n|File path|No|[File](../variable-data-types.md#files-and-folders)||The file to read|\n|Store content as|N/A|Single text value, List (each is a list item)|Single text value|Specifies how to store the text. Choose 'Single text value' to store the entire text as a single text value. Choose 'List' to store each line of the original text as a text item in a list.|\n|Encoding|N/A|System default, ASCII, Unicode, Unicode (big-endian), UTF-8|UTF-8|The encoding to read the specified text from the text file with.|\n\n### Variables produced\n\n|Argument|Type|Description|\n|-----|-----|-----|\n|FileContents|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)|The contents as a text|\n|FileContents|[List](../variable-data-types.md#list) of [Text values](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)|The contents as a list of texts|\n\n### Exceptions\n\n|Exception|Description|\n|-----|-----|\n|Directory not found|Indicates that the directory wasn't found|\n|File not found|Indicates that the file doesn't exist|\n|Failed to read from file|Indicates a problem reading from the file| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Encrypt Text with AES in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This action encrypts a string using AES encryption with specified parameters. It supports various encoding formats, key sizes, and optional salt and initialization vector usage. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/cryptography.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## Encrypt text with AES Encrypt a string with AES, using a key and a specified encoding format. ### Input parameters |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |Encoding|N/A|System default, ASCII, Unicode, Big-endian Unicode, UTF-8|Unicode|The encoding of the text to encrypt| |Text to encrypt|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The text to encrypt| |Encryption key|No|Direct encrypted input or [Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The encryption key to use| |Padding|N/A|None, PKCS7, Zeros, ANSIX923, ISO10126|PKCS7|The padding to use for the selected encryption algorithm| |Key size|N/A|128 bits, 192 bits, 256 bits|256 bits|The size of the key in bits to use for the encryption| |Use salt|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|False|Specifies whether to use salt for encryption. When this option is enabled, the randomly generated salt becomes an output in the form of a base64 string.| |Use initialization vector|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|False|Specifies whether to use an initialization vector. When this option is enabled, the randomly generated initialization vector becomes an output in the form of a base64 string| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accessing List and Data Table Values - Power Fx - Power Fx DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates retrieving values from a list and a data table using the Index function. 'var' is the list or table variable, and 'number' is the one-based position/index. Examples show nested usage for cell access and direct row access: '=Index(Index(DataTableVar, 1), 2)' retrieves the value at row 1, column 2 of DataTableVar; '=Index(DataRowVar, 1)' gets the first value in DataRowVar. Proper initialization and typing of data tables or rows are prerequisites. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/power-fx.md#2025-04-23_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: Power Fx CODE: ``` "=Index(Index(DataTableVar, 1), 2)" ``` LANGUAGE: Power Fx CODE: ``` "=Index(DataRowVar, 1)" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Scroll to Bottom of Web Page Using JavaScript DESCRIPTION: JavaScript function that scrolls to the bottom of a web page by using document.body.scrollHeight to determine the maximum scroll height. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/scroll-web-page.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` function ExecuteScript() { window.scrollTo(0, document.body.scrollHeight); } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Up Approval Process in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Instructions for configuring the approval action and conditional logic based on the approval outcome. This demonstrates how to implement a business approval process with Power Automate. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/replace-workflows-with-flows.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: plaintext CODE: ``` 1. To request approval on the quote summary we've created, add the **Approval – Start and wait for an approval** action. Select an **Approval type** (for example, **Approve/Reject – First to respond**), give the approval request a **Title** (for example, the name of the quote for which approval is being requested, picked from the list of dynamic values), and enter the email address for the person who needs to review and approve the quote in the **Assigned to** box. In the **Details** box, add the **Quote line summary** variable, along with any other information that might be relevant using the dynamic value picker (for example, **Total Amount**). 1. To determine what happens once an approval is accepted or rejected, add the **Condition** action. Select **Outcome** from the list of dynamic values from the first field in the condition, **contains** from the drop-down list in the second field, and enter **Approve** in the third field of the condition. Finally, add actions based on the outcome of the approval (for example, send a notification email). ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accessing Custom Form Input Element Data in Power Automate Desktop DESCRIPTION: This expression demonstrates how to access the value of a specific input element from a custom form after it has been submitted. The 'CustomFormData' variable is a custom object automatically populated with the form's data upon submission. 'ElementID' should be replaced with the unique ID assigned to the target input element within the custom form designer. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/custom-forms.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Power Automate Expression CODE: ``` %CustomFormData['ElementID']% ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Populating Web Text Field - Power Automate Desktop Low-Code DESCRIPTION: Fills a text box on a web page with specified input, supporting both emulated typing and physical keystrokes for difficult capture cases. Needs a Web browser instance and UI element; key parameters include the string content, text replacement/append behavior, typing mode, and pop-up handling. It does not generate output variables and will throw exceptions on selection or write failures. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/webautomation.md#2025-04-23_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: Power Automate Desktop CODE: ``` Action: Populate text field on web page Parameters: Web browser instance: [Variable Required] UI element: [UI Element Required] Text: [String Required] If field isn't empty: [Replace or Append, Default='Replace text'] Populate text using physical keystrokes: [Boolean, Default=False] Emulate typing: [Boolean, Default=True] Unfocus text box after filling it: [Boolean, Default=False] Wait for page to load: [Boolean, Default=True] Timeout for webpage to load: [Numeric, Default=60] If a pop-up dialog appears: [Option, Default='Do nothing'] Dialog button to press: [Text, Default='OK'] Output: None Exceptions: - Element with specified CSS selector not found - Failed to write on text field ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Formatting Date/Time Using Custom Format Strings in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Examples of using custom format strings with the formatDateTime() function in Power Automate to format date and time values with specific patterns. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/date-time-values.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: PowerAutomate CODE: ``` formatDateTime('2009-06-15T13:45:30', 'M/dd/yyyy h:mm tt') ``` LANGUAGE: PowerAutomate CODE: ``` formatDateTime('2009-06-15T13:45:30', 'M/dd/yyyy HH:mm:ss tt') ``` LANGUAGE: PowerAutomate CODE: ``` formatDateTime('2009-06-15T13:45:30', 'yyyy/MM/dd hh:mm:ss tt') ``` LANGUAGE: PowerAutomate CODE: ``` formatDateTime(utcNow(), 'MMMM dd, yyyy, HH:mm') ``` LANGUAGE: PowerAutomate CODE: ``` formatDateTime(utcNow(), 'dd-MM-yyyy') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a List in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create a list using the Create new list and Add item to list actions in Power Automate desktop flows. Lists are collections of items and can contain various data types. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/variable-data-types.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: PowerAutomate CODE: ``` Create new list ListVariable Add item "Item1" to list ListVariable Add item "Item2" to list ListVariable ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Retrieving Data with Expand Query in Dataverse DESCRIPTION: An OData expression example showing how to retrieve specific columns from a related table. This example gets the contactid and fullname columns for the primarycontactid of an account record. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/dataverse/get-row-id.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: odata CODE: ``` primarycontactid($select=contactid,fullname) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Exporting Solution using Dataverse Web API DESCRIPTION: This HTTP request demonstrates how to export a solution using the ExportSolution Action in the Dataverse Web API. It includes the request and response examples, showing how to retrieve the base64 encoded solution file. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/manage-flows-with-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` POST [Organization Uri]/api/data/v9.2/ExportSolution OData-MaxVersion: 4.0 OData-Version: 4.0 If-None-Match: null Accept: application/json Content-Type: application/json; charset=utf-8 Content-Length: 472 { "SolutionName": "FlowContainer", "Managed": false } ``` LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` HTTP/1.1 200 OK OData-Version: 4.0 { "@odata.context": "[Organization Uri]/api/data/v9.2/$metadata#Microsoft.Dynamics.CRM.ExportSolutionResponse", "ExportSolutionFile": "UEsDBBQAA..." } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Initializing String Variable in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Example of how to initialize a string variable in Power Automate. This snippet shows the JSON structure for setting the name, type, and initial value of a string variable. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/create-variable-store-values.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "name": "myStringVariable", "type": "String", "value": "lorem ipsum" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Retrieving Email Messages with Specific Criteria in Power Automate Desktop DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use the Retrieve email messages action to fetch emails based on specific criteria such as read status, sender, subject, and body content. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/email.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` :::image type="content" source="media/email/retrieve-email-messages-example.png" alt-text="Screenshot of the Retrieve email messages action."::: ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Scroll Within Specific Element Using JavaScript DESCRIPTION: JavaScript function that scrolls within a specific div element by adjusting its scrollTop property. Demonstrates how to scroll vertically within a contained element. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/scroll-web-page.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` function ExecuteScript() { document.getElementById('divElem').scrollTop -= 10; } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Cloud Flow Using .NET SDK in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This C# method creates a new cloud flow using the IOrganizationService.Create method. It sets required properties like category, name, type, primaryentity, and clientdata. The clientdata contains the flow definition in JSON format. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/manage-flows-with-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` public static Guid CreateCloudFlow(IOrganizationService service) { var workflow = new Entity("workflow") { Attributes = { {"category", new OptionSetValue(5) }, // Cloud flow {"name", "Sample flow name"}, {"type", new OptionSetValue(1) }, //Definition {"description", "This flow reads some data from Dataverse." }, {"primaryentity", "none" }, {"clientdata", "{\"properties\":{\"connectionReferences\":{\"shared_commondataserviceforapps\":{\"impersonation\":{},\"runtimeSource\":\"embedded\",\"connection\":{\"name\":\"shared-commondataser-114efb88-a991-40c7-b75f-2693-b1ca6a0c\",\"connectionReferenceLogicalName\":\"crdcb_sharedcommondataserviceforapps_109ea\"},\"api\":{\"name\":\"shared_commondataserviceforapps\"}}},\"definition\":{\"$schema\":\"https://schema.management.azure.com/providers/Microsoft.Logic/schemas/2016-06-01/workflowdefinition.json#\",\"contentVersion\":\"1.0.0.0\",\"parameters\":{\"$connections\":{\"defaultValue\":{},\"type\":\"Object\"},\"$authentication\":{\"defaultValue\":{},\"type\":\"SecureObject\"}},\"triggers\":{\"manual\":{\"metadata\":{\"operationMetadataId\":\"76f87a86-89b3-48b4-92a2-1b74539894a6\"},\"type\":\"Request\",\"kind\":\"Button\",\"inputs\":{\"schema\":{\"type\":\"object\",\"properties\":{},\"required\":[]}}}},\"actions\":{\"List_rows\":{\"runAfter\":{},\"metadata\":{\"operationMetadataId\":\"9725b30f-4a8e-4695-b6fd-9a4985808809\"},\"type\":\"OpenApiConnection\",\"inputs\":{\"host\":{\"apiId\":\"/providers/Microsoft.PowerApps/apis/shared_commondataserviceforapps\",\"connectionName\":\"shared_commondataserviceforapps\",\"operationId\":\"ListRecords\"},\"parameters\":{\"entityName\":\"accounts\",\"$select\":\"name\",\"$top\":1},\"authentication\":\"@parameters('$authentication')\"}}}}},\"schemaVersion\":\"1.0.0.0\"}" } } }; return service.Create(workflow); } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using formatDateTime() with Dynamic Content in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Example of using the formatDateTime() function with dynamic content in a Power Automate flow, formatting a date input from a trigger. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/date-time-values.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: PowerAutomate CODE: ``` formatDateTime(triggerBody()?['date'], 'MM/dd/yyyy') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using JSON Variables for Related Data in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use a single JSON object variable to store multiple related values instead of using individual variables. This approach reduces the number of actions in your flow and makes data management more efficient. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/guidance/coding-guidelines/use-data-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "var1": "value1", "var2": "value2" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Basic Arithmetic in Power Automate Expression Language DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates basic arithmetic operations using the Power Automate expression language. It shows examples of multiplication, division, and string concatenation. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/variable-manipulation.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Power Automate Expression Language CODE: ``` %5 * 3% %4 / Var% %'this is ' + 'text'% %'This is the number ' + 5% ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Read XML from File in Power Automate Desktop Flows DESCRIPTION: This action reads the contents of an XML file into a variable. It requires a file path and allows selection of encoding type. The action produces an XML node variable containing the document. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/xml.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: XML CODE: ``` |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |File path|No|[File](../variable-data-types.md#files-and-folders)||The file that contains the XML document to read| |Encoding|N/A|System default, ASCII, Unicode, Unicode big endian, UTF-8|System default|The encoding used for the specified file| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Selecting Radio Button on Web Page - Power Automate Desktop Low-Code DESCRIPTION: Automates the process of selecting a radio button element in a browser-managed web page, utilizing explicit UI selection and browser instance reference. Parameters focus on element selection, wait for page load, pop-up handling, and timeout settings. Generates no persistent variables and throws exceptions for element lookup or selection errors. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/webautomation.md#2025-04-23_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: Power Automate Desktop CODE: ``` Action: Select radio button on web page Parameters: Web browser instance: [Variable Required] UI element: [UI Element Required] Wait for page to load: [Boolean, Default=True] Timeout for webpage to load: [Numeric, Default=60] If a pop-up dialog appears: [Option, Default='Do nothing'] Dialog button to press: [Text, Default='OK'] Output: None Exceptions: - Element with specified CSS selector not found - Failed to select radio button ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accessing a PDF Table Info List Item - Power Automate Expression DESCRIPTION: Shows how to access a specific item in a list of PDF table information variables in Power Automate Desktop using a one-based index. Requires a 'List of PDF table info' variable produced by the 'Extract tables from PDF' action. Replace 'VariableName' with your variable's name and 'ItemNumber' with the desired index. The output refers to the info object for a particular extracted table. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/variable-data-types.md#2025-04-23_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: Expression CODE: ``` %VariableName[ItemNumber]% ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Variables and Loops in Power Automate Flow DESCRIPTION: Instructions for setting up a string variable to summarize quote line items and using the 'Append to string variable' action within an 'Apply to each' loop. This demonstrates how to handle collections of data in Power Automate. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/replace-workflows-with-flows.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: plaintext CODE: ``` 1. Because we want to summarize quote line items for the approval, add the **Initialize variable** action. Set **Name** to **Quote line summary**, and **Type** to **String** (from the drop-down list), and leave **Value** empty. 1. Add the **Append to string variable** action and then select the **Quote line summary** variable we created earlier. In the **Value** box, select **Quantity**, **Name**, **Price Per Unit**, **Extended amount**, and **Manual discount** from the list of dynamic values. The Power Automate designer identifies that these values are from a list of quote line items, and adds this action in an **Apply to each** loop to ensure information from each line item is added to this summary. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Full Example of Embedding Power Automate Templates Widget in HTML DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates a complete example of embedding a Power Automate templates widget, showing the top four SharePoint templates in German and starting with a specific list name. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/developer/embed-flow-dev.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: html CODE: ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Decrypt Text with AES in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This action decrypts a string using AES decryption with specified parameters. It supports various encoding formats, key sizes, and optional salt and initialization vector usage. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/cryptography.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## Decrypt text with AES Decrypt a string with AES based on a specified key and an encoding format. ### Input parameters |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |Encoding|N/A|System default, ASCII, Unicode, Big-endian Unicode, UTF-8|Unicode|The encoding for the decrypted text| |Text to decrypt|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The text to decrypt in the form of a base64 string| |Decryption key|No|Direct encrypted input or [Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The decryption key to use| |Padding|N/A|None, PKCS7, Zeros, ANSIX923, ISO10126|PKCS7|The padding to use for the selected decryption algorithm| |Key size|N/A|128 bits, 192 bits, 256 bits|256 bits|The size of the key in bits to use for the decryption| |Use salt|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|False|Specifies whether to use salt for the decryption| |Salt|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The salt to use for decryption in the form of a base64 string| |Use initialization vector|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|False|Specifies whether to use an initialization vector| |Initialization vector|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The initialization vector to use for decryption in the form of a base64 string| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Autofitting Excel Columns Using VBScript in Power Automate Desktop Flows - VBScript DESCRIPTION: This VBScript snippet opens an Excel workbook whose path is defined by the variable %ExcelFile%, makes Excel visible, selects a specified sheet (replace 'SheetName' as appropriate), and then loops through the first 19 columns to apply the AutoFit method, resizing columns to fit their contents. It saves and closes the workbook afterwards. Dependencies include Microsoft Excel, the proper configuration of the Power Automate 'Run VBScript' action, and definition of the 'ExcelFile' variable. Inputs: the Excel file path variable and a target worksheet name. Output: Resized columns in the specified Excel sheet. Users should ensure the worksheet name exists and that Excel is installed on the running machine. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/autofit-excel-columns-vbscript.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: VBScript CODE: ``` 'Opens the Excel file' Set objExcel = CreateObject("Excel.Application") Set objWorkbook = objExcel.Workbooks.Open("%ExcelFile%") objExcel.Application.Visible = True 'Selects the specified sheet' Set objSheet = objWorkbook.Sheets("SheetName") 'Autofits the columns of the sheet'S for col=1 to 19 objSheet.columns(col).AutoFit() next 'Saves and closes the Excel file' objWorkbook.Save objWorkbook.Close SaveChanges = True ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Formatting Date/Time Using Standard Format Strings in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Examples of using standard format strings with the formatDateTime() function in Power Automate to format date and time values. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/date-time-values.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: PowerAutomate CODE: ``` formatDateTime('2009-06-15T13:45:30', 'g') ``` LANGUAGE: PowerAutomate CODE: ``` formatDateTime('2009-06-15T13:45:30', 'D') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using 'and' Expression in Power Automate Condition DESCRIPTION: This expression checks if the Status column value is 'blocked' and the Assigned column value is 'John Wonder'. It's used to determine which rows to delete from an Excel spreadsheet. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/use-expressions-in-conditions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_11 LANGUAGE: Power Automate CODE: ``` @and(equals(item()?['Status'], 'blocked'), equals(item()?['Assigned'], 'John Wonder')) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accessing Element Coordinates and Size from List (Power Automate Desktop) DESCRIPTION: Accesses the individual coordinates (left, top) and dimensions (width, height) of a web element stored in a list variable named 'List'. Assumes the list was populated by splitting the 'waelementrectangle' attribute value retrieved using the 'Get details of element on web page' action and converting the parts to numbers. `List[0]` is left, `List[1]` is top, `List[2]` is width, `List[3]` is height, relative to the top-left corner of the HTML page. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/get-coordinates-size-web-element.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: powerautomate-expressions CODE: ``` List[0] ``` LANGUAGE: powerautomate-expressions CODE: ``` List[1] ``` LANGUAGE: powerautomate-expressions CODE: ``` List[2] ``` LANGUAGE: powerautomate-expressions CODE: ``` List[3] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Requeuing Work Queue Items with Delay in Power Automate Desktop DESCRIPTION: Details the configuration of the 'Requeue item with delay' action in Power Automate Desktop, typically used within a 'Process work queue items' loop. This action allows requeuing the currently processed item (%WorkQueueItem%) with a mandatory future release time ('delay until') and optional new expiry time ('expires') and processing notes, often calculated using preceding datetime actions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/work-queues-process.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: Power Automate Desktop Action Configuration CODE: ``` Context: Inside a 'Process work queue items' loop. Action: Requeue item with delay Parameters: Work queue item: [%WorkQueueItem% (Variable from the loop)] Delay until: [%CalculatedDelayDateTime% (Mandatory future datetime variable)] Expires: [%CalculatedExpiryDateTime% (Optional future datetime variable)] Processing result: [Optional text] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Numeric Value Variable in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Shows how to create a numeric value variable using the Set variable action in Power Automate desktop flows. The input parameter is populated with a number or a mathematical expression using variables within percentage signs. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/variable-data-types.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: PowerAutomate CODE: ``` Set variable NumericVariable to 42 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Datetime Variable - Power Automate Expression DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the syntax for creating a datetime variable using the 'Set Variable' action. Requires specifying the input parameter with a formatted string, where date and time segments follow the provided notation. Replace the date string as needed. The output is a datetime variable that can be used in date/time operations in flows. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/variable-data-types.md#2025-04-23_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: Expression CODE: ``` %d"yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.ff+zzz"% ``` LANGUAGE: Expression CODE: ``` %d"2022-03-25"% ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Combining 'greater' and 'less' Expressions in Power Automate Condition DESCRIPTION: This expression checks if the Due amount is greater than the Paid amount and if the due date is less than one day away. It's used to send reminder emails to employees who haven't paid in full and whose due date is approaching. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/use-expressions-in-conditions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: Power Automate CODE: ``` @and(greater(item()?['Due'], item()?['Paid']), less(item()?['dueDate'], addDays(utcNow(),1))) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Sending Approval Reminder Emails in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Highlights the ability to configure Power Automate flows to send reminder emails for outstanding approval requests. This helps ensure timely responses in approval processes. Often implemented using techniques like parallel branches in the flow logic. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/email-top-scenarios.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: Power Automate CODE: ``` Sending reminder emails for approval requests (Conceptual) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Record Object - Power Fx - Power Fx DESCRIPTION: Creates a record structure (akin to an object) with one property 'prop' set to the string 'value'. Used to construct structured data, often for custom object parameters or outputs. Requires no external dependencies and returns a record value. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/power-fx.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Power Fx CODE: ``` "= {'prop':\"value\"}" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Deleting a Cloud Flow - .NET SDK - C# DESCRIPTION: This static C# method demonstrates deleting a cloud flow (workflow) by its ID using an authenticated IOrganizationService. It invokes the service.Delete method, passing the entity name 'workflow' and the workflow ID to permanently remove the flow. Requires Microsoft.Xrm.Sdk.IOrganizationService and appropriate permissions; does not return a value. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/manage-flows-with-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` /// \n/// Deletes a workflow\n/// \n/// Authenticated client implementing the IOrganizationService interface\n/// The id of the cloud flow to delete.\npublic static void DeleteCloudFlow(IOrganizationService service, Guid workflowId) { \n\nservice.Delete(entityName:"workflow",id: workflowId);\n\n} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Combining Conditions with OR and Parentheses in Power Automate If Action DESCRIPTION: This Power Automate expression demonstrates using the OR logical operator and parentheses within an 'If' action to handle complex validation scenarios. It checks if either the 'ButtonPressed' variable equals 'Cancel' OR if the count of items in the 'SelectedFiles' list variable exceeds 100. This logic is useful for validating user input from dialogs or enforcing operational limits, evaluating to TRUE if at least one of the conditions holds. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/logical-operations-conditional-statements.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Power Automate Expression CODE: ``` (%ButtonPressed == 'Cancel') OR (%SelectedFiles.Count > 100%) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Updating a Cloud Flow - .NET SDK - C# DESCRIPTION: This C# static method updates the description, owner, and state (activation) of a cloud flow using an authenticated IOrganizationService client. It creates an Entity object with the updated attributes and calls service.Update to persist changes. Requires Microsoft.Xrm.Sdk.IOrganizationService, and parameters include the service instance, workflow (flow) ID, and new owner user ID; outputs no value. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/manage-flows-with-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` /// \n/// Updates a cloud flow\n/// \n/// Authenticated client implementing the IOrganizationService interface\n/// The ID of the flow to update.\n/// The id of the user to assign the flow to.\npublic static void UpdateCloudFlow(IOrganizationService service, Guid workflowid, Guid systemuserid) {\n\n var workflow = new Entity("workflow",workflowid)\n {\n Attributes = {\n\n {"description", "This flow will ensure consistency across systems." },\n {"ownerid", new EntityReference("systemuser",systemuserid)},\n {"statecode", new OptionSetValue(1) } //Turn on the flow.\n }\n };\n\n service.Update(workflow);\n} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Retrieving Variable Value in Power Automate Expression DESCRIPTION: Example of how to retrieve a variable's value using an expression in Power Automate. This snippet shows how to use the variables() function to get the contents of an array variable and convert it to a string. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/create-variable-store-values.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` @{string(variables('myArrayVariable'))} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Concurrency Control in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Configuration steps for implementing concurrency control on a flow trigger to limit simultaneous executions. This helps manage resource utilization and prevent race conditions by controlling parallel flow executions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/guidance/coding-guidelines/optimize-power-automate-triggers.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: power-automate CODE: ``` Trigger Settings:\nConcurrency Control: Enabled\nDegree of Parallelism: 1-100 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Extracting Right Substring in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: The RIGHT function extracts a specified number of characters from the right side of a string. It takes the input string and the number of characters to extract as parameters. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/string-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## RIGHT([string],[count]) Extracts a given number of characters from the right side of a supplied text string. **Parameters:** - **[string]** - input string Data type: STRING - **[count]** - number of characters Data type: INT **Output Data Type**: STRING ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Identifying Potential SQL Injection Risks in Desktop Flows using SQL DESCRIPTION: This query detects desktop flows that might be vulnerable to SQL injection by searching for the use of 'database.executesqlstatement.execute' within flow definitions. It's crucial for identifying potential security risks in SQL statement execution. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/automation-analytics-with-fabric-queries.md#2025-04-23_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: sql CODE: ``` SELECT w.name AS 'Desktop flow', w.workflowid AS 'Desktop flow Id', w.createdon AS 'Created on', w.modifiedon AS 'Last modified on', w.definition AS 'Script', w.ownerid AS 'Owner Id', s.fullname AS 'Owner name', s.internalemailaddress AS 'Owner email' FROM workflow w JOIN systemuser s ON w.ownerid = s.systemuserid WHERE w.category = 6 AND w.definition IS NOT NULL AND LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%database.executesqlstatement.execute%'; ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Desktop Flow Connection via Power Platform HTTP API (HTTP) DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to construct and send an HTTP PUT request to the Power Apps API to create a connection using a service principal for a Power Automate Desktop Flow. Required dependencies include an OAuth2 access token (Bearer), valid environment and connection IDs, group ID, service principal credentials (username and password), and details about the machine or machine group. Key parameters such as ENVIRONMENT_ID_URL, ENVIRONMENT_ID, CONNECTION_ID, MACHINE_ACCOUNT, MACHINE_PASSWORD, and GROUP_ID must be populated according to the environment. The request expects JSON input and output, and placeholders need to be replaced with actual runtime values. The method only works with direct API calls, not through the Power Automate web portal. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/alm/alm-connection.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: HTTP CODE: ``` PUT https://{ENVIRONMENT_ID_URL}.environment.api.powerplatform.com/connectivity/connectors/shared_uiflow/connections/{CONNECTION_ID}?api-version=1\nContent-Type: application/json\nHost: {ENVIRONMENT_ID_URL}.environment.api.powerplatform.com\nAccept: application/json\nAuthorization: Bearer eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJu...\nBODY:\n{\n "properties":\n {\n "environment":\n {\n "id": "/providers/Microsoft.PowerApps/environments/{ENVIRONMENT_ID}",\n "name":"{ENVIRONMENT_ID}"\n },\n "connectionParametersSet":\n {\n "name":"azureRelay",\n "values":\n {\n "username":{"value":"{MACHINE_ACCOUNT}"},\n "password":{"value":"{MACHINE_PASSWORD}"},\n "targetId":{"value":"{GROUP_ID}"}\n }\n }\n }\n} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accessing List Items in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Shows how to access specific items in a list using index notation in Power Automate desktop flows. The notation %VariableName[ItemNumber]% is used to retrieve individual items. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/variable-data-types.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: PowerAutomate CODE: ``` Set variable FirstItem to %ListVariable[0]% ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: String Interpolation in Inputs and Selectors - Power Fx - Power Fx DESCRIPTION: Illustrates embedding an interpolated expression within a string using '${...}' syntax. In this example, Sum(10, 20) computes the sum and the result is injected into the string. Used for creating dynamic input strings or UI/web selectors. Variables or function results can be included. Escaping the interpolation syntax requires a double dollar sign (e.g., '$${' for literal output). SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/power-fx.md#2025-04-23_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: Power Fx CODE: ``` "The total number is ${Sum(10, 20)}" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Comparisons in Power Automate Expression Language DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use comparison operators in Power Automate expressions. It includes examples of equality, inequality, and greater/less than comparisons. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/variable-manipulation.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Power Automate Expression Language CODE: ``` =, <> <, <= >, >= ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using Dynamic Content in convertTimeZone Expression for Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to use dynamic content in the convertTimeZone expression. It converts a timestamp from a trigger body from UTC to Eastern Standard Time using the 'HH:mm' time format. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/convert-time-zone.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: console CODE: ``` convertTimeZone(triggerBody()?['Date'],'UTC','Eastern Standard Time','HH:mm') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Exporting User Connection Permissions using PowerShell DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell script retrieves all connection role assignments for a specific user identified by their principal object ID. It requires authentication using 'Add-PowerAppsAccount', specifies the target user ID, fetches the permissions using 'Get-AdminConnectionRoleAssignment', converts the output to JSON format, and saves it to a file named 'ConnectionPermissions.txt'. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/privacy-dsr-export.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` ```PowerShell Add-PowerAppsAccount #Retrieves all connection permissions for the specified userID Add-PowerAppsAccount $userId = "{userID}" Get-AdminConnectionRoleAssignment -PrincipalObjectId $userId | ConvertTo-Json | Out-File -FilePath "ConnectionPermissions.txt" ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Converting Time Zone with Specific Format in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Example of using the convertTimeZone expression to convert a timestamp from UTC to Pacific Standard Time with a specific date format 'D'. This returns the date in the format 'Monday, January 1, 2018'. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/convert-time-zone.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: console CODE: ``` convertTimeZone('2018-01-01T80:00:00.0000000Z', 'UTC', 'Pacific Standard Time', 'D') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining an Adaptive Card for Image Sharing in Microsoft Power Automate (JSON) DESCRIPTION: This JSON snippet provides the schema and layout for an Adaptive Card intended for displaying images and related metadata in Microsoft Power Automate. Dependencies include Adaptive Cards v1.0 and placeholders for dynamic content (acphotoTitle, acTimestamp, acImageThumbnail, acAltText) that must be replaced with actual values, especially a valid URL for the image. The card consists of a large title, a lightweight timestamp, and a single image display with alternate text for accessibility. Inputs required are the corresponding tokens for title, date/time, thumbnail image URL, and alt text; output is a rendered visual Adaptive Card. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/image-share-sample.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` {\n \"$schema\": \"http://adaptivecards.io/schemas/adaptive-card.json\",\n \"type\": \"AdaptiveCard\",\n \"version\": \"1.0\",\n \"body\": [\n {\n \"type\": \"TextBlock\",\n \"text\": \"{acphotoTitle}\",\n \"id\": \"Title\",\n \"size\": \"Large\"\n },\n {\n \"type\": \"TextBlock\",\n \"text\": \"{acTimestamp}\",\n \"size\": \"Medium\",\n \"weight\": \"Lighter\"\n },\n {\n \"type\": \"Image\",\n \"altText\": \"{acAltText}\",\n \"url\": \"{acImageThumbnail}\"\n }\n ],\n \"spacing\": \"None\"\n} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Auto-Retry for Work Queue Items in Power Automate Desktop DESCRIPTION: Describes how to configure the auto-retry mechanism within the 'Process work queue items' action in Power Automate Desktop. This allows overriding the default queue-level retry settings to handle transient IT exceptions locally by specifying a maximum retry count or disabling retries (count=0). The local variable 'CurrentRetryCount' tracks attempts. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/work-queues-process.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Power Automate Desktop Action Configuration CODE: ``` Action: Process work queue items Advanced Settings: Override work queue auto-retry configuration: Enabled Maximum auto-retry count: [User-defined value > 0 for retries, or 0 to disable] Note: Interacts with 'Update work queue item' (status 'IT exception'). Local variable 'CurrentRetryCount' increments with each retry. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Power Automate Desktop Actions SDK using PowerShell DESCRIPTION: These PowerShell commands are executed within the Visual Studio Package Manager console to find and install the necessary NuGet package (`Microsoft.PowerPlatform.PowerAutomate.Desktop.Actions.SDK`) required for developing custom actions for Power Automate for desktop. This step is crucial for accessing the SDK's APIs and attributes. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/guidance/how-to/build-custom-action/buildcustomaction.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: powershell CODE: ``` Find-Package Microsoft.PowerPlatform.PowerAutomate.Desktop.Actions.SDK NuGet\Install-Package Microsoft.PowerPlatform.PowerAutomate.Desktop.Actions.SDK ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Fetching Accounts with Related Contacts using FetchXML in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This FetchXML query retrieves up to 10 account records with specific attributes, including a related contact's full name. It filters for accounts created after 2021 and sorts them by name in descending order. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/dataverse/list-rows.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: XML CODE: ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Declaring and Returning Variables in PowerShell DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to declare new variables using $ notation and return values using Write-Output in PowerShell scripts. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/scripting.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` $variableName = "variableValue" Write-Output $variableName ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Updating BPF Instance Stage via Web API HTTP PATCH DESCRIPTION: This HTTP PATCH request updates an existing BPF instance to navigate to a different stage (e.g., from S1 to S2). It requires the ID of the BPF instance in the URL. The request body updates the 'activestageid' to the target stage's ID and updates the 'traversedpath' to include the ID of the new active stage. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/developer/business-process-flows-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` PATCH [Organization URI]/api/data/v9.0/new_mycustombpfs(dc2ab599-306d-e811-80ff-00155d513100) HTTP/1.1 Content-Type: application/json OData-MaxVersion: 4.0 OData-Version: 4.0 { "activestageid@odata.bind": "/processstages(19a11fc0-3398-4214-8522-cb2a97f66e4b)", "traversedpath": "9a9185f5-b75b-4bbb-9c2b-a6626683b99b,19a11fc0-3398-4214-8522-cb2a97f66e4b" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Candidate Feedback Adaptive Card in JSON DESCRIPTION: JSON schema for an Adaptive Card that implements a candidate feedback form. The card includes input fields for candidate name, comments, a hire/no hire decision radio button, and multi-select checkboxes for follow-up discussion topics. The form supports dynamic token placeholders for name and comments display. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/candidate-feedback-sample.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "$schema": "http://adaptivecards.io/schemas/adaptive-card.json", "type": "AdaptiveCard", "version": "1.0", "body": [ { "type": "TextBlock", "size": "Medium", "weight": "Bolder", "id": "Title", "text": "CANDIDATE FEEDBACK FORM", "horizontalAlignment": "Left" }, { "type": "Input.Text", "placeholder": "{acFullName}", "style": "text", "isMultiline": false, "maxLength": 75, "id": "acFullName" }, { "type": "Input.Text", "placeholder": "{acComments}", "style": "text", "isMultiline": true, "maxLength": 200, "id": "acComments" }, { "type": "TextBlock", "size": "Medium", "weight": "Bolder", "text": "Decision", "horizontalAlignment": "Left", "separator": true }, { "type": "Input.ChoiceSet", "id": "acDecision", "value": "1", "choices": [ { "title": "Hire", "value": "Hire" }, { "title": "No Hire", "value": "No Hire" } ], "style": "expanded" }, { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Suggest follow-up discussion regarding:", "weight": "Bolder" }, { "type": "Input.ChoiceSet", "id": "acFollowUp", "isMultiSelect": true, "value": "", "choices": [ { "title": "Past experience in the topic area", "value": "Experience" }, { "title": "Inclusive behaviors and work ethics", "value": "Inclusivity" }, { "title": "Ability to work without supervision", "value": "Independent" } ] } ], "actions": [ { "type": "Action.Submit", "title": "Submit" } ] } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Deleting Specific User's Shared Connection Permissions in Power Automate using PowerShell (Admin) DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell script allows an administrator to remove all connection role assignments (permissions) for a specific user from shared Power Automate connections. It requires admin authentication (`Add-PowerAppsAccount`), setting the target user's principal object ID in `$deleteDsrUserId`, retrieving their assignments using `Get-AdminConnectionRoleAssignment -PrincipalObjectId`, and deleting them via `Remove-AdminConnectionRoleAssignment`. Note that owner role assignments cannot be deleted unless the connection itself is deleted first. Requires the Power Apps Admin PowerShell module and administrative permissions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/privacy-dsr-delete.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` ```PowerShell Add-PowerAppsAccount $deleteDsrUserId = "{userID}" #Retrieves all shared connections for the specified userID and deletes their permissions Get-AdminConnectionRoleAssignment -PrincipalObjectId $deleteDsrUserId | Remove-AdminConnectionRoleAssignment ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Passing Tabular JSON Data from Cloud Flow to Desktop Flow - Power Automate - JSON DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to structure a datatable as an array of JSON objects for passing from a Power Automate cloud flow to a desktop flow. Each object in the array represents a row in the datatable, with fields such as 'Name', 'Last Name', and 'Email'. This JSON is intended for input into the 'Run a flow built with Power Automate for desktop' action. The primary input parameter is the array itself, and the snippet expects that the corresponding variable in the desktop flow is of the datatable datatype. Limitations include strict adherence to the JSON schema in both source and destination flows. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/passing-datatable.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: JSON CODE: ``` [ { "Name": "Tania", "Last Name": "Agius", "Email": "taniaagius@contoso.com" }, { "Name": "Ditiro", "Last Name": "Kgosi", "Email": "ditirokgosi@contoso.com" }, { "Name": "Zoltan", "Last Name": "Gal", "Email": "zoltangal@contoso.com" } ] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Exporting User Custom Connectors using PowerShell DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell script retrieves all custom connectors created by a specific user in Power Automate. It requires authentication using 'Add-PowerAppsAccount', specifies the target user ID, fetches the custom connectors using 'Get-AdminConnector', converts the output to JSON format, and saves it to a file named 'UserCustomConnectors.txt'. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/privacy-dsr-export.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` ```PowerShell Add-PowerAppsAccount #Retrieves all custom connectors for the specified userID Add-PowerAppsAccount $userId = "{userID}" Get-AdminConnector -CreatedBy $userId | ConvertTo-Json | Out-File -FilePath "UserCustomConnectors.txt" ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Conditional Action with Custom Exception Handling - Power Automate Actions SDK - C# DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates defining a conditional action where the action returns a boolean 'Result' and includes structured error handling. It employs the [ConditionAction] attribute to specify result semantics, and [Throws] for custom exceptions, both visible in the Power Automate designer. The Execute method illustrates a try-catch block that catches exceptions, re-states ActionExceptions, and otherwise throws a new ActionException with a matching name and details for error management. Input arguments are handled using attribute decoration. Dependencies are the Power Automate Actions SDK, and System.ComponentModel. This is suitable for design-time error mapping and flow control. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/create-custom-actions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` using Microsoft.PowerPlatform.PowerAutomate.Desktop.Actions.SDK;\nusing Microsoft.PowerPlatform.PowerAutomate.Desktop.Actions.SDK.Attributes;\nusing System;\nusing System.ComponentModel;\n\nnamespace Modules.CustomModule\n{\n [ConditionAction(Id = \"ConditionalAction1\", ResultPropertyName = nameof(Result))]\n [Throws(\"ActionError\")] // TODO: change error name (or delete if not needed)\n public class ConditionalAction1 : ActionBase\n {\n #region Properties\n\n public bool Result { get; private set; }\n\n [InputArgument]\n public string InputArgument1 { get; set; }\n\n #endregion\n\n #region Methods Overrides\n\n public override void Execute(ActionContext context)\n {\n try\n {\n //TODO: add action execution code here\n }\n catch (Exception e)\n {\n if (e is ActionException) throw;\n\n throw new ActionException(\"ActionError\", e.Message, e.InnerException);\n }\n }\n\n #endregion\n }\n}\n ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Power Automate Flow via Copilot based on Email Subject DESCRIPTION: This Copilot prompt instructs Power Automate to build a flow that activates when a new email arrives with the word 'lottery' in its subject line. Upon activation, the flow sends a push notification to the user's mobile device and marks the triggering email as read in the inbox. Dependencies include Power Automate, an email connection (like Outlook), and the push notification service connection. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/email-triggers.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` When I receive an email that contains the word 'lottery' in the subject, send me a push notification and mark the email as Read. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating an On-Demand Quote Approval Flow in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Step-by-step instructions for creating a cloud flow that runs on demand when a quote is selected, retrieves related quote line items, summarizes them, and sends an approval request. This example demonstrates triggers, list operations, variable manipulation, and conditional logic. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/replace-workflows-with-flows.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: plaintext CODE: ``` 1. Sign in to [Power Automate](https://make.powerautomate.com) and [create a cloud flow in a solution](create-flow-solution.md). 1. From the list of triggers, select **Microsoft Dataverse – When a row is selected**, and then select **Quotes** as the table. This trigger allows a cloud flow to run on-demand on a row or set of rows. 1. With the trigger configured, add actions to run in the flow. This provides the approver with the summary detail that they need to identify the quoted items and values. Begin by adding the **Microsoft Dataverse – List rows** action. The goal is to get the individual items from a Quote, so set the **Table name** to **Quote lines**. To ensure the list contains only those quote line items that belong to the Quote for which the flow was triggered, we'll specify an OData style filter criterion. In the **Filter Query** box, type *\_quoteid_value eq* and then select **Quote** from the list of dynamic values that appear. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Primary Contact with OData Notation in Dataverse DESCRIPTION: Example of using OData notation to set a relationship column. When creating an account row, the Primary Contact column needs to be set using the full OData ID of a contact row. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/dataverse/relationships.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: OData CODE: ``` contacts(c96be312-4ac1-4358-99b6-1e14e2957b15) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Adding Work Queue Items from CSV Data in Power Automate Desktop DESCRIPTION: Illustrates configuring the 'Add work queue item' action within a 'For each' loop in Power Automate Desktop to populate a work queue from rows in a CSV data table. It involves setting parameters like the target work queue, priority, item name (potentially dynamic using data row values), input data (formatted as JSON from the current row), and an optional expiry date calculated using datetime actions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/work-queues-process.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Power Automate Desktop Action Configuration CODE: ``` Context: Inside a 'For each' loop iterating through rows (%CurrentItem%) of a data table (%CSVTable%). Action: Add work queue item Parameters: Work queue: [Target Queue Name, e.g., "Demo PAD queue"] Priority: [Low | Normal (default) | High] Name: [Item Name String, e.g., "StaticPrefix-" + %CurrentItem['ID']%] Input: [JSON formatted data using CurrentItem, e.g., { "InvoiceID": %CurrentItem['ID']%, "Amount": %CurrentItem['Amount']% } ] Expires: [%ExpiryDatetime% (Calculated datetime variable)] Processing notes: [Optional text] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Specifying Action Categories and Order - Power Automate Actions SDK - C# DESCRIPTION: This code illustrates how to group custom actions in categories and control their display order within Power Automate for desktop using the Category and Order properties of the [Action] attribute. Assigning a value to Category allows organization into categories or subcategories, and Order determines display sequence. Only the attribute usage is shown, which should precede the action class definition. Multiple categories and subcategory nesting are supported. No executable code is provided, only attribute usage for structure. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/create-custom-actions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` [Action(Category = \"category.subcategory\")]\n ``` LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` [Action(Id = \"Action1\", Order = 1, Category = \"TestCategory\")]\n ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using the convertTimeZone Expression Function in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the basic syntax of the convertTimeZone function which converts a timestamp from a source time zone to a target time zone. The function accepts timestamp, sourceTimeZone, destinationTimeZone, and an optional format parameter. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/convert-time-zone.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: console CODE: ``` convertTimeZone(timestamp: string, sourceTimeZone: string, destinationTimeZone: string, format?: string) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Displaying Message Box in Power Automate Desktop Flow DESCRIPTION: Example of using the Display Message action to show a message box to the user. It demonstrates setting the title, content, icon, and buttons for the message box. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/display.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` :::image type="content" source="media/display/display-message-example.png" alt-text="Screenshot of the Display message action."::: ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Calculating Web Element Bottom Coordinate (Power Automate Desktop) DESCRIPTION: Calculates the bottom coordinate of a web element using Power Automate Desktop expressions. Requires the list 'List' to contain numeric values for these indices, derived from the 'waelementrectangle' attribute.
