Utilizes the Table function to build a typed table structure in flows. Useful for scenarios needing a list of objects or tabular data representation. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/power-fx.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: Power Fx CODE: ``` "= Table({'prop':\"value\"})" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Exporting All Custom Connectors using PowerShell DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell script retrieves all custom connectors within the Power Platform tenant. It requires authentication using 'Add-PowerAppsAccount', uses the 'Get-Connector' cmdlet with the '-FilterNonCustomConnectors' flag to retrieve only custom connectors, converts the output to JSON format, and saves it to a file named 'CustomConnectors.txt'. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/privacy-dsr-export.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` ```PowerShell Add-PowerAppsAccount Get-Connector -FilterNonCustomConnectors | ConvertTo-Json | Out-File -FilePath "CustomConnectors.txt" ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: List of Reserved Keywords in Power Automate Desktop DESCRIPTION: A comprehensive list of all reserved keywords in Power Automate for desktop that cannot be used for variable names, custom object properties, or in custom actions. These keywords are case insensitive, meaning that uppercase and lowercase versions are treated the same. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/reserved-keywords.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` - ACTION - AND - AS - BLOCK - CALL - CASE - DEFAULT - DISABLE - ELSE - END - ERROR - EXIT - FALSE - FOR - FOREACH - FROM - FUNCTION - GLOBAL - GOTO - IF - IMPORT - IN - INPUT - LABEL - LOOP - MAIN - MOD - NEXT - NO - NOT - ON - OR - OUTPUT - REPEAT - SET - STEP - SWITCH - THEN - THROW - TIMES - TO - TRUE - WAIT - WHILE - XOR - YES ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Finding Top 10 Failing Desktop Flow Actions using SQL DESCRIPTION: This SQL query retrieves the top 10 desktop flow actions that have recorded the highest number of failures within the last 7 days. It queries the `flowlog` table, filters records from the past week, extracts the action name using `JSON_VALUE`, and counts entries where the status is 'Failed'. The results are grouped by action name and ordered by the failure count in descending order. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/automation-analytics-with-fabric-queries.md#2025-04-23_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: sql CODE: ``` SELECT TOP(10) JSON_VALUE(data, '$.name') AS ActionName, SUM(CASE WHEN JSON_VALUE(data, '$.status') = 'Failed' THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) AS ErrorCount FROM [flowlog] WHERE createdon >= DATEADD(day, -7, GETDATE()) GROUP BY JSON_VALUE(data, '$.name') HAVING SUM(CASE WHEN JSON_VALUE(data, '$.status') = 'Failed' THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) > 0 ORDER BY ErrorCount DESC; ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Initializing Array Variable with Strings in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Example of how to initialize an array variable containing strings in Power Automate. This snippet demonstrates the JSON structure for setting the name, type, and initial value of an array variable with string elements. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/create-variable-store-values.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "name": "myArrayVariable", "type": "Array", "value": ["red", "orange", "yellow"] } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Sending Email from User Account using Power Automate Outlook Connector DESCRIPTION: Describes using the 'Send an email (V2)' action in Power Automate to send emails from the user's own account. Supports rich text formatting, dynamic content from previous steps, and sending to multiple recipients. Optionally allows sending 'as' or 'on behalf of' another user if Outlook permissions are granted. Sent emails are stored in the user's Outlook Sent Items folder. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/email-top-scenarios.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Power Automate CODE: ``` Send an email (V2) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using AND Expression in Power Automate Conditions DESCRIPTION: Example of using the 'and' expression in Power Automate, which takes two boolean arguments and returns true only if both values are true. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/use-expressions-in-conditions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: PowerFx CODE: ``` and(greater(1,10),equals(0,0)) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Adding Auto-login and Run ID Parameters to Power Automate Desktop Flow URL DESCRIPTION: These snippets demonstrate how to add the auto-login parameter for silent sign-in and the run ID parameter for log management to a Power Automate desktop flow run URL. The proper syntax requires the table name and GUID in parentheses. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/dataverse/relationships.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: OData CODE: ``` systemusers() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Parsing Paginated JSON Response in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This JSON snippet demonstrates a paginated response from a Power Automate query. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/dataverse/list-rows.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "@odata.context":"[Organization URI]/api/data/v9.1/$metadata#accounts(name)", "value":[ { "@odata.etag":"W/\"437194\"", "name":"Fourth Coffee (sample)", "accountid":"7d51925c-cde2-e411-80db-00155d2a68cb" }, { "@odata.etag":"W/\"437195\"", "name":"Litware, Inc. (sample)", "accountid":"7f51925c-cde2-e411-80db-00155d2a68cb" }, { "@odata.etag":"W/\"468026\"", "name":"Adventure Works (sample)", "accountid":"8151925c-cde2-e411-80db-00155d2a68cb" } ], "@odata.nextLink":"[Organization URI]/api/data/v9.1/accounts?$select=name&$skiptoken=%3Ccookie%20pagenumber=%222%22%20pagingcookie=%22%253ccookie%2520page%253d%25221%2522%253e%253caccountid%2520last%253d%2522%257b8151925C-CDE2-E411-80DB-00155D2A68CB%257d%2522%2520first%253d%2522%257b7D51925C-CDE2-E411-80DB-00155D2A68CB%257d%2522%2520%252f%253e%253c%252fcookie%253e%22%20/%3E" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Work Queue Data Table (Robin) in Power Automate Desktop DESCRIPTION: This Robin code snippet demonstrates how to use the 'Create new data table' action in Power Automate desktop (traditional flows) to define the required structure for adding multiple work queue items. It initializes a data table variable named `DataTable` with columns: Name, Input, Expires in, Processing notes, Priority, Unique reference, Status, and Delay until, setting empty string values for the first row. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/workqueues.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Robin CODE: ``` Variables.CreateNewDatatable InputTable: { ^['Name', 'Input', 'Expires in', 'Processing notes', 'Priority', 'Unique reference', 'Status', 'Delay until'], [$'''''', $'''''', $'''''', $'''''', $'''''', $'''''', $'''''', $''''''] } DataTable=> DataTable ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Counting Desktop Flow Runs with Pro-Code Usage using SQL DESCRIPTION: This SQL query identifies and counts distinct desktop flow runs (Flow Sessions) from the last 7 days that utilized pro-coding actions like VBScript, PowerShell, JavaScript, .NET, or Python. It achieves this by checking the workflow definition (`w.definition`) for keywords associated with these script actions. It uses Common Table Expressions (CTEs): `ProCodingSessions` identifies the relevant sessions and joins necessary tables (`flowlog`, `flowsession`, `workflow`, `systemuser`), and `FlowCounts` aggregates the distinct session counts per desktop flow. The final result lists desktop flows ordered by the number of runs involving pro-code actions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/automation-analytics-with-fabric-queries.md#2025-04-23_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: sql CODE: ``` WITH ProCodingSessions AS ( SELECT fs.flowsessionid, f.data AS 'Action log', f.parentobjectid AS 'Parent object id', f.createdon AS 'Log created on', w.name AS 'Desktop flow', w.workflowid AS 'Desktop flow Id', w.createdon AS 'Created on', w.modifiedon AS 'Last modified on', w.definition AS 'Script', w.ownerid AS 'Owner Id', s.fullname AS 'Owner name', s.internalemailaddress AS 'Owner email' FROM [flowlog] f JOIN flowsession fs ON f.parentobjectid = fs.flowsessionid JOIN workflow w ON fs.regardingobjectid = w.workflowid JOIN systemuser s ON w.ownerid = s.systemuserid WHERE f.createdon >= DATEADD(day, -7, GETDATE()) AND ( LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%runvbscript%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%runpowershellscript%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%runjavascript%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%rundotnetscript%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%runpythonscript%' ) ), FlowCounts AS ( SELECT p.[Desktop flow], p.[Desktop flow Id], p.[Created on], p.[Last modified on], p.[Script], p.[Owner Id], p.[Owner name], p.[Owner email], COUNT(DISTINCT p.flowsessionid) AS ProCodingSessionCount FROM ProCodingSessions p GROUP BY p.[Desktop flow], p.[Desktop flow Id], p.[Created on], p.[Last modified on], p.[Script], p.[Owner Id], p.[Owner name], p.[Owner email] ) SELECT f.[Desktop flow], f.[Desktop flow Id], f.[Created on], f.[Last modified on], f.[Script], f.[Owner Id], f.[Owner name], f.[Owner email], f.ProCodingSessionCount AS 'Runs with pro-code' FROM FlowCounts f ORDER BY f.ProCodingSessionCount DESC; ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Adaptive Card Template for Weather Reports in JSON DESCRIPTION: This JSON schema defines an Adaptive Card layout for displaying weather information in Microsoft Teams. The template includes placeholders for dynamic content such as location, current temperature, high/low temperatures, summary, and weather condition images. These placeholders must be replaced with actual data from a weather service like MSN Weather. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/daily-weather-sample.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "$schema": "http://adaptivecards.io/schemas/adaptive-card.json", "type": "AdaptiveCard", "version": "1.0", "body": [ { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "{acCity}, {acState}", "size": "Large", "isSubtle": true }, { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "{acCurrentDateTime}", "spacing": "None" }, { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "{acDailySummary}", "spacing": "None" }, { "type": "ColumnSet", "columns": [ { "type": "Column", "width": "auto", "items": [ { "type": "Image", "url": "{acUrlConditionsImage}", "size": "Large" } ] }, { "type": "Column", "width": "auto", "items": [ { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "{acCurrentTemperature}", "size": "ExtraLarge", "spacing": "None" } ] }, { "type": "Column", "width": "stretch", "items": [ { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "°F", "weight": "Bolder", "spacing": "Small" } ] }, { "type": "Column", "width": "stretch", "items": [ { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Hi {actempHi}", "horizontalAlignment": "Left" }, { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Lo {actempLow}", "horizontalAlignment": "Left", "spacing": "None" } ] } ] } ] } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Checking if Datetime is within Working Hours in Power Automate Expressions DESCRIPTION: Determines if the provided datetime falls within the working hours defined in the active calendar configuration. Upon receiving the event, the host fetches the necessary Microsoft Entra ID JWT token (audience 'https://service.flow.microsoft.com') and passes it back to the widget using the `widgetDoneCallback` function. The host is responsible for managing token expiration and refreshing it if needed. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/developer/embed-flow-dev.md#2025-04-23_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` widget.listen("GET_ACCESS_TOKEN", function(requestParam, widgetDoneCallback) { widgetDoneCallback(null, { token: '' }); }); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using GREATER Expression in Power Automate Conditions DESCRIPTION: Example of using the 'greater' expression in Power Automate to check if the first argument is greater than the second argument. Use the notation **%ListName[0]%** to refer to the first item in the list, **%ListName[1]%** to the second, and so on. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining a Lead Collection Adaptive Card in JSON DESCRIPTION: This JSON code defines the structure and elements of an Adaptive Card for collecting lead information. It utilizes the Adaptive Card schema version 1.0 and includes TextBlock elements for displaying titles and instructions, Input.Text fields for capturing the lead's first name (acLeadFName), last name (acLeadLName), email (acLeadEmail), and phone number (acLeadPrimaryPhone), and an Input.ChoiceSet (acLeadProductInterest) for selecting multiple product interests (Office 365, Dynamics 365, Azure Services, Power Platform). A submit action (Action.Submit) is included at the end. Placeholders like {firstName} are used in the input fields. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/lead-collection-sample.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "$schema": "http://adaptivecards.io/schemas/adaptive-card.json", "type": "AdaptiveCard", "version": "1.0", "body": [ { "type": "ColumnSet", "columns": [ { "type": "Column", "width": 2, "items": [ { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Lead Notification", "weight": "Bolder", "id": "Title", "size": "ExtraLarge" }, { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Please fill out a single form for each individual expressing interest in our products. ", "isSubtle": true, "wrap": true, "id": "acInstructions", "size": "Large" } ] } ] }, { "type": "Container", "items": [ { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Potential Customer FIRST NAME", "wrap": true, "size": "Medium" } ] }, { "type": "Input.Text", "id": "acLeadFName", "placeholder": "{firstName}" }, { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Potential Customer LAST NAME", "wrap": true }, { "type": "Input.Text", "id": "acLeadLName", "placeholder": "{lastName}" }, { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Corporate email", "wrap": true }, { "type": "Input.Text", "id": "acLeadEmail", "placeholder": "{emailAddress}", "style": "Email" }, { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Business Phone Number" }, { "type": "Input.Text", "id": "acLeadPrimaryPhone", "placeholder": "{primaryPhone10digits}", "style": "Tel" }, { "type": "RichTextBlock", "inlines": [ { "type": "TextRun", "text": "{productInterests}" } ] }, { "type": "Input.ChoiceSet", "placeholder": "Placeholder text", "choices": [ { "title": "Office 365", "value": "Office 365" }, { "title": "Dynamics 365", "value": "Dynamics 365" }, { "title": "Azure Services", "value": "Azure Services" }, { "title": "Power Platform", "value": "Power Platform" } ], "style": "expanded", "id": "acLeadProductInterest", "isMultiSelect": true } ], "actions": [ { "type": "Action.Submit", "title": "Submit" } ] } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Writing Text to File - Power Automate Actions - Markdown DESCRIPTION: Documents parameters for the 'Write text to file' action in Microsoft Power Automate. Details inputs like file path, text content, encoding, append mode, and error cases. Output is not a variable but the action's side effect is described, and all details are formatted in markdown tables for reference. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/file.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Markdown CODE: ``` ## Write text to file\n\nWrite or appends text to a file.\n\n### Input parameters\n\n|Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description|\n|-----|-----|-----|-----|-----|\n|File path|No|[File](../variable-data-types.md#files-and-folders)||The file to write the text. This value can be a file path, or a variable containing a file or a textual path.|\n|Text to write|Yes|[General value](../variable-data-types.md#general-value)||The text to write in the specified file|\n|Append new line|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|True|Specifies whether to append a new line at the end of the overall text to write to the file|\n|If file exists|N/A|Overwrite existing content, Append content|Overwrite existing content|Specifies whether to overwrite the existing content, or to append to the end of the existing content. If the file doesn't exist, this action automatically creates it.|\n|Encoding|N/A|System default, ASCII, Unicode, Unicode (big-endian), UTF-8, Unicode (without byte order mask), UTF-8 (without byte order mask)|Unicode|The encoding to use for the specified text to write into the text file|\n\n### Variables produced\n\nThis action doesn't produce any variables.\n\n### Exceptions\n\n|Exception|Description|\n|-----|-----|\n|Failed to write text to file|Indicates a problem writing to the file|\n|Invalid directory for file|Indicates that the directory is invalid| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining a Custom Action Class in C# for Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This C# code defines a custom action class `LogEventToFile` within the `ModulesLogEvent` namespace. It inherits from `ActionBase` provided by the SDK. Attributes like `[Action]`, `[InputArgument]`, `[OutputArgument]`, and `[Throws]` define the action's metadata, input/output parameters (LogFileName, LogMessage, StatusCode), and potential errors. The `Execute` method contains the core logic, which appends a message to a specified file using `File.AppendAllText` and sets a status code. It includes basic error handling. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/guidance/how-to/build-custom-action/buildcustomaction.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` using System; using System.IO; using Microsoft.PowerPlatform.PowerAutomate.Desktop.Actions.SDK; using Microsoft.PowerPlatform.PowerAutomate.Desktop.Actions.SDK.Attributes; namespace ModulesLogEvent { [Action(Id = "LogEventToFile" , Order = 1, Category = "Logging")] [Throws("LogEventError")] public class LogEventToFile : ActionBase { [InputArgument] public string LogFileName { get; set; } [InputArgument] public string LogMessage { get; set; } [OutputArgument] public bool StatusCode { get; set; } public override void Execute(ActionContext context) { try { // To append all of the text to the file File.AppendAllText(LogFileName, LogMessage); StatusCode = true; } catch (Exception e) { if (e is ActionException) throw; throw new ActionException("LogEventError", e.Message, e.InnerException); } } } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating BPF Instance at First Stage via Web API HTTP POST DESCRIPTION: This HTTP POST request creates a new instance of a custom Business Process Flow ('new_mycustombpfs') using the Web API. The request body specifies the primary table row (an account) to associate with the BPF instance using 'bpf_accountid@odata.bind' and sets the initial active stage using 'activestageid@odata.bind'. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/developer/business-process-flows-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` POST [Organization URI]/api/data/v9.0/new_mycustombpfs HTTP/1.1 Content-Type: application/json; charset=utf-8 OData-MaxVersion: 4.0 OData-Version: 4.0 Accept: application/json { "bpf_accountid@odata.bind": "/accounts(a176be9e-9a68-e711-80e7-00155d41e206)", "activestageid@odata.bind": "/processstages(9a9185f5-b75b-4bbb-9c2b-a6626683b99b)" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Create text with GPT Action Parameters Table DESCRIPTION: Markdown table defining the input parameters for the Create text with GPT action, specifying the argument name, optionality, accepted values, defaults and descriptions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/aibuilder.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |Instructions|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||Provide instructions for the GPT model to perform a task| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Extracting Tables from PDF in Power Automate Desktop DESCRIPTION: This action extracts tables from a specified PDF file. It allows selection of specific pages and includes options for password-protected files, table headers, and merging tables across page margins. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/pdf.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## Extract tables from PDF You can extract tables that are contained in a PDF file by using the **Extract tables from PDF** action. In the action properties you can define the PDF file and the range of pages that the tables will be extracted from. Under the advanced action properties you can define a password in case a the PDF file is protected, define if the table has headers or not, and finally if tables that cross page margins should be merged or not. ### Input parameters |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |PDF file|No|[File](../variable-data-types.md#files-and-folders)||The PDF file to extract tables from. Enter a file path, a variable containing a file or a text path| |Page(s) to extract|N/A|All, Single, Range|All|Specifies how many pages to extract tables from: all pages, a single page or a range of pages| |Single page number|No|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)||The number of the single page to extract tables from| |From page number|No|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)||The first page number from the range of pages to extract tables from| |To page number|No|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)||The last page number from the range of pages to extract tables from| |Password|Yes|Direct encrypted input or [Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The password of the PDF file. Leave this blank if the PDF isn't password protected| |Merge tables that cross page margins|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|True|Specifies whether to merge tables that cross page margins in the specified page range| |First line contains column names|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|True|Specifies whether the first line of table contains column names| ### Variables produced |Argument|Type|Description| |-----|-----|-----| |ExtractedPDFTables|[List of PDF table info](../variable-data-types.md#list-of-pdf-table-info)|The extracted tables with their info as a list| ### Exceptions |Exception|Description| |-----|-----| |PDF file doesn't exist|File doesn't exist on the given path| |Invalid password|The given password is invalid| |Failed to extract tables|Error while trying to extract tables| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using LESSOREQUALS Expression in Power Automate Conditions DESCRIPTION: Example of using the 'lessOrEquals' expression in Power Automate to check if the first argument is less than or equal to the second argument. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/use-expressions-in-conditions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: PowerFx CODE: ``` lessOrEquals(10,10) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring SAP Function Call Action in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Describes the configuration steps for the 'Call SAP function (preview)' action in Power Automate to validate SAP data. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/statistical-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## OCCURRENCE([attributeName]) Returns occurrence index of a given event attribute value within the case. **Supported context:** event **Parameters:** - ***[attributeName]*** - Attribute to calculate repetitions. If none is entered, the default attribute is mining attribute (activity attribute), optional Data type: STRING (only fixed string is allowed) **Output Data Type**: INT ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Custom Log Event Action Class in C# DESCRIPTION: C# code for a custom action class that logs events to a file. This updated version includes three input parameters (LogFileName, LogMessage, LogLevel) and returns a boolean status code indicating success or failure. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/guidance/how-to/build-custom-action/buildcustomaction.md#2025-04-23_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` using System; using System.IO; using Microsoft.PowerPlatform.PowerAutomate.Desktop.Actions.SDK; using Microsoft.PowerPlatform.PowerAutomate.Desktop.Actions.SDK.Attributes; namespace ModulesLogEvent { [Action(Id = "LogEventToFile" , Order = 1, Category = "Logging")] [Throws("LogEventError")] public class LogEventToFile : ActionBase { [InputArgument] public string LogFileName { get; set; } [InputArgument] public string LogMessage { get; set; } [InputArgument] public string LogLevel { get; set; } [OutputArgument] public bool StatusCode { get; set; } public override void Execute(ActionContext context) { try { // To append all of the text to the file File.AppendAllText(LogFileName, LogLevel + ": " + LogMessage); StatusCode = true; } catch (Exception e) { if (e is ActionException) throw; throw new ActionException("LogEventError", e.Message, e.InnerException); } } } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Assigning a Numeric Value - Power Fx - Power Fx DESCRIPTION: Assigns the numeric value 1 using a Power Fx expression. No dependencies are required. In Power Automate desktop flows with Power Fx enabled, prefixing with '=' denotes expression mode. The snippet is typically used in input fields or variable assignments where a constant value is needed. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/power-fx.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Power Fx CODE: ``` "=1" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Documenting Input Parameters for Pressing Button on Web Page in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Markdown table detailing input parameters for the 'Press button on web page' action, including browser instance, UI element selection, wait options, and handling of pop-up dialogs. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/webautomation.md#2025-04-23_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |Web browser instance|No|[Web browser instance](../variable-data-types.md#instances)||Enter or choose the variable that contains the web browser instance to work with| |UI element|No|[UI element](../ui-elements.md)||Select the button to press| |Wait for page to load|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|True|Specify whether to wait for the new web page to load completely after pressing the button| |Timeout for webpage to load|No|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)|60|Set the time in seconds for page to load before the action throws an error| |If a pop-up dialog appears|N/A|Close it, Press a button, Do nothing|Do nothing|Specify what to do if a pop-up dialog appears after pressing the button| |Dialog button to press|Yes|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)|OK|Enter the dialog button to press if a pop-up dialog appears| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Exporting All Connection Permissions using PowerShell DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell script retrieves all connection role assignments within the Power Platform tenant. It allows users to extract various types of data from web pages and store them in variables or Excel spreadsheets. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/webautomation.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## Extract data from web page Extract data from specific parts of a web page in the form of single values, lists, rows, or tables. For more information on how to use this action, go to [Web data extraction](../automation-web.md#extract-data-from-webpages). ### Input parameters |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |Web browser instance|No|[Web browser instance](../variable-data-types.md#instances)||Enter or choose the variable that contains the web browser instance to work with| |UI element|No|[UI element](../ui-elements.md)||Select the UI element on web page to extract data from| |Extraction parameters|No|[Datatable](../variable-data-types.md#datatable)||The parameters to use when extracting data. Depending on the extraction mode, this parameter accepts different data.| |Max web pages to process|No|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)||The maximum number of web pages to process| |Send physical click for next page|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|False|Specify whether to physically move the mouse cursor over the page prior to clicking. A physical click is required for cases where emulated clicks to the page don't perform the intentional action on the element. As this option requires the browser window to be focused, it will automatically bring it to the foreground.| |Page CSS selector|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The page CSS selector| |Extraction mode|N/A|Undefined, Single value, Handpicked values, List, Table, Entire HTML table|Single value|Specify what to extract from the web page| |Use paging|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|False|Specify whether to use paging| |Get all web pages|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|False|Specify whether to get all web pages| |Process data upon extraction|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|False|Specify whether to process extracted data to present them exactly as displayed in the webpage. Processing of extracted data includes displaying of the information nested in iframes and filtering through hidden or visible elements. For larger datasets, having this option enabled isn't recommended as it will increase the extraction time.| |Timeout|Yes|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)|60|Set the time in seconds that you want to wait for the extraction to be completed before the action fails| |Store data mode|N/A|Variable, Excel spreadsheet|Variable|Specify whether to store the extracted data in a variable or an Excel spreadsheet| ### Variables produced |Argument|Type|Description| |-----|-----|-----| |ExcelInstance|[Excel instance](../variable-data-types.md#instances)|The Excel instance with the extracted data. Use this instance to manipulate the spreadsheet (or save and close it) by using the dedicated Excel actions.| |DataFromWebPage|[Datatable](../variable-data-types.md#datatable)|The extracted data in the form of a single value, list, data row, or data table. | ### Exceptions |Exception|Description| |-----|-----| |Failed to extract data|Indicates a problem extracting data| |Failed to launch Excel instance|Indicates a problem launching an Excel instance| |Failed to write values to Excel|Indicates a problem writing the values to an Excel| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Updating Nested List Properties in Power Fx (Power Automate Desktop) DESCRIPTION: Example of using the Set function to update nested list properties in a data table within a Power Fx enabled flow. This demonstrates accessing and modifying specific indexes in complex data structures. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/power-fx.md#2025-04-23_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: Power Fx CODE: ``` =Set(Index(Index(DataTable, 1), 1), 42) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Filtering SQL Rows Based on SharePoint Item Title using OData DESCRIPTION: This OData filter query is used within the 'Filter Query' field of the 'SQL Server - Get rows' action in Power Automate. It searches the specified SQL table for rows where the 'Title' column exactly matches the 'Title' dynamic content token from the triggering SharePoint item ('When an item is created or modified'). The single quotes are necessary to denote a string literal comparison in OData. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/odata-filters.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: OData Filter Query CODE: ``` Title eq '[Title Token]' ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Microsoft Access Connection String Format DESCRIPTION: Standard connection string format for connecting to Microsoft Access databases. Includes provider specification, data source path, and security settings. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/sql-queries-microsoft-access.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` Provider=Microsoft.ACE.OLEDB.12.0;Data Source=DatabasePath;Persist Security Info=False ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining ISLOOPINFLOW() Operation in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: Checks if an event or edge has a loop inflow. Supports an optional attribute parameter. Supported in event and edge contexts. Returns a BOOL. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/statistical-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_18 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## ISLOOPINFLOW([attributeName]) Returns true when event/edge has loop inflow. **Supported context:** event, edge **Parameters:** - ***[attributeName]*** - Attribute to calculate repetitions. If none is entered, the default attribute is mining attribute (activity attribute), optional Data type: STRING (only fixed string is allowed) **Output Data Type**: BOOL ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Windows 365 Service Principal using Azure CLI DESCRIPTION: This Azure CLI command creates the necessary service principal for the Windows 365 application (ID: 0af06dc6-e4b5-4f28-818e-e78e62d137a5) in Microsoft Entra ID. This step is a prerequisite for provisioning Power Automate hosted machines if the service principal doesn't already exist in the tenant. Requires Azure CLI and appropriate Azure permissions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/hosted-machines.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: azurecli CODE: ``` az ad sp create --id 0af06dc6-e4b5-4f28-818e-e78e62d137a5 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Identifying URL Shortener Usage in Desktop Flows using SQL DESCRIPTION: This query detects desktop flows containing scripts that reference URL shorteners. It's useful for assessing potential risks of restricted URL usage within desktop flow scripts. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/automation-analytics-with-fabric-queries.md#2025-04-23_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: sql CODE: ``` SELECT w.name AS 'Desktop flow', w.workflowid AS 'Desktop flow Id', w.createdon AS 'Created on', w.modifiedon AS 'Last modified on', w.definition AS 'Script', w.ownerid AS 'Owner Id', s.fullname AS 'Owner name', s.internalemailaddress AS 'Owner email' FROM workflow w JOIN systemuser s ON w.ownerid = s.systemuserid WHERE w.category = 6 AND w.definition IS NOT NULL AND ( LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%bit.ly%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%linkedin.com%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%aka.ms%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%tinyurl.com%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%goo.gl%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%t.co%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%fb.me%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%is.gd%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%buff.ly%' ); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Retrieving Mouse Position - Power Automate Actions Reference - Markdown DESCRIPTION: Describes the \"Get mouse position\" action in Power Automate Desktop, which retrieves the current screen coordinates of the mouse cursor. Key input parameter is whether the coordinates are relative to the screen or foreground window. Produces MousePosX and MousePosY variables; potential exceptions are listed if operation fails in non-interactive mode. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/mouseandkeyboard.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Markdown CODE: ``` ## Get mouse position\n\nRetrieves the current position of the mouse cursor on the screen in pixel coordinates.\n\n### Input parameters\n\n|Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description|\n|-----|-----|-----|-----|-----|\n|Relative to|N/A|Screen, Foreground window|Screen|Specify whether to retrieve the mouse position in screen coordinates or relative to the top left corner of the active window|\n\n### Variables produced\n\n|Argument|Type|Description|\n|-----|-----|-----|\n|MousePosX|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)|The horizontal (X) value of the mouse position|\n|MousePosY|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)|The vertical (Y) value of the mouse position|\n\n### Exceptions\n\n|Exception|Description|\n|-----|-----|\n|Can't retrieve the mouse position in non interactive mode|Indicates a problem retrieving the mouse cursor position in non-interactive mode|\n ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Drop-Down List Value on Web Page - Power Automate Desktop Low-Code DESCRIPTION: Sets or clears the selected item(s) of a drop-down list control in a web form, supporting single- and multi-select scenarios by name or index. Relies on a web browser instance and a specifically chosen UI element; other parameters include operation mode, option values, regular expression support, wait/load behaviors, and pop-up response. Throws exceptions if selection fails and does not produce output variables. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/webautomation.md#2025-04-23_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: Power Automate Desktop CODE: ``` Action: Set drop-down list value on web page Parameters: Web browser instance: [Variable Required] UI element: [UI Element Required] Operation: [Clear or Select by name/index, Default='Clear all options'] Option names: [List of Text Values, Optional] Use regular expressions: [Boolean, Default=False] Option indices: [List of Numeric Values, Optional] Wait for page to load: [Boolean, Default=True] Timeout for webpage load: [Numeric, Default=60] If a pop-up dialog appears: [Option, Default='Do nothing'] Dialog button to press: [Text, Default='OK'] Output: None Exceptions: Not explicitly listed in this snippet, but implied by context. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Checking String Contains Value in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: The CONTAINS function checks if a string contains a specific value. It returns TRUE if the value is found, FALSE otherwise. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/string-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## CONTAINS([string],[value]) Returns TRUE if the string contains the given value, else returns FALSE. **Parameters:** - **[string]** - input string Data type: STRING - **[value]** - value to be matched in input string Data type: STRING **Output Data Type**: BOOL ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Converting Base64 String to Hexadecimal Format using PowerShell DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell command converts a Base64 encoded string, stored in the Power Automate variable `%Base64Text%`, into its hexadecimal representation. It uses the .NET `System.Convert.FromBase64String` method to decode the Base64 string into a byte array, which is then piped to the `Format-Hex` cmdlet to produce the hexadecimal output. This script is intended to be used within the 'Run PowerShell script' action in Power Automate Desktop. The output is typically stored in the `PowershellOutput` variable generated by the action. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/convert-base64-hexadecimal-format.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` [System.Convert]::FromBase64String("%Base64Text%") | Format-Hex ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining If Action Parameters in Markdown DESCRIPTION: This snippet outlines the input parameters for the If action in a conditional statement. It details the operator and operands using a markdown table format. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/conditionals.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |Operator|N/A|Equal to (=), Not equal to (<>), Greater than (>), Greater than or equal to (>=), Less than (<), Less than or equal to (<=), Contains, Does not contain, Is empty, Is not empty, Starts with, Does not start with, Ends with, Does not end with, Is blank, Is not blank|Equal to (=)|Choose the relationship of first operand to the second operand.| |First operand|No|*||Enter a value name defined by a previous action, text, number or expression to compare with the second operand.| |Second operand|No|*||Enter a value name produced by a previous action, text, number or expression to compare with the first operand.| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Deleting BPF Instance via Web API HTTP DELETE DESCRIPTION: This HTTP DELETE request removes a specific Business Process Flow instance using the Web API. The ID of the BPF instance to be deleted is included in the request URL. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/developer/business-process-flows-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` DELETE [Organization URI]/api/data/v9.0/new_mycustombpfs(dc2ab599-306d-e811-80ff-00155d513100) HTTP/1.1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Extracting Word Document Text Sentence by Sentence using VBScript DESCRIPTION: This VBScript code automates Microsoft Word to open a specified document, reads its content sentence by sentence, and outputs each sentence using `WScript.Echo`. It requires the file path of the Word document to be provided, typically through the placeholder variable `%FilePath%` which should be set in the preceding Power Automate steps (e.g., using a 'Set variable' action) or replaced with a hardcoded path. The script closes the Word application after processing. It's designed to be executed within the Power Automate 'Run VBScript' action, which captures the echoed output into the `VBScriptOutput` variable. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/extract-text-word-document.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: VBScript CODE: ``` ``` VBScript Dim Word Dim WordDoc Dim var Set Word = CreateObject("Word.Application") 'Open the document Set WordDoc = Word.Documents.open("%FilePath%") 'Read the document NumberOfWords = WordDoc.Sentences.count For i = 1 to NumberOfWords WScript.Echo WordDoc.Sentences(i) Next 'Close the document WordDoc.Save Word.Quit 'Release the object variables Set WordDoc = Nothing Set Word = Nothing ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining a Flow with Natural Language using Copilot DESCRIPTION: This snippet provides an example natural language prompt for Power Automate Copilot. The prompt asks Copilot to create a flow that triggers when a new tweet is posted and then sends an email containing the tweeter's username to a specified email address. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/get-started-logic-flow.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: plaintext CODE: ``` when a new tweet is posted, send an email to eug@contoso.com with Twitter username ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Aborting BPF Instance via Web API HTTP PATCH DESCRIPTION: This HTTP PATCH request updates the state of an existing BPF instance to 'Aborted'. It targets the specific BPF instance via its ID in the URL. The request body sets the 'statecode' to 1 (Inactive) and the 'statuscode' to 3 (Aborted) to reflect the change. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/developer/business-process-flows-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` PATCH [Organization URI]/api/data/v9.0/new_mycustombpfs(dc2ab599-306d-e811-80ff-00155d513100) HTTP/1.1 Content-Type: application/json OData-MaxVersion: 4.0 OData-Version: 4.0 { "statecode" : "1", "statuscode": "3" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Work Queue via CSV Import (CSV) DESCRIPTION: Sample CSV data defining a single work queue record for import into Dataverse.
