This configuration needs to be placed within the `` element in the relevant `.config` files. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/proxy-settings.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: xml CODE: ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Simple Query Syntax Examples in Dataverse Search DESCRIPTION: Sample operators and functionality supported by the simple query syntax in Dataverse search, including Boolean operators, precedence operators, wildcards, and exact matches. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/dataverse/search.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` Boolean operators| AND operator; denoted by + \nOR operator; denoted by | \nNOT operator; denoted by -\nPrecedence operators | A search term "hotel+(wifi | luxury)" will search for results containing the term "hotel" and either "wifi" or "luxury" (or both).\nWildcards | Trailing wildcards are supported; for example, "Alp*" searches for "alpine".\nExact matches | A query enclosed in quotation marks " ". ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Getting Link List Count in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Retrieves the total number of links extracted from the web page using the 'Extract data from web page' action. This count is stored in the 'DataFromWebPage' variable (generated by the extraction action) and accessed via its 'RowsCount' property. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/click-elements-list-links.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Power Automate Expression CODE: ``` DataFromWebPage.RowsCount ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining an Adaptive Card Schema for Metadata Updates (JSON) DESCRIPTION: This JSON code defines the structure of an Adaptive Card according to the Adaptive Cards schema (version 1.0). It includes sections for a title, sub-header, description, a set of facts (key-value pairs using placeholders like `{acFact1}`), and a column set for displaying tabular data with headers. The card is designed for display purposes but can be extended with input fields. It uses placeholders (e.g., `acTitle`, `acSubHeader`, `acFactSet`, `acDataContext`) that are expected to be populated dynamically, likely within a Power Automate flow. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/metadata-update-sample.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "$schema": "http://adaptivecards.io/schemas/adaptive-card.json", "type": "AdaptiveCard", "version": "1.0", "body": [ { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Metadata Update Card", "weight": "bolder", "size": "large", "id": "acTitle" }, { "type": "ColumnSet", "columns": [ { "type": "Column", "width": "auto", "items": [ { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Sub Header Tag Line", "weight": "Bolder", "wrap": true, "id": "acSubHeader" } ] } ] }, { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. In condimentum leo lorem, at facilisis augue hendrerit eget. Praesent ut malesuada ipsum. Vivamus semper faucibus felis quis sagittis. Nunc pellentesque metus at nunc gravida, vitae volutpat sapien vehicula. Nulla lorem nibh, porttitor vel semper ut, ornare nec erat.", "wrap": true, "id": "acDescriptionArea" }, { "type": "FactSet", "facts": [ { "title": "Fact 1:", "value": "{acFact1}" }, { "title": "Fact 2:", "value": "{acFact2}" }, { "title": "Fact 3:", "value": "{acFact3}" } ], "id": "acFactSet" }, { "type": "Container", "spacing": "Large", "items": [ { "type": "ColumnSet", "columns": [ { "type": "Column", "items": [ { "type": "TextBlock", "weight": "Bolder", "text": "HEADER 1" } ], "width": "stretch" }, { "type": "Column", "items": [ { "type": "TextBlock", "weight": "Bolder", "text": "HEADER 2" } ], "width": "stretch" }, { "type": "Column", "items": [ { "type": "TextBlock", "weight": "Bolder", "text": "HEADER 3" } ], "width": "stretch" } ] } ], "bleed": true }, { "type": "ColumnSet", "columns": [ { "type": "Column", "items": [ { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Column 1", "wrap": true, "id": "acCol1" } ], "width": "stretch" }, { "type": "Column", "items": [ { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Column 2", "wrap": true, "id": "acCol2" } ], "width": "stretch" }, { "type": "Column", "items": [ { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Column 3", "wrap": true, "id": "acCol4" } ], "width": "stretch" } ], "$data": "acDataContext" } ], "bleed": true } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Converting Date to String in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: The TOSTRING function converts a date to a string. It can optionally apply a formatting string. It takes a date value and an optional formatting string as parameters. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/string-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_15 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## TOSTRING([date],[format]*) Converts a date to a string according to the formatting string (if an optional parameter is specified). **Parameters:** - **[date]** - input date Data type: STRING - **[format*]** - formatting string applied on date [Learn more about formatting strings ](/dotnet/standard/base-types/formatting-types) Date type: STRING (only fixed string is allowed) **Output Data Type**: STRING ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Converting Float to String in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: The TOSTRING function converts a float to a string. It can optionally apply a formatting string. It takes a float value and an optional formatting string as parameters. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/string-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## TOSTRING([float],[format]*) Converts a float to a string according to the formatting string (if an optional parameter is specified). **Parameters:** - **[float]** - input float value Data type: FLOAT - **[format*]** - formatting string [Learn more about formatting strings](/dotnet/standard/base-types/formatting-types) Data type: STRING (only fixed string in allowed) **Output Data Type**: STRING ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Embedding Unauthenticated Power Automate Templates Widget in HTML DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to embed an unauthenticated Power Automate templates widget into a webpage using an iframe. It allows customization of locale, search terms, number of templates, destination, and category. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/developer/embed-flow-dev.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: html CODE: ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using COUNTUNIQUE for Counting Distinct Values in Power Automate Expressions (Pseudo-Expression Language) DESCRIPTION: Presents COUNTUNIQUE, which outputs the count of unique values for a given attribute, expression, or nested operation within a context. Parameters include [context] (grouping) and [value] (attribute/expression of INT, FLOAT, BOOL, STRING, DATE, or TIME). Returns integer output. Useful for determining diversity or variety in metrics. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/aggregations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: pseudo-expression CODE: ``` COUNTUNIQUE([context],[value]) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Blocking User Mouse and Keyboard Input - Power Automate Actions Reference - Markdown DESCRIPTION: Documents the \"Block Input\" action, which blocks or unblocks user mouse and keyboard input to prevent interference during automated flows in Power Automate Desktop. Requires administrator/elevated rights to execute. The snippet specifies the input parameter (Block it) as a boolean, describes that no variables are produced, and lists potential exception messages. Key limitation: action will not run without admin rights, and fails in non-interactive modes. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/mouseandkeyboard.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Markdown CODE: ``` ## Block Input\n\nBlocks user mouse and keyboard input, so that the flow can perform mouse and keyboard actions without interference from the user.\n\n> [!IMPORTANT]\n> Because of its critical functionality, the **Block input** action requires elevated rights to run. Therefore, before using the action, ensure that Power Automate runs with administrator rights. To find more information regarding running Power Automate as an administrator, go to [Run Power Automate with elevated rights](../setup.md#run-power-automate-with-elevated-rights).\n\n### Input parameters\n\n|Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description|\n|-----|-----|-----|-----|-----|\n|Block it|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|True|Specify whether to block or unblock mouse and keyboard input|\n\n### Variables produced\n\nThis action doesn't produce any variables.\n\n### Exceptions\n\n|Exception|Description|\n|-----|-----|\n|Can't block/unblock user input in non interactive mode|Indicates a problem blocking/unblocking input in non-interactive mode|\n|Failed to block/unblock input|Indicates a problem blocking/unblocking input|\n ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Central Custom Action with Enum Selector - Power Automate Desktop - C# DESCRIPTION: Defines a central custom action that takes an enum-based selector to switch between different action behaviors. The action is annotated with Power Automate SDK attributes, and input/output arguments are ordered for UI display. Requires Microsoft.PowerPlatform.PowerAutomate.Desktop.Desktop.Actions.SDK and related namespaces. Inputs include selector choice, first and last name, and age. Output is a message string, which is formatted based on the selected variation. The code demonstrates proper implementation of property ordering and usage of enums for multiple variations. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/create-custom-actions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` using System.ComponentModel; using Microsoft.PowerPlatform.PowerAutomate.Desktop.Desktop.Actions.SDK; using Microsoft.PowerPlatform.PowerAutomate.Desktop.Desktop.Actions.SDK.Attributes; namespace Modules.CustomModule { [Action(Id = "CentralCustomAction")] public class CentralCustomAction : ActionBase { #region Properties [InputArgument, DefaultValue(SelectorChoice.Selector1)] public SelectorChoice Selector { get; set; } [InputArgument(Order = 1)] public string FirstName { get; set; } [InputArgument(Order = 2)] public string LastName { get; set; } [InputArgument(Order = 3)] public int Age { get; set; } [OutputArgument] public string DisplayedMessage { get; set; } #endregion #region Methods Overrides public override void Execute(ActionContext context) { if (Selector == SelectorChoice.Selector1) { DisplayedMessage = $"Hello, {FirstName}!"; } else if (Selector == SelectorChoice.Selector2) { DisplayedMessage = $"Hello, {FirstName} {LastName}!"; } else // The 3rd Selector was chosen { DisplayedMessage = $"Hello, {FirstName} {LastName}!\nYour age is: {Age}"; } } #endregion } // you can see below how to implement an action selector } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Updating (Nullifying) Data in a Row - Simulating Delete for Excel - SQL DESCRIPTION: Uses an UPDATE SQL statement to set one or more columns in a specific Excel worksheet row to NULL, effectively removing the row's data as Excel SQL does not support DELETE operations. Requires an established SQL connection and accurate replacements for the worksheet, column names, and selection condition. The WHERE clause targets the row(s) for nullification based on column identifiers. Intended for scenarios where logical record removal is desired. Limitations include the manual declaration of all columns to nullify. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/sql-queries-excel.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: SQL CODE: ``` UPDATE [SHEET$] SET [COLUMN1]=NULL, [COLUMN2]=NULL WHERE [COLUMN1]='VALUE' ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Converting Binary to Decimal using PowerShell in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell command, executed within the 'Run PowerShell script' action in Power Automate Desktop, converts a binary number string stored in the flow variable 'BinaryNumber' to its decimal equivalent. It utilizes the .NET `System.Convert.ToInt32` method, specifying base 2 for the conversion. The output, the decimal representation, is stored in the 'PowershellOutput' variable. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/convert-data-powershell.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: powershell CODE: ``` # This script is intended to be run within the 'Run PowerShell script' action. # It assumes a Power Automate variable named 'BinaryNumber' holds the binary string. [Convert]::ToInt32($BinaryNumber, 2) # The result is outputted and typically stored in the 'PowershellOutput' variable by the action. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Documenting Exceptions for PDF Merge Action - Markdown DESCRIPTION: This Markdown table outlines the exceptions that may be encountered when merging PDF files in Power Automate. It includes errors for missing files, invalid passwords, and merge failures, equipping users to handle and diagnose potential issues. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/pdf.md#2025-04-23_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Exception|Description|\n|-----|-----|\n|PDF file doesn't exist|File doesn't exist on the given path|\n|Invalid password|The given password is invalid|\n|Failed to merge PDF files|Indicates that an error occurred while merging the files| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using GREATEROREQUALS Expression in Power Automate Conditions DESCRIPTION: Example of using the 'greaterOrEquals' expression in Power Automate to check if the first argument is greater than or equal to the second argument. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/use-expressions-in-conditions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: PowerFx CODE: ``` greaterOrEquals(10,100) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Converting Time to String in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: The TOSTRING function converts a time value to a string. It can optionally apply a formatting string. It takes a time value and an optional formatting string as parameters. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/string-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_16 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## TOSTRING([time],[format]*) Converts a time to a string according to the formatting string (if an optional parameter is specified). **Parameters:** - **[time]** - input time Data type: STRING - **[format*]** - formatting string applied on time [Learn more about formatting strings ](/dotnet/standard/base-types/formatting-types) Data type: STRING (only fixed string is allowed) **Output Data Type**: STRING ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating and Configuring Managed Identity for Azure Data Lake with PowerShell DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell script sequence installs necessary PowerShell modules, logs into Azure, sets the default subscription, and executes scripts for managed identity and policy creation in the context of Process Mining and isolated Azure Data Lake. It requires the Microsoft.PowerApps PowerShell modules, Azure CLI installed, and administrator access to the subscription and environment. The script parameters such as $subscriptionId, $resourceGroupName, $enterprisePolicyLocation, and $environmentId must be pre-defined. The output is a configured managed identity with association through the specified enterprise policy resource, ready for access assignment. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/process-mining-byo-azure-data-lake-private.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: powershell CODE: ``` # PowerShell script # To have ready beforehand $subscriptionId, $resourceGroupName, $enterprisePolicyLocation, $environmentId # Note: The $enterprisePolicyLocation must be set to the same location as the environment. And the environments with spaces should have the spaces removed i.e. “South Africa” -> “southafrica” # Note: You can choose the value for $NewEnterprisePolicyName i.e. CreateMSITokenForExternalLake Install-Module -Name Microsoft.PowerApps.Administration.PowerShell Install-Module -Name Microsoft.PowerApps.PowerShell -AllowClobber Az login Update-AzConfig -DefaultSubscriptionForLogin $subscriptionId ./SetupSubscriptionForPowerPlatform.ps1 $subscriptionId cd Identity ./CreateIdentityEnterprisePolicy.ps1 $subscriptionId $resourceGroupName $NewEnterprisePolicyName $enterprisePolicyLocation ./NewIdentity.ps1 -environmentId $environmentId -policyArmId /subscriptions/$subscriptionId/resourceGroups/$resourceGroupName/providers/Microsoft.PowerPlatform/enterprisePolicies/$NewEnterprisePolicyName -endpoint prod ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Datatable with Column Headers in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create a datatable with column headers using the Set variable action and array notation in Power Automate desktop flows. The ^['ColumnName1', 'ColumnName2'] expression is used for the first row to define column headers. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/variable-data-types.md#2025-04-23_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: PowerAutomate CODE: ``` Set variable DatatableWithHeaders to %{^['Product', 'Price'], ['Product1', '10 USD'], ['Product2', '20 USD']}% ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Cloud Flow - Web API - HTTP DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates sending an HTTP POST request to the Power Platform Web API to create a new workflow (cloud flow). Dependencies include a valid Organization URI and appropriate authentication headers. The JSON body defines properties such as 'category', 'name', 'type', and a complex 'clientdata' object representing the flow definition and connection references. The flow is created in draft state and further configuration or enabling may be needed. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/manage-flows-with-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` POST [Organization URI]/api/data/v9.2/workflows HTTP/1.1\nContent-Type: application/json\n\n{\n "category": 5,\n "name": "Sample flow name",\n "type": 1,\n "description": "This flow reads some data from Dataverse.",\n "primaryentity":"none",\n "clientdata": "{\"properties\": {\"connectionReferences\": {\"shared_commondataserviceforapps\": {\"runtimeSource\": \"embedded\",\"connection\": {},\"api\": { \"name\": \"shared_commondataserviceforapps\" }}},\"definition\": {\"$schema\": \"https:\\/\\/schema.management.azure.com\\/providers\\/Microsoft.Logic\\/schemas\\/2016-06-01\\/workflowdefinition.json#\",\"contentVersion\": \"1.0.0.0\",\"parameters\": {\"$connections\": { \"defaultValue\": {}, \"type\": \"Object\" },\"$authentication\": { \"defaultValue\": {}, \"type\": \"SecureObject\" }},\"triggers\": {\"manual\": {\"metadata\": {},\"type\": \"Request\",\"kind\": \"Button\",\"inputs\": { \"schema\": { \"type\": \"object\", \"properties\": {}, \"required\": [] }}}},\"actions\": {\"List_rows\": {\"runAfter\": {},\"metadata\": {},\"type\": \"OpenApiConnection\",\"inputs\": { \"host\": { \"apiId\": \"\\/providers\\/Microsoft.PowerApps\\/apis\\/shared_commondataserviceforapps\", \"connectionName\": \"shared_commondataserviceforapps\", \"operationId\": \"ListRecords\" }, \"parameters\": { \"entityName\": \"accounts\", \"$select\": \"name\", \"$top\": 1 }, \"authentication\": \"@parameters('$authentication')\"}}}}},\"schemaVersion\": \"1.0.0.0\"}"\n} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Corrected Condition Using length() to Check for Item Existence DESCRIPTION: This Power Automate expression is the corrected version for the 'Condition' action's advanced mode. It uses the `length()` function to determine the number of items in the 'value' array returned by the 'Get_rows' action. It then compares this length to 0 using `@equals()`. If the length is 0, it means the item was not found in the destination SQL table (evaluates to true), and the flow proceeds to the 'If yes' branch to insert a new row. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/odata-filters.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Power Automate Expression Language CODE: ``` @equals(length(body('Get_rows')?['value']), 0) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Date Creation Functions DESCRIPTION: Functions for creating date objects from individual components. Includes TODATE variations with different parameter combinations. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/date-and-time-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` TODATE([year],[month],[day]) TODATE([year],[month],[day],[hour],[minute],[second],[millisecond]) TODATE([year],[month],[day],[time]) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example Username Formats for CyberArk Credentials in Power Automate Connections DESCRIPTION: Illustrates various formats for specifying the username when creating a CyberArk credential intended for use in a Power Automate desktop flow connection. This includes local machine accounts (`` or ``) and Microsoft Entra ID accounts (`` or ``). This username corresponds to the device account under which the desktop flow will run. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/create-cyberark-credential.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: plaintext CODE: ``` or ``` LANGUAGE: plaintext CODE: ``` or ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Detecting Advanced API Request Usage in Desktop Flows using SQL DESCRIPTION: This query retrieves desktop flows that use advanced API request methods like curl, Invoke-RestMethod, and other requests. It's useful for identifying connectivity to external web services or services within desktop flows. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/automation-analytics-with-fabric-queries.md#2025-04-23_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: sql CODE: ``` SELECT w.name AS 'Desktop flow', w.workflowid AS 'Desktop flow Id', w.createdon AS 'Created on', w.modifiedon AS 'Last modified on', w.definition AS 'Script', w.ownerid AS 'Owner Id', s.fullname AS 'Owner name', s.internalemailaddress AS 'Owner email' FROM workflow w JOIN systemuser s ON w.ownerid = s.systemuserid WHERE w.category = 6 AND w.definition IS NOT NULL AND ( LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%curl%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%invoke-restmethod%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%invoke-webrequest%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%httpclient%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%requests.get%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%requests.post%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%fetch%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%axios%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%.ajax%' ); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using MAX for Maximum Value Extraction in Power Automate Expressions (Pseudo-Expression Language) DESCRIPTION: Utilizes the MAX aggregation to return the maximum value of an attribute or expression grouped by context. Takes [context] and [value] as parameters (supports INT, FLOAT, DATE, TIME types). Output is the same type as input. Ideal for metrics like latest or longest event. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/aggregations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: pseudo-expression CODE: ``` MAX([context],[value]) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using 'or' Expression in Power Automate Condition DESCRIPTION: This expression checks if the Status column value is either 'completed' or 'unnecessary'. It's used in a condition to determine which rows to delete from an Excel spreadsheet. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/use-expressions-in-conditions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: Power Automate CODE: ``` @or(equals(item()?['Status'], 'completed'), equals(item()?['Status'], 'unnecessary')) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Reading from CSV File - Power Automate Actions - Markdown DESCRIPTION: Documents the configuration and output of the 'Read from CSV file' action in Microsoft Power Automate. Explains required and optional parameters such as encoding, delimiter, column name row, and trimming options, as well as output variable type. Exception handling is also clearly indicated, fully presented in markdown. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/file.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: Markdown CODE: ``` ## Read from CSV file\n\nRead a CSV file into a data table.\n\nYou can use the **Read from CSV file** action to create a datatable variable with the file's contents. You need to define the path to the CSV file and the encoding to use for reading it, while you can also trim any whitespaces from the extracted cells, handle the first line as column headers, and specify the columns separator.\n\n### Input parameters\n\n|Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description|\n|-----|-----|-----|-----|-----|\n|File path|No|[File](../variable-data-types.md#files-and-folders)||The CSV file to read. This value can be a file path, or a variable containing a file or a textual path|\n|Encoding|N/A|UTF-8, Unicode, Unicode (big-endian), UTF-8 (No byte order mark), Unicode (no byte order mark), System default, ASCII|UTF-8|The encoding to be used for reading the specified CSV file|\n|Trim fields|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|True|Specifies whether to automatically trim off the leading and trailing whitespaces of the extracted cells|\n|First line contains column names|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|False|Specifies whether to use the first row of the CSV resource to set the column names of the resulting data table variant. Enable this option to avoid reading the names as data into the table. Subsequent actions may access the data held by the data table using column names (instead of column numbers).|\n|Columns separator|N/A|Predefined, Custom, Fixed column widths|Predefined|Specifies whether to use a predefined columns separator, a custom one or fixed column widths|\n|Separator|N/A|System default, Comma, Semicolon, Tab|System default|The column-separator to parse the CSV file|\n|Custom separator|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The custom column-separator to use for parsing the CSV resource specified|\n|Fixed column widths|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The fixed column-widths to use for parsing the CSV resource specified. Separate the widths using commas, spaces, tabs or newlines.|\n\n### Variables produced\n\n|Argument|Type|Description|\n|-----|-----|-----|\n|CSVTable|[Datatable](../variable-data-types.md#datatable)|The contents of the CSV file as a data table|\n\n### Exceptions\n\n|Exception|Description|\n|-----|-----|\n|Read from CSV failed|Indicates a problem reading from the CSV file| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Input and Output Arguments for Custom Actions - Power Automate Actions SDK - C# DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to define input and output parameters for a custom action using [InputArgument] and [OutputArgument] attributes in C#. It demonstrates providing a default value for an input via DefaultValue, and defining a property for output. The Execute method uses these parameters to set the output based on the input. Required dependencies include System.ComponentModel, Microsoft.PowerPlatform.PowerAutomate.Desktop.Actions.SDK, and related attribute namespaces. This setup enables Power Automate to recognize and expose parameters in the designer, ensuring user-friendly configuration. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/create-custom-actions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` using System.ComponentModel;\nusing Microsoft.PowerPlatform.PowerAutomate.Desktop.Actions.SDK;\nusing Microsoft.PowerPlatform.PowerAutomate.Desktop.Actions.SDK.Attributes;\n\nnamespace Modules.MyCustomModule\n{\n [Action(Id = \"CustomAction\")]\n public class CustomAction : ActionBase\n {\n [InputArgument, DefaultValue(\"Developer\")]\n public string InputName { get; set; }\n\n [OutputArgument]\n public string DisplayedMessage { get; set; }\n\n public override void Execute(ActionContext context)\n {\n DisplayedMessage = $\"Hello, {InputName}\";\n }\n }\n}\n ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using IF Expression in Power Automate Conditions DESCRIPTION: Example of using the 'if' expression in Power Automate to return a specific value based on whether the condition evaluates to true or false. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/use-expressions-in-conditions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: PowerFx CODE: ``` if(equals(1, 1), 'yes', 'no') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Get Credential Action Parameters in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines the input parameters for the 'Get credential' action in Power Automate. It specifies the required 'Credential' parameter and an optional 'Timeout' parameter, along with their accepted data types and descriptions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/powerautomatesecretvariables.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |Credential|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The credential whose values are retrieved| |Timeout|No|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)|0|The maximum waiting time (in seconds) to get the credential| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Concatenating Strings in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: The CONCAT function concatenates multiple strings. It takes any number of string parameters and returns a single concatenated string. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/string-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## CONCAT([string1],...,[stringN]) Concatenates given strings. **Parameters:** - **[string1]** - input string Data type: STRING - **[stringN]** - last input string Data type: STRING **Output Data Type**: STRING ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Printing Images via rundll32 DOS Command DESCRIPTION: This DOS command utilizes `rundll32.exe` to call the `ImageView_PrintTo` function within `shimgvw.dll` (Windows Picture and Fax Viewer). It prints the specified image file (`Image_Path`) to a designated printer (`Printer_Name`). Both placeholders need to be replaced with the actual file path and printer name before execution. This command is designed to be used as input within the "Run DOS command" action in Power Automate. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/print-images.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: cmd CODE: ``` ``` DOS command rundll32 C:\WINDOWS\system32\shimgvw.dll,ImageView_PrintTo "Image_Path" "Printer_Name" ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Container for Power Automate Widget in HTML DESCRIPTION: This HTML snippet creates a div element that will serve as the container for the Power Automate widget. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/developer/embed-flow-dev.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: html CODE: ```
``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Recording SAP PM Notification Creation using VBScript DESCRIPTION: This VBScript code, typically generated by the SAP GUI Script Recorder, automates the process of creating an SAP Plant Maintenance (PM) Notification using transaction code IW21. It initializes the SAP GUI scripting objects, maximizes the window, navigates through screens by sending virtual keys (sendVKey 0 for Enter), enters data into specific fields using their IDs (e.g., `okcd` for transaction code, `ctxtRIWO00-QMART` for Notification type), and simulates button presses (`press`). It relies on the SAP GUI Scripting engine being enabled and requires established `application`, `connection`, and `session` objects. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/guidance/rpa-sap-playbook/extracting-information-from-SAP-GUI-UI.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: vbscript CODE: ``` If Not IsObject(application) Then Set SapGuiAuto = GetObject("SAPGUI") Set application = SapGuiAuto.GetScriptingEngine End If If Not IsObject(connection) Then Set connection = application.Children(0) End If If Not IsObject(session) Then Set session = connection.Children(0) End If If IsObject(WScript) Then WScript.ConnectObject session, "on" WScript.ConnectObject application, "on" End If session.findById("wnd[0]").maximize session.findById("wnd[0]/tbar[0]/okcd").text = "IW21" session.findById("wnd[0]").sendVKey 0 session.findById("wnd[0]/usr/ctxtRIWO00-QMART").text = "M2" session.findById("wnd[0]/usr/ctxtRIWO00-QMART").caretPosition = 2 session.findById("wnd[0]").sendVKey 0 session.findById("wnd[0]/usr/subSCREE...").text = "My Notification Short Text" ' Actual field ID shortened in source session.findById("wnd[0]/usr/tabsTAB_...").text = "010" ' Actual field ID shortened in source session.findById("wnd[0]/usr/tabsTAB_...").text = "0001" ' Actual field ID shortened in source session.findById("wnd[0]/usr/tabsTAB_...").text = "MAIN" ' Actual field ID shortened in source session.findById("wnd[0]/usr/tabsTAB_...").setFocus ' Actual field ID shortened in source session.findById("wnd[0]/usr/tabsTAB_...").caretPosition = 4 ' Actual field ID shortened in source session.findById("wnd[0]/tbar[0]/btn[11]").press session.findById("wnd[0]/tbar[0]/btn[15]").press ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Referencing Environment Variable in Power Automate HTTP Action DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to reference an environment variable named 'API_Base_URL' within an HTTP action in a Power Automate flow. The variable is used to set the URL dynamically, allowing for easy configuration changes across different environments. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/guidance/coding-guidelines/use-environment-variables.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` @{variables('API_Base_URL')} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Querying Failed Desktop Flow Sessions in SQL for Microsoft Fabric DESCRIPTION: SQL query to retrieve all failed desktop flow runs (flow sessions) for a specific desktop flow and machine within the last seven days. The query selects key attributes including status, timestamps, error details, and execution metrics. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/automation-analytics-with-fabric-queries.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: sql CODE: ``` SELECT flowsessionid, statuscode, startedon, completedon, errorcode, errormessage, sessionusername, runexecutionduration, runduration, runwaitduration, context FROM flowsession WHERE regardingobjectid = '[specific_flow_id]' -- Replace with the actual flow ID AND machineid = '[specific_machine_guid]' -- Replace with the actual machine ID AND statuscode = 8 -- 'Failed' sessions AND createdon >= DATEADD(day, -7, GETDATE()) ORDER BY createdon DESC; ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Detecting Plain Text Passwords in Database Connections using SQL DESCRIPTION: This query finds all desktop flows that use OLEDB database connection strings configured with plaintext passwords. It's useful for identifying potential security risks in database connections within desktop flows. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/automation-analytics-with-fabric-queries.md#2025-04-23_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: sql CODE: ``` SELECT w.name AS 'Desktop flow', w.workflowid AS 'Desktop flow Id', w.createdon AS 'Created on', w.modifiedon AS 'Last modified on', w.definition AS 'Script', w.ownerid AS 'Owner Id', s.fullname AS 'Owner name', s.internalemailaddress AS 'Owner email' FROM workflow w JOIN systemuser s ON w.ownerid = s.systemuserid WHERE w.category = 6 AND w.definition IS NOT NULL AND (LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%;password=%'); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Variables Produced by Subtract Dates Action DESCRIPTION: This markdown table defines the variables produced by the 'Subtract dates' action, specifically the TimeDifference variable of type Numeric value. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/datetime.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Argument|Type|Description| |-----|-----|-----| |TimeDifference|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)|The difference in time as a numeric value| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Deleting a Cloud Flow - Web API - HTTP DESCRIPTION: This HTTP DELETE request removes a cloud flow workflow record using the Web API. The URL specifies the workflow by its primary key, and headers ensure correct OData protocol behavior. Upon success, a 204 NoContent response with OData-Version header is returned; no body is included. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/manage-flows-with-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` DELETE [Organization Uri]/api/data/v9.2/workflows(ac1a3664-b704-ee11-8f6e-000d3a9933c9)\nOData-MaxVersion: 4.0\nOData-Version: 4.0\nIf-None-Match: null\nAccept: application/json ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Flow Run URL Construction DESCRIPTION: HTTP URL template for constructing a direct link to a specific flow run, using environment name, logic app name, and run details from the workflow() function. It specifies the 'Credential' variable of type 'Credential' that contains the retrieved credential content. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/powerautomatesecretvariables.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Argument|Type|Description| |-----|-----|-----| |Credential|[Credential](../variable-data-types.md#credentials)|The content of the retrieved credential| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Trimming Right Whitespace in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: The RTRIM function removes whitespace from the end of a string. It takes a single string parameter and returns the string with trailing whitespace removed. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/string-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## RTRIM([string]) Removes whitespace from the end of the string. **Parameters:** - **[string]** - input string Data type: STRING **Output Data Type**: STRING ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining an Adaptive Card Poll in JSON DESCRIPTION: This JSON code defines the structure of an Adaptive Card (version 1.0) for creating a poll. It uses elements like 'TextBlock' for displaying static text such as the title ('Poll Request'), header tagline, main header, instructions, and the poll question itself, identified by IDs like 'Title', 'acHeaderTagLine', 'acHeader', 'acInstructions', and 'acPollQuestion'. An 'Input.ChoiceSet' element with ID 'acPollChoices' presents the poll options as radio buttons (due to 'style': 'expanded') and captures the user's selection. An 'Action.Submit' button with the title 'Submit' allows users to submit their choice. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/poll-generator-sample.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` {     "$schema": "http://adaptivecards.io/schemas/adaptive-card.json",     "type": "AdaptiveCard",     "version": "1.0",     "body": [         {             "type": "TextBlock", Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Example showing how to set up a trigger condition to check if an expense amount is greater than $100 before starting an approval flow. This optimization ensures the flow only runs when the specified condition is met rather than for every data change. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/guidance/coding-guidelines/optimize-power-automate-triggers.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: power-automate CODE: ``` When a row is added, modified, or deleted\nTrigger Condition: @greater(triggerBody()?['amount'], 100)\nStart an approval ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Clickable HTML Link in a Power Automate Email DESCRIPTION: This HTML snippet demonstrates how to embed a clickable link in an email body within a Power Automate flow using the HTML editor. It utilizes an anchor tag (``) where the `href` attribute dynamically references the shared file's URL (`{WebURL}`) and the link text displays the file's name (`{name}`), both obtained from previous flow steps (like OneDrive 'Create share link' and 'Parse JSON'). This requires switching the email body editor to HTML view (``) in the 'Send an email (V2)' action. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/forms/popular-scenarios.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: html CODE: ``` {name} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Time Interval Creation Functions DESCRIPTION: Functions for creating time intervals from various time unit specifications. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/date-and-time-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` TOTIME([hour],[minute],[second],[millisecond]) TOTIMEFROMDAYS([value]) TOTIMEFROMHOURS([value]) TOTIMEFROMMILLIS([value]) TOTIMEFROMMINUTES([value]) TOTIMEFROMSECONDS([value]) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Performing Cross-Table Navigation in BPF via Web API HTTP PATCH DESCRIPTION: This HTTP PATCH request demonstrates cross-table navigation within a BPF instance. It updates the specified BPF instance by setting the active stage to the last stage ('activestageid'), updating the 'traversedpath' accordingly, and changing the associated primary table row by setting the 'bpf_contactid@odata.bind' property to a new contact record. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/developer/business-process-flows-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_11 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` PATCH [Organization URI]/api/data/v9.0/new_mycustombpfs(dc2ab599-306d-e811-80ff-00155d513100) HTTP/1.1 Content-Type: application/json OData-MaxVersion: 4.0 OData-Version: 4.0 { "activestageid@odata.bind": "/processstages(a107e2fd-7543-4c1a-b6b4-b8060ecb1a1a)", "traversedpath":"9a9185f5-b75b-4bbb-9c2b-a6626683b99b,19a11fc0-3398-4214-8522-cb2a97f66e4b,a107e2fd-7543-4c1a-b6b4-b8060ecb1a1a", "bpf_contactid@odata.bind": "/contacts(0e3f10b0-da33-e811-80fc-00155d513100)" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Calculating Average Case Duration per Specific Attribute (Statistics) DESCRIPTION: Calculates the average duration using the 'CasesPerAttribute' context within a Statistics case-level attribute context. It returns the average duration of all cases in the view that share the same value for a specified attribute (e.g., Supplier.City), ensuring each case is counted only once. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/calculation-context.md#2025-04-23_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: PowerAutomateExpression CODE: ``` AVG(CasesPerAttribute, DURATION()) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using LESS Expression in Power Automate Conditions DESCRIPTION: Example of using the 'less' expression in Power Automate, which compares if the first argument is less than the second argument. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/use-expressions-in-conditions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: PowerFx CODE: ``` less(10,100) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Finding Desktop Flows Lacking Error Handling using SQL DESCRIPTION: This query searches for desktop flows that lack error handling mechanisms such as 'on block error' or 'on error'. It's important for ensuring robustness and reliability in script execution within desktop flows. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/automation-analytics-with-fabric-queries.md#2025-04-23_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: sql CODE: ``` SELECT w.name AS 'Desktop flow', w.workflowid AS 'Desktop flow Id', w.createdon AS 'Created on', w.modifiedon AS 'Last modified on', w.definition AS 'Script', w.ownerid AS 'Owner Id', s.fullname AS 'Owner name', s.internalemailaddress AS 'Owner email' FROM workflow w JOIN systemuser s ON w.ownerid = s.systemuserid WHERE w.category = 6 AND w.definition IS NOT NULL AND NOT (LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%on block error%' OR LOWER(w.definition) LIKE '%on error%'); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Describing Get Details of Window Action in Power Automate Documentation (Markdown) DESCRIPTION: Documents the 'Get details of window' UI automation action in Power Automate. Includes explanation of input arguments, output variables, and handled exceptions in Markdown tables for users referencing actions in the documentation. Designed for use within Markdown technical documentation and does not require additional dependencies. Inputs describe the window and property to extract, with output presenting the requested window property. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/uiautomation.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## Get details of window\n\nGets a property of a window such as its title or its source text.\n\n### Input parameters\n\n|Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description|\n|-----|-----|-----|-----|-----|\n|Window|No|[UI element](../ui-elements.md)||The window to get details from|\n|Window property|N/A|Get window title, Get window text, Get window location and size, Get process name|Get window title|Choose which property of the window to extract|\n|Bring to front|N/A|Boolean value|True|Specify whether the window containing the UI element will be brought to the front during execution. If this option is disabled, the action is executed in the background. Note that not all UI elements are compatible with having the option disabled. Additionally, if execution of the action requires scrolling, disabling this option might not extract all elements.|\n\n### Variables produced\n\n|Argument|Type|Description|\n|-----|-----|-----|\n|WindowProperty|[General value](../variable-data-types.md#general-value)|The retrieved information of the window|\n\n### Exceptions\n\n|Exception|Description|\n|-----|-----|\n|Failed to retrieve property of window|Indicates a problem retrieving the window property| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Power Automate SharePoint Create File Action DESCRIPTION: Adds and configures the SharePoint action to store the converted PDF file. It specifies the target SharePoint site address and the 'PDF - Finished files' folder path. The file name is constructed using the base file name from the Muhimbi action output appended with '.pdf', and the file content is taken directly from the Muhimbi action's processed output. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/includes/learning-create-pdf.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Power Automate CODE: ``` Action: SharePoint – Create file Site address: [Your SharePoint Site URL] Folder path: /Shared Documents/PDF – Finished files File name: [Dynamic Content: Base file name].pdf File content: [Dynamic Content: Processed file content] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Documenting Exceptions for Text Actions in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to document exceptions that may occur during text manipulation actions in Power Automate. It includes the exception name and its description. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/text.md#2025-04-23_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Exception|Description| |-----|-----| |Provided regular expression is invalid|Indicates that the provided regular expression is invalid| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Checkbox State on Web Form - Power Automate Desktop Low-Code DESCRIPTION: Enables checking or unchecking a checkbox element on a web page, referencing the target via UI element within a web browser session. Primary parameters include desired checkbox state, waiting for load, pop-up management, and timeout configuration. The action triggers errors if the target element cannot be found or if checkbox state change fails; no output variables are produced. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/webautomation.md#2025-04-23_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: Power Automate Desktop CODE: ``` Action: Set check box state on web page Parameters: Web browser instance: [Variable Required] UI element: [UI Element Required] Check box state: [Checked/Unchecked, Default=Checked] Wait for page to load: [Boolean, Default=True] Timeout for webpage to load: [Numeric, Default=60] If a pop-up dialog appears: [Option, Default='Do nothing'] Dialog button to press: [Text, Default='OK'] Output: None Exceptions: - Element with specified CSS selector not found - Failed to set the state of the checkbox ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using MIN for Minimum Value Extraction in Power Automate Expressions (Pseudo-Expression Language) DESCRIPTION: MIN returns the smallest value for a given attribute or expression, grouped by context. Inputs: [context] and [value] (numeric, date, or time types). Output matches input type. Useful for earliest, shortest, or minimum-case calculations in custom metrics. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/aggregations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: pseudo-expression CODE: ``` MIN([context],[value]) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Documenting Input Parameters for Conditional Web Page Content Check in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Markdown table detailing input parameters for the 'If web page contains' action, used to conditionally check for the presence of text or elements on a web page. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/webautomation.md#2025-04-23_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |Web browser instance|No|[Web browser instance](../variable-data-types.md#instances)||Enter or choose the variable that contains the web browser instance to work with| |Check if web page|N/A|Contains element, Doesn't contain element, Contains text, Doesn't contain text|Contains element|Check whether a specific text or web page element exists in a web page| |UI element|No|[UI element](../ui-elements.md)||Select the UI element on web page to check for| |Text|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||Enter the text on web page to check for| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Calculating Working Hours Duration Between First/Last 'C' Activity in Process Mining Expression DESCRIPTION: This expression calculates the duration between the first occurrence of Activity 'C' (specifically its start time) and the last occurrence of Activity 'C' (specifically its end time) within a case, considering only working hours. It uses `FIRSTIF()` and `LASTIF()` to identify the relevant events based on the 'Activity' attribute within the `CaseEvents` context. The `DURATIONCALENDAR()` operator then computes the time difference based on the working hours defined in the applied calendar, rather than a simple timestamp difference. The result is a single duration value per case. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/custom-metrics-advanced-examples.md#2025-04-23_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: Process Mining Expression CODE: ``` DURATIONCALENDAR(FIRSTIF(CaseEvents, Activity == "C").Start(), LASTIF(CaseEvents, Activity == "C").End()) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining EVENTCOUNT() Operation in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: Returns the number of events in a case or process. Supported in process and event contexts. Output is of INT data type. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/statistical-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## EVENTCOUNT() Returns number of the events in the case/process. **Supported context:** process, event **Output Data Type**: INT ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Subprocess Filter Values Using Expression in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to use expressions to define filter criteria for both string and numeric attributes in the subprocess filter. There's a checkbox to wrap text within the input field, which makes it easier for you to view in the editor. Text value variables accept numbers as inputs, but keep in mind that if you modify this value and try to pass it to an action with an input parameter that only accepts numeric value, the flow throws an exception error when it reaches that point. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Moving Mouse to Specific Position - Power Automate Actions Reference - Markdown DESCRIPTION: Details the \"Move mouse\" action used in Power Automate Desktop to move the mouse cursor to a specified X/Y coordinate, with various animation styles and relative origins (screen, active window, current mouse). No output variables are produced. Includes input parameter descriptions, default values, and exception handling. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/mouseandkeyboard.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Markdown CODE: ``` ## Move mouse\n\nMoves the mouse to a specific position.\n\n### Input parameters\n\n|Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description|\n|-----|-----|-----|-----|-----|\n|Position X|No|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)||The horizontal (X) value of the position to send the mouse to|\n|Position Y|No|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)||The vertical (Y) value of the position to send the mouse to|\n|Relative to|N/A|Screen, Active window, Current mouse position|Screen|Specify whether the new mouse position will be relative to the top left corner of the screen, the foremost window, or the current mouse position|\n|Move mouse from previous position|N/A|Instant, With animation (low speed), With animation (normal speed), With animation (high speed)|Instant|Specify how to move the mouse|\n\n### Variables produced\n\nThis action doesn't produce any variables.\n\n### Exceptions\n\n|Exception|Description|\n|-----|-----|\n|Can't move mouse in non interactive mode|Indicates a problem moving the mouse in non-interactive mode|\n|Failed to move mouse|Indicates a problem moving the mouse|\n ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Converting String to Lowercase in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: The LOWER function converts a given string to lowercase. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/dynamics365-fin-rpa.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Known issue |Workaround| |----|----|\n|The cloud flow doesn't run after selecting **Play** in the flow designer |Go back to the solution explorer, select the **…** menu for the app or flow, and then select **Turn On**.| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Updating a Cloud Flow - Web API - HTTP DESCRIPTION: This HTTP PATCH request updates a cloud flow's properties, including description, owner, and state, using the Power Platform Web API. The request targets a specific workflow resource and requires OData versioning headers. The body includes updated values, and the owner must be referenced using the '@odata.bind' notation as per OData standards. Returns a 204 No Content response if successful. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/manage-flows-with-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` PATCH [Organization URI]/api/data/v9.2/workflows(7598c284-01ee-ed11-8849-000d3a993550)\nContent-Type: application/json\nOData-MaxVersion: 4.0 \nOData-Version: 4.0\nIf-Match: * \n\n{\n "description" : "This flow will ensure consistency across systems.",\n "ownerid@odata.bind": "systemusers(8061643d-ebf7-e811-a974-000d3a1e1c9a)",\n "statecode" : 1\n} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Sending a Keyboard Shortcut Using Power Automate Curly Bracket Notation - Markdown DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates sending a keypress (e.g., Ctrl+B) using Power Automate's 'Send keys' action. The syntax uses curly brackets for the modifier and parentheses to indicate the modifier is held while pressing another key. Required context: Power Automate Desktop and a focused application window. 'Text to send' should be populated precisely as shown. Inputs: name(s) of key(s) to send. Output: simulated keystroke(s) in the target application. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/automate-applications-keyboard-shortcuts.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` **{Control}({B})** ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining TemplatesSettings Configuration for Power Automate Widget DESCRIPTION: This snippet outlines the structure of the `TemplatesSettings` object (using TypeScript syntax) used to configure widgets that allow flow creation from templates (Flows, FlowCreation, Templates widgets). It includes optional parameters such as `defaultParams` (pre-filling parameters), `destination` ('new' or 'details' page), `pageSize` (number of templates shown), `searchTerm`, `templateCategory`, `useServerSideProvisioning`, and `enableDietDesigner` to control the template browsing and flow creation experience. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/developer/embed-flow-dev.md#2025-04-23_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: typescript CODE: ``` templatesSettings?: { defaultParams?: any; destination?: string; pageSize?: number; searchTerm?: string; templateCategory?: string; useServerSideProvisioning?: boolean; enableDietDesigner?: boolean; }; ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Extracting and Returning SAP Notification ID via VBScript DESCRIPTION: This modified VBScript snippet enhances a recorded SAP script to extract a newly created Notification ID from the SAP status bar after saving (pressing btn[11]). It retrieves the full status bar text using `session.findById("wnd[0]/sbar/pane[0]").text`, then uses nested `Replace` functions and the `Trim` function to remove surrounding text ("Notification" and " saved") and isolate the ID. Finally, it uses `WScript.Echo` to output the extracted `notificationID`, making it available as the `VBScriptOutput` variable in the Power Automate Desktop 'Run VBScript' action. It also includes pressing the Exit button (btn[15]). SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/guidance/rpa-sap-playbook/extracting-information-from-SAP-GUI-UI.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: vbscript CODE: ``` ' This is the Save button session.findById("wnd[0]/tbar[0]/btn[11]").press ' This is the full Status Bar text that contain the data to be extracted statusBarMessage = session.findById("wnd[0]/sbar/pane[0]").text ' Trimming and removing any text surrounding our new notification Id notificationID = Trim(Replace(Replace(statusBarMessage, "Notification", ""), " saved", "")) ' This is the Exit button session.findById("wnd[0]/tbar[0]/btn[15]").press ' This writes the newly created Id to the Run VBScript output variable in Power Automate Desktop WScript.Echo notificationID ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Central Action Execution Logic Based on Selector - Power Automate Desktop - C# DESCRIPTION: Override of the Execute method from the central custom action. Implements logic to format the output message string according to the selected enum value. Requires input parameters corresponding to selector, first name, last name, and age. Returns a custom-formatted string as output. Dependent on the main custom action class structure and property types. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/create-custom-actions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` public override void Execute(ActionContext context) { if (Selector == SelectorChoice.Selector1) { DisplayedMessage = $"Hello, {FirstName}!"; } else if (Selector == SelectorChoice.Selector2) { DisplayedMessage = $"Hello, {FirstName} {LastName}!"; } else // The 3rd Selector was chosen { DisplayedMessage = $"Hello, {FirstName} {LastName}!\nYour age is: {Age}"; } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Input Parameters for 'Wait for window' Action in Markdown DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines a table of input parameters for the 'Wait for window' action, including argument names, optional status, accepted values, default values, and descriptions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/uiautomation.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |Find window|N/A|By window UI element, By window instance/handle, By title and/or class|By window UI element|Specify whether to look for the window using a UI element or a combination of window title/class| |Window title|Yes|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The window title. Wildcards can be used, like '?' or '*'.| |Window|No|[UI element](../ui-elements.md)||The window UI element| |Window instance|No|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)||The instance or handle of the window to check| |Window class|Yes|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||If there are two windows with the same title, window class might help differentiate between them. In this case, enter the class of the window to be used| |Wait for window to|N/A|Open, Close, Become focused, Lose focus|Open|Whether to wait for a specific window to open, close, become focused (i.e become the foreground window), or lose focus (i.e stop being the foreground window).| |Focus window after it opens|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|False|Bring the window to the front after it opens, so later actions are directed at this window| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing Conditional Logic with IF() in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: Evaluates a boolean condition (`EventCount() > 10`). If the condition is true, it returns the first specified value ("Complex"); otherwise, it returns the second specified value ("Simple"). This example metric is applicable on the case overview statistics screen to categorize cases based on event count. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/other-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: dsl CODE: ``` IF(EventCount() > 10, "Complex", "Simple") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Querying Dataverse Logs V2 by Flow Session ID via HTTP API - HTTP DESCRIPTION: This HTTP request example demonstrates how to retrieve log records associated with a specific Flow Session from Dataverse using the v9.0 API endpoint. It uses an HTTP GET to the flowsessions entity, appending the Flow Session GUID and the navigation property to access related FlowLog records. The Organization URI should be replaced with your environment's Dataverse API base URL. The request will return the log data for the specified session if permissions allow. Ensure that proper authentication and required API permissions are provided in headers. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/configure-desktop-flow-logs.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` [Organization URI]/api/data/v9.0/flowsessions(aaaaaaaa-0000-1111-2222-bbbbbbbbbbbb)/flowsession_flowlog_parentobjectid ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Deleting Specific User's Custom Connectors in PowerShell DESCRIPTION: PowerShell script to delete all custom connectors created by a specific user ID. Requires admin privileges and PowerApps account authentication. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/privacy-dsr-delete.md#2025-04-23_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` Add-PowerAppsAccount $deleteDsrUserId = "{userID}" #Retrieves all custom connectors created by the specified userID and deletes them Get-AdminConnector -CreatedBy $deleteDsrUserId | Remove-AdminConnector ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Enabling Organization Selection and List via Windows Registry - Registry DESCRIPTION: Allows users to select organizations or automatically connect to a preset list at sign-in by setting 'EnableOrganizationPicker' (String) with a JSON-formatted value under 'SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Power Automate Desktop' in HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE. The 'isEnabled', 'organizationList', and 'selectOrganizationFromListIsEnabled' fields enable/disable switching and curate available organizations. Values must be set in proper JSON and string format, and improper setting may prevent expected organization selection behavior. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/governance.md#2025-04-23_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: registry CODE: ``` Windows Registry Editor Version 5.00\n\n[HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Power Automate Desktop]\n"EnableOrganizationPicker"="{\"isEnabled\":1,\"organizationList\":[\"10z677m8-l4v6-9cm5-c6n6-r1747rp5338k\",\"86d487j7-y1t2-9gk7-k7n2-x5079jq4619r\"],\"selectOrganizationFromListIsEnabled\":1}"\n ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Listing All Flows (Including Deleted) in an Environment using PowerShell DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell command retrieves a list of all flows within the specified Power Apps environment, identified by its unique name (e.g., '41a90621-d489-4c6f-9172-81183bd7db6c'). The `-IncludeDeleted $true` parameter ensures that flows soft-deleted within the last 21 days are included in the results. This is crucial for identifying the `FlowName` (GUID) required to restore a deleted flow. Requires prior authentication using `Add-PowerAppsAccount` and the environment name. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/how-tos-restore-deleted-flow.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` Get-AdminFlow -EnvironmentName 41a90621-d489-4c6f-9172-81183bd7db6c -IncludeDeleted $true //To view examples: Get-Help Get-AdminFlow -Examples ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Getting Web Element Details in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to use the 'Get details of element on web page' action in Power Automate. It allows users to retrieve the value of a specific attribute from a web element. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/webautomation.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## Get details of element on web page Get the value of an element's attribute on a web page. ### Input parameters |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |Web browser instance|No|[Web browser instance](../variable-data-types.md#instances)||Enter or choose the variable that contains the web browser instance to work with| |UI element|No|[UI element](../ui-elements.md)||Select the UI element on web page to get details from| |Attribute name|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)|Own Text|Enter or select the attribute whose value to retrieve| ### Variables produced |Argument|Type|Description| |-----|-----|-----| |AttributeValue|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)|The value of the web element's attribute| ### Exceptions |Exception|Description| |-----|-----| |Failed to retrieve attribute of UI element on web page|Indicates a problem retrieving attribute of web page element| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Enum for Selector Choice - Power Automate Desktop - C# DESCRIPTION: Defines the SelectorChoice enumeration with three members, each representing a selector variant for the central custom action. This enum allows the main action to switch logic depending on user/UI input. Required by central action and selector classes to implement switching and filtering. No dependencies except the C# language. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/create-custom-actions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` public enum SelectorChoice { Selector1, Selector2, Selector3 } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Converting String to Integer in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: The TOINT function converts a string to an integer. If conversion fails, it returns 0 or an optional default value. It takes a string to convert and an optional default value as parameters. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/string-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_11 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## TOINT([string],[default]) Converts a string to an integer. Returns 0 or default value (optional) if conversion error. occurs **Parameters:** - **[string]** - input string to be converted Data type: STRING - **[default]** - default value Data type: INT, FLOAT **Output Data Type**: INT ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Calculating Average Duration for All Edges in View DESCRIPTION: Calculates the average duration across all edges within the current view filters using the 'ViewEdges' context. When visualized on the process map, this results in a single, consistent average duration value applicable to all activities and edges within the view. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/calculation-context.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: PowerAutomateExpression CODE: ``` AVG(ViewEdges, DURATION()) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Converting Timespan to Total Seconds in Power Automate Expressions DESCRIPTION: Calculates the total duration of a given timespan value, expressed in whole and fractional seconds. The input parameter '[time]' must be of TIME data type, and the function returns a FLOAT. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/date-and-time-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: powerautomate-expression CODE: ``` TOTALSECONDS([time]) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Input Parameters for 'If window' Action in Markdown DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines a table of input parameters for the 'If window' action, including argument names, optional status, accepted values, default values, and descriptions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/uiautomation.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |Get window|N/A|By window UI element, By window instance/handle, By title and/or class|By window UI element|Specify whether to look for the Window using a UI element or a combination of window title/class| |Window title|Yes|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The window title. Wildcards can be used, like '?' or '*'.| |Window|No|[UI element](../ui-elements.md)||The window UI element| |Window instance|No|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)||The instance or handle of the window to check| |Window class|Yes|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||If there are two windows with the same title, window class might help differentiate between them. In this case, enter the class of the window to be used.| |Check if window|N/A|Is open, Isn't open, Is focused, Isn't focused|Is open|The state of the window to be checked| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example JSON Work Queue Item in Power Automate Desktop DESCRIPTION: This JSON structure represents a work queue item in Power Automate desktop. It contains invoice details that would be used in a hypothetical finance portal for Fabrikam. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/work-queues-process.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "InvoiceId": "I-1006", "InvoiceDate": "06/04/2023", "AccountName": "Fabrikam", "ContactEmail": "invoicing@fabrikam.com", "Amount": 1253.78, "Status": "Paid", "WorkQueueKey": "Vendor Invoices", "ComponentState": 0, "OverwriteTime": "1900-01-01T00:00:00" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Exceptions for Get Current Date and Time Action DESCRIPTION: This markdown table defines the possible exceptions that can occur when using the 'Get current date and time' action, including failure to retrieve current date/time and invalid country/region specification. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/datetime.md#2025-04-23_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Exception|Description| |-----|-----| |Failed to get current date and time|Indicates that there was a problem retrieving the current date and time| |Specified country/region not found|Indicates that the specified country or region wasn't found| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using OData Filter Expressions for Row Triggers in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Examples of OData filter expressions used in the 'Filter rows' property to trigger flows only when specific conditions are met. These expressions evaluate after changes are saved in Dataverse. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/dataverse/create-update-delete-trigger.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: OData CODE: ``` firstname eq 'John' ``` LANGUAGE: OData CODE: ``` contains(firstname,'John') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Cloud Flow Definition and Connection References - JSON DESCRIPTION: This snippet provides a JSON schema for the 'clientdata' property in a cloud flow creation or update, including connection references and the flow's workflow definition. It outlines how connection references and Logic Apps workflow definitions are structured within the flow, detailing the schema, properties, triggers, and actions. Used as the payload or sub-property in API requests. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/manage-flows-with-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` {\n "properties": {\n "connectionReferences": {\n "shared_commondataserviceforapps": {\n "runtimeSource": "embedded",\n "connection": {},\n "api": { \n "name": "shared_commondataserviceforapps" \n }\n }\n },\n "definition": {\n "$schema": "https://schema.management.azure.com/providers/Microsoft.Logic/schemas/2016-06-01/workflowdefinition.json#",\n "contentVersion": "1.0.0.0",\n "parameters": {\n "$connections": { "defaultValue": {}, "type": "Object" },\n "$authentication": { "defaultValue": {}, "type": "SecureObject" }\n },\n "triggers": {\n "manual": {\n "metadata": {},\n "type": "Request",\n "kind": "Button",\n "inputs": {\n "schema": { "type": "object", "properties": {}, "required": [] }\n }\n }\n },\n "actions": {\n "List_rows": {\n "runAfter": {},\n "metadata": {},\n "type": "OpenApiConnection",\n "inputs": {\n "host": {\n "apiId": "/providers/Microsoft.PowerApps/apis/shared_commondataserviceforapps",\n "connectionName": "shared_commondataserviceforapps",\n "operationId": "ListRecords"\n },\n "parameters": {\n "entityName": "accounts",\n "$select": "name",\n "$top": 1\n },\n "authentication": "@parameters('$authentication')"\n }\n }\n }\n }\n },\n "schemaVersion": "1.0.0.0"\n} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Trimming Left Whitespace in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: The LTRIM function removes whitespace from the beginning of a string. It takes a single string parameter and returns the string with leading whitespace removed. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/string-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## LTRIM([string]) Removes whitespace from the beginning of the string. **Parameters:** - **[string]** - input string Data type: STRING **Output Data Type**: STRING ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Identifying Machine and Licensing Capacity Issues in SQL DESCRIPTION: This query identifies machine and licensing-related capacity issues for a specific desktop flow. It helps in optimizing resource allocation and addressing performance constraints by providing information on machine status, capacity, and last heartbeat date. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/automation-analytics-with-fabric-queries.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: sql CODE: ``` SELECT f.machineid, fm.name AS machine_name, CASE WHEN mg.managementtype = 0 THEN 'Regular Machine (Group)' ELSE 'Hosted Machine (Group)' END AS managementtype, mg.maxmanagedmachinecount AS maxmanagedmachinecount, fm.lastheartbeatdate AS last_heartbeat_date, fm.sessioncapacity AS 'Max Parallel Sessions', fm.overcapacitysince, CASE WHEN fm.overcapacitysince IS NOT NULL THEN 'Over Capacity' ELSE 'Within Capacity' END AS capacity_status FROM flowsession f JOIN flowmachinegroup mg ON f.machinegroupid = mg.flowmachinegroupid JOIN flowmachine fm ON f.machinegroupid = fm.flowmachinegroupid WHERE f.regardingobjectid = '[specific_flow_id]' -- Replace with the actual flow ID GROUP BY f.machineid, fm.name, mg.managementtype, mg.maxmanagedmachinecount, fm.lastheartbeatdate, fm.sessioncapacity, fm.overcapacitysince ORDER BY capacity_status DESC, fm.lastheartbeatdate DESC; ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accessing a Property of a PDF Table Info List Item - Power Automate Expression DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to retrieve the value of a specific property (like DataTable) from a particular element in a list of PDF table info objects. Requires the list variable and valid property names as described in the documentation. Replace 'PropertyName' and 'ItemNumber' appropriately. The output is the value of the selected property from the specified table info item.
