SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/variable-data-types.md#2025-04-23_snippet_11 LANGUAGE: Expression CODE: ``` %VariableName[ItemNumber].PropertyName% ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Converting String to Uppercase in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: The UPPER function converts a given string to uppercase. It takes a single string parameter and returns the uppercase version of that string. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/string-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_18 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## UPPER([string]) Returns upper-case version of a given text string. **Parameters:** - **[string]** - input string Data type: STRING **Output Data Type**: STRING ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accessing Browser Top-Left Y Coordinate (Power Automate Desktop) DESCRIPTION: Retrieves the Y-coordinate (vertical position) of the top-left corner of the HTML page's display area within the browser window using a Power Automate Desktop expression. Assumes a browser instance is stored in a variable named '%Browser%'. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/get-coordinates-size-web-element.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: powerautomate-expressions CODE: ``` %Browser.DisplayRectangleY% ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Executing Cosmos SQL Query with ExecuteCosmosSqlQuery API (HTTP) DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to structure and call the ExecuteCosmosSqlQuery API endpoint via HTTP in Microsoft Dataverse to query activity logs from the FlowLogs table. It requires a valid Organization URI, Dataverse Web API (v9.2), and appropriate table access. Key parameters include the SQL query text (QueryText), entity logical name (EntityLogicalName), query parameters as a JSON payload (QueryParameters), and the page size (PageSize). The query retrieves multiple log properties filtered by type and ordered by start time. Input values must match the Dataverse entity and authentication context. Output is the paginated query result set for desktop flow action logs; limitations exist for log visibility and bulk actions as noted in the documentation. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/configure-desktop-flow-logs.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` [Organization URI]/api/data/v9.2/ExecuteCosmosSqlQuery( QueryText=@p1,EntityLogicalName=@p2,QueryParameters=@p3,PageSize=@p4)? @p1: 'SELECT c.props.flowlogid as flowlogid, c.props.createdon as createdon, c.props.data as data, c.props.level as level, c.props.type as type, c.ttl as ttlinseconds, c.props.cloudflowid as cloudflowid, c.props.cloudflowrunid as cloudflowrunid, c.props.desktopflowid as desktopflowid, c.props.flowmachineid as flowmachineid, c.props.flowmachinegroupid as flowmachinegroupid, c.props.flowsessionid as flowsessionid, c.props.workqueueid as workqueueid, c.props.workqueueitemid as workqueueitemid FROM c WHERE c.props.type IN (100000001) ORDER BY c.props.data.startTime DESC' @p2: 'flowlog' @p3: {"Keys":["@referencingParentId","@referencingParentLogicalName"],"Values":[{"Type":"System.Guid","Value":"40590757-a9c0-4f4c-abfc-e2f389049d90"},{"Type":"System.String","Value":"flowsession"}]} @p4: 50 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Filtering Deleted Flows by Display Name in an Environment using PowerShell DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell command filters the list of flows within a specific environment ('3c2f7648-ad60-4871-91cb-b77d7ef3c239') to find those whose display name contains the string "Testing". Like the general listing command, `-IncludeDeleted $true` includes soft-deleted flows. This helps locate the specific `FlowName` (GUID) of a deleted flow when its exact name isn't known but part of its display name is. Requires prior authentication and the environment name. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/how-tos-restore-deleted-flow.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` Get-AdminFlow Testing -EnvironmentName 3c2f7648-ad60-4871-91cb-b77d7ef3c239 -IncludeDeleted $true ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Listing Top 10 Desktop Flow Error Codes using SQL DESCRIPTION: This SQL query identifies the top 10 most frequent error codes encountered in desktop flow runs over the past 7 days. It filters the `flowlog` table for entries within the last week that have a status of 'Failed', extracts the `errorCode` from the JSON `data` column using `JSON_VALUE`, groups the results by error code, counts the occurrences of each, and orders them by frequency in descending order. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/automation-analytics-with-fabric-queries.md#2025-04-23_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: sql CODE: ``` SELECT TOP(10) JSON_VALUE(data, '$.errorCode') AS ErrorCode, COUNT(*) AS OccurrenceCount FROM [flowlog] WHERE createdon >= DATEADD(day, -7, GETDATE()) AND JSON_VALUE(data, '$.status') = 'Failed' GROUP BY JSON_VALUE(data, '$.errorCode') ORDER BY OccurrenceCount DESC; ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Power Automate Muhimbi PDF Conversion Action DESCRIPTION: Adds and configures the Muhimbi PDF action to convert the file obtained from the OneDrive trigger into PDF format. It requires authentication with Muhimbi using a SharePoint tenant ID and maps dynamic content from the trigger output (File name, File content) to the action's inputs. The output format is explicitly set to PDF. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/includes/learning-create-pdf.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Power Automate CODE: ``` Action: Muhimbi PDF – Convert document Source file name: [Dynamic Content: File name] Source file content: [Dynamic Content: File content] Output format: PDF ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Taking Screenshots of Web Pages in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to use the 'Take screenshot of web page' action in Power Automate. It allows users to capture screenshots of entire web pages or specific elements and save them to a file or clipboard. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/webautomation.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## Take screenshot of web page Take a screenshot of the web page (or an element of the web page) currently displayed in the browser and save the image into a file or to the clipboard. ### Input parameters |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |Web browser instance|No|[Web browser instance](../variable-data-types.md#instances)||Enter or choose the variable that contains the web browser instance to work with| |Capture|N/A|Entire web page, Specific element|Entire web page|Specify whether to capture the entire web page or only a specific element of it| |UI element|No|[UI element](../ui-elements.md)||Select the UI element on web page to capture| |Save mode|N/A|Clipboard, File|Clipboard|Specify whether to save the image into a file or store it into the clipboard| |Image file|No|[File](../variable-data-types.md#files-and-folders)||Set the full path for the file to save the image capture| |File format|N/A|BMP, EMF, EXIF, GIF, JPG, PNG, TIFF, WMF|BMP|Select the format of the image file| ### Variables produced This action doesn't produce any variables. ### Exceptions |Exception|Description| |-----|-----| |Element with specified CSS selector not found|Indicates that a web page element with the specified CSS selector wasn't found| |Failed to save file|Indicates a problem saving the specified file| |Failed to save in the clipboard|Indicates a problem while saving to the clipboard| |Failed to take screenshot|Indicates a problem taking a screenshot| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Retrieving CyberArk Credentials within a Power Automate Desktop Flow DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates using the 'Get credential' action from the 'Power Automate secret variables' module within the Power Automate Desktop designer. This action retrieves a pre-configured CyberArk credential (or Azure Key Vault credential) for use within the flow, storing it in a sensitive variable. The retrieved username and password can then be used in subsequent actions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/create-cyberark-credential.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: plaintext CODE: ``` Get credential ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Accessing Attribute Values with Spaces using GETVALUE() in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: Retrieves the value of the 'invoice total' attribute using the `GetValue` function. This function is necessary when attribute names contain spaces or special characters and cannot be referenced directly. The function takes the attribute name as a string parameter. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/other-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: dsl CODE: ``` GetValue("invoice total") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using AVGIF for Conditional Average Calculation in Power Automate Expressions (Pseudo-Expression Language) DESCRIPTION: Shows AVGIF, which calculates the average of values satisfying a specified condition within a context. Parameters: [context] (grouping), [condition] (boolean filter), [value] (numeric, date, or time expression), [default] (return value if no element matches). Inputs are context, filter, metric, and default. Outputs match the input type; supports robust handling of missing data. Example use filters events by user and averages costs. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/aggregations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: pseudo-expression CODE: ``` AVGIF(ViewEvents, userName == "Laura", eventCost) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Sending a Key Multiple Times Using Power Automate Notation - Markdown DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to use the Power Automate Desktop 'Send keys' feature to send a specific key multiple times. The curly bracket syntax includes the key name and the number of repetitions, separated by a colon. Enter this syntax in the 'Text to send' field. Inputs: desired key name and integer count. Output: the specified key sent repeatedly to the focused window. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/automate-applications-keyboard-shortcuts.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` **{Key:numberOfTimes}** ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Exceptions for 'Wait for window' Action in Markdown DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines a table of exceptions that can occur during the 'Wait for window' action, including exception names and descriptions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/uiautomation.md#2025-04-23_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Exception|Description| |-----|-----| |Can't focus window|Indicates a problem focusing the specified window| |Wait for window failed|Indicates that the wait operation failed| |Can't perform window-related action in noninteractive mode|Indicates a problem performing window-related action in non-interactive mode| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Connection Configuration JSON DESCRIPTION: JSON body for configuring a desktop flow connection without credentials, including run owner certificate settings and machine access parameters SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/set-runowner-desktopflowconnection.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: JSON CODE: ``` { "properties": { "environment": { "id": "/providers/Microsoft.PowerApps/environments/[ENVIRONMENT_ID]", "name":"[ENVIRONMENT_ID]" }, "displayName": "[DISPLAY_NAME]", "connectionParametersSet": { "name":"azureRelayRunOwner", "values": { "username":{"value":"[MACHINE_ACCOUNT]"}, "password":{"value":"[MACHINE_PASSWORD]"}, "targetId":{"value":"[GROUP_ID]"}, "tokenRunOwnerCert:clientId":{"value":"[APP_ID]"}, "tokenRunOwnerCert:clientCertificateSecret": { "value": { "pfx":"[PFX]", "password":"[PASSWORD]" } } } } } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Adding a Trigger Condition Expression in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to add a trigger condition expression in Power Automate. The expression must start with the '@' symbol and can be used to filter when a flow should run based on specific conditions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/triggers-introduction.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` @equals(triggerBody()?['Status'], 'Approved') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Converting Time Zones with formatDateTime() in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Example of using formatDateTime() in conjunction with convertTimeZone() to display the current time in Eastern Standard Time. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/date-time-values.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: PowerAutomate CODE: ``` formatDateTime(convertTimeZone(utcNow(), 'UTC', 'Eastern Standard Time'), 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss') ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Exporting All Custom Connector Permissions using PowerShell DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell script retrieves all custom connector role assignments within the Power Platform tenant. It requires authentication using 'Add-PowerAppsAccount', uses the 'Get-ConnectorRoleAssignment' cmdlet to fetch all permission assignments for custom connectors, converts the output to JSON format, and saves it to a file named 'CustomConnectorPermissions.txt'. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/privacy-dsr-export.md#2025-04-23_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` ```PowerShell Add-PowerAppsAccount Get-ConnectorRoleAssignment | ConvertTo-Json | Out-File -FilePath "CustomConnectorPermissions.txt" ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Embedding an Image using Base64 and Alt Attribute in HTML DESCRIPTION: This HTML snippet demonstrates embedding an image using Base64 encoded data directly in the src attribute. This method is useful when a direct URL is not available or desired. It also includes the 'alt' attribute, providing alternative text for accessibility or if the image fails to load. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/add-images-email-messages.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: html CODE: ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example CyberArk CCP Server Address Configuration DESCRIPTION: Provides an example format for the CyberArk Central Credential Provider (CCP) server URL required when creating a CyberArk credential store in Power Automate. Note that versions prior to the August release did not support URLs ending with a '/'. This URL is used to connect Power Automate to the CyberArk CCP AIMWebService. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/create-cyberark-credential.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: url CODE: ``` https://svc.skytap.com:8992 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Proxy with Address and Default Credentials in Power Automate (XML) DESCRIPTION: This XML snippet demonstrates how to configure Power Automate for desktop components to connect through a specified proxy server. It sets the `useDefaultCredentials` attribute to `True` within the `` element, indicating that the default Windows credentials should be used for authentication. The `proxyaddress` attribute within the nested `` element specifies the address and port of the proxy server (e.g., "http://proxy.example.com:8080"), and `bypassonlocal="True"` typically means local addresses bypass the proxy. This configuration should be applied to the relevant `.config` files (e.g., `PAD.Proxy.config`, `UIFlowService.Proxy.config`). SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/proxy-settings.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: xml CODE: ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Analyzing Performance Metrics of Desktop Flow Runs in SQL DESCRIPTION: This query retrieves performance metrics for desktop flow runs, including minimum, mean, maximum, and standard deviation of runtimes. It groups results by machine IDs and includes details such as machine names, management types, and session capacity. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/automation-analytics-with-fabric-queries.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: sql CODE: ``` SELECT f.machineid, fm.name AS machine_name, CASE WHEN mg.managementtype = 0 THEN 'Regular Machine (Group)' ELSE 'Hosted Machine (Group)' END AS managementtype, mg.maxmanagedmachinecount AS maxmanagedmachinecount, fm.lastheartbeatdate AS last_heartbeat_date, fm.sessioncapacity AS 'Max Parallel Sessions', CEILING(MIN(f.runduration) / 1000.0) AS min_runtime, CEILING(AVG(f.runduration) / 1000.0) AS mean_runtime, CEILING(MAX(f.runduration) / 1000.0) AS max_runtime, CEILING(STDEV(f.runduration) / 1000.0) AS stdev_runtime FROM flowsession f JOIN flowmachinegroup mg ON f.machinegroupid = mg.flowmachinegroupid JOIN flowmachine fm ON f.machinegroupid = fm.flowmachinegroupid WHERE f.regardingobjectid = '[specific_flow_id]' -- Replace with the actual flow ID GROUP BY f.machineid, fm.name, mg.managementtype, mg.maxmanagedmachinecount, fm.lastheartbeatdate, fm.sessioncapacity ORDER BY mean_runtime DESC; ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using Interpolated Strings in Power Automate Desktop DESCRIPTION: Example of using string interpolation in Power Automate Desktop inputs. This feature allows embedding expressions or variables directly within text strings. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/power-fx.md#2025-04-23_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: Power Fx CODE: ``` The total number is ${Sum(10, 20)} ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining CDF() Operation in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: Calculates the estimated cumulative distribution function (CDF) for a given value. Supports case, event, and edge contexts. Takes context, value, x, and optional compression parameters. Returns various data types. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/statistical-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_23 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## CDF([context],[value],[x],[compression]) Calculates the estimated cumulative distribution function (cdf) for the given value from values grouped according to the defined context. **Supported context:** case, event, edge **Parameters:** - ***[context]*** - defines the context in which the operation is calculated Data type: STRING (only fixed string is allowed) - ***[value]*** - value for evaluation for cumulative distribution. Data type: INT, FLOAT, DATE, TIME - ***[x]*** - threshold value Data type: INT, FLOAT, DATE, TIME (need to be the same data type as [value] parameter) - ***[compression]*** - controls the estimation accuracy and memory utilization. High compression values increase the accuracy of estimation but make the operation slower. The value must be between 20 and 1000, the default value is 200. Data type: FLOAT **Output Data Type**: INT, FLOAT, DATE, TIME ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Selecting All Data from Excel Worksheet - SQL DESCRIPTION: Executes a SQL SELECT statement to retrieve all data from a specified Excel spreadsheet within Power Automate Desktop flows. Dependencies include having an open SQL connection to the targeted Excel file, as well as specifying the correct worksheet name in place of the SHEET placeholder. The statement returns all rows and columns as result objects, which can be further processed in the flow. Columns are mapped from the first row of the worksheet. Limitations include worksheet name replacement and the requirement for header rows. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/sql-queries-excel.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: SQL CODE: ``` SELECT * FROM [SHEET$] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Restoring a Single Deleted Flow using PowerShell DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell command restores a specific soft-deleted flow within the given environment ('Default-55abc7e5-2812-4d73-9d2f-8d9017f8c877'). It requires the unique `FlowName` (GUID, e.g., '4d1f7648-ad60-4871-91cb-b77d7ef3c239') of the flow to be restored, typically obtained using `Get-AdminFlow`. The restored flow will be in a disabled state and must be manually enabled. Requires prior authentication, the environment name, and the flow's GUID. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/how-tos-restore-deleted-flow.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` Restore-AdminFlow -EnvironmentName Default-55abc7e5-2812-4d73-9d2f-8d9017f8c877 -FlowName 4d1f7648-ad60-4871-91cb-b77d7ef3c239 //To view examples: Get-Help Restore-AdminFlow -Examples ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Case Action Parameters in Markdown DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines the input parameters for the Case action in a conditional statement. It specifies the operator and value to compare, using a markdown table format. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/conditionals.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |Operator|N/A|Equal to (=), Not equal to (<>), Greater than (>), Greater than or equal to (>=), Less than (<), Less than or equal to (<=), Contains, Does not contain, Is empty, Is not empty, Starts with, Does not start with, Ends with, Does not end with, Is blank, Is not blank|Equal to (=)|The comparison operator of this case| |Value to compare|No|*||Enter a value to compare with the switch-block value| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Enabling Flow Run Resubmission via Tenant Settings using PowerShell DESCRIPTION: Modifies the tenant settings to enable flow run resubmissions for cloud flows initiated by instant triggers. It sets the `disableFlowRunResubmission` flag within the `powerPlatform.powerAutomate` object to `$False` using the retrieved `$tenantSettings` object and applies the changes using `Set-TenantSettings`. Requires prior retrieval of settings and appropriate administrative permissions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/how-tos-bulk-resubmit.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: powershell CODE: ``` $tenantSettings.powerPlatform.powerAutomate.disableFlowRunResubmission= $False Set-TenantSettings -RequestBody $tenantSettings ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Machine Registration to Different Tenants in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This registry entry allows machine registrations to tenants different from the machine joined Microsoft Entra tenant. The value should contain a comma-separated list of tenant IDs that are allowed during machine registration. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/governance.md#2025-04-23_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: registry CODE: ``` HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\WOW6432Node\Microsoft\Power Automate Desktop\Registration\AllowedRegistrationTenants ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Transforming Name Object Array in JSON DESCRIPTION: Example of a transformed JSON array with renamed properties and a new FullName field. This structure demonstrates the output of the select operation in Power Automate. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/data-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: JSON CODE: ``` [ { "FirstName": "Eugenia", "FamilyName": "Lopez", "FullName": "Eugenia Lopez" }, { "FirstName": "Elizabeth", "FamilyName": "Moore", "FullName": "Elizabeth Moore" } ] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Converting Integer to String in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: The TOSTRING function converts an integer to a string. It can optionally apply a formatting string. It takes an integer value and an optional formatting string as parameters. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/string-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## TOSTRING([int],[format]*) Converts an integer to a string according to the formatting string (if an optional parameter is specified). **Parameters:** - **[int]** - input int value Data type: STRING - **[format*]** - formatting string [Learn more about formatting strings](/dotnet/standard/base-types/formatting-types) Data type: STRING (only fixed string is allowed) **Output Data Type**: STRING ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Uninstalling Java Automation Configuration - CMD DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to uninstall the Java configuration for Power Automate for desktop by using the command line interface. It requires administrator rights and assumes that 'PAD.Java.Installer.exe' is available in the current directory or system PATH. The '-u' flag reverts all Java automation-related system changes, restoring previous state. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/java.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: CMD CODE: ``` PAD.Java.Installer.exe -u ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Constructing Email Subject with Dynamic Content in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to configure the Subject field of the 'Send an email (V2)' action in the Power Automate classic designer. It combines static text ('New tweet from: ') with a dynamic content token ('Tweeted by') derived from the Twitter trigger to create a personalized subject line. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/get-started-logic-flow.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: plaintext CODE: ``` New tweet from: [Tweeted by token] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Documenting Action Input Parameters Table - Markdown DESCRIPTION: Documents required and optional input parameters for an action in a Markdown table. Each row describes an argument, its necessity, supported types, default value, and purpose. This table helps users configure actions correctly; must be used with corresponding action documentation. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/text.md#2025-04-23_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: Markdown CODE: ``` |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description|\n|-----|-----|-----|-----|-----|\n|Text to recognize from|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The text to recognize entities from|\n|Entity type|N/A|Date time, Dimension, Temperature, Currency, Number range, Number, Ordinal, Percentage, Phone number, Email, IP address, Mention, Hashtag, URL, GUID, Quoted text|Date time|The type of entity to recognize (, Date time, Email, URL etc.)|\n|Language|N/A|English, Chinese (Simplified), Spanish, Spanish (Mexico), Portuguese, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Dutch, Korean, Swedish, Turkish, Hindi|English|Specify the language of the text| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Input Parameters for Convert Document Action in Markdown DESCRIPTION: This code snippet defines the input parameters for the 'Convert Document' IBM cognitive action in a markdown table format. It includes details like parameter names, whether they are optional, accepted values, default values, and descriptions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/ibmcognitive.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |Username|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The username to be used for this call| |Password|No|Direct encrypted input or [Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The password to use for this call| |Version date|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The release date of the API to use| |File path|No|[File](../variable-data-types.md#files-and-folders)||The path to the file to analyze| |Mime type|N/A|text/html, text/xhtml+xml, application/pdf, application/msword, application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.wordprocessingml.document|text/html|The MIME type of the file| |Conversion target|N/A|Answer units, Normalized HTML, Normalized text|Answer units|The output format of the conversion| |Answer units|Yes|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The heading levels as a comma-separated string| |Timeout|Yes|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)|30|The time (in seconds) that the agent should wait for a connection to be established with the server, before it fails| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Exporting User Details using PowerShell DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell script retrieves details for a specific Power Automate user. It requires authentication using 'Add-PowerAppsAccount' and uses the 'Get-AdminFlowUserDetails' cmdlet, passing the target user's ID as a parameter, to fetch the user details. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/privacy-dsr-export.md#2025-04-23_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` ```PowerShell Add-PowerAppsAccount Get-AdminFlowUserDetails -UserId {userID} ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Modified FetchXML Query for Instant Flow Runs DESCRIPTION: A modified version of the FetchXML query that counts flow runs, with trigger type changed to 'Instant' and a different date range extending further back. This demonstrates how to edit and rerun queries in Copilot. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/automation-center-copilot.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: xml CODE: ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Retrieving DLP Policy and Desktop Flow Modules using PowerShell DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell script demonstrates the initial steps for managing desktop flow modules within a DLP policy. It retrieves a specific DLP policy named 'My DLP Policy' and fetches all available Power Automate for desktop flow modules using Power Platform PowerShell cmdlets (`Get-DlpPolicy`, `Get-DesktopFlowModules`). These steps provide the necessary objects for subsequent actions, such as adding specific modules to different classification groups within the retrieved policy. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/prevent-data-loss.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` # Step #1: Retrieve a DLP policy named 'My DLP Policy' $dlpPolicies = Get-DlpPolicy  $dlpPolicy = $dlpPolicies.value | where {$_.displayName -eq 'My DLP Policy'}  # Step #2: Get all Power Automate for desktop flow modules $desktopFlowModules = Get-DesktopFlowModules  ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Calculate Run Duration in Seconds using Excel Formula DESCRIPTION: This Excel formula calculates the duration between a run's end time and start time in seconds. It requires the run start time and end time values, typically obtained by exporting the Power Automate flow run history to a CSV or Excel file. The formula subtracts the start time cell from the end time cell and multiplies the result by 24, 60, and 60 to convert the time difference (represented in days by Excel) into total seconds. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/guidance/planning/analyze-and-assess.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Excel Formula CODE: ``` (**Run end time** cell − **Run start time** cell) × 24 × 60 × 60 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using 'greater' Expression in Power Automate Condition DESCRIPTION: This expression checks if the Due amount is greater than the Paid amount. It's used to identify employees who haven't paid the full amount for baseball tickets. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/use-expressions-in-conditions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: Power Automate CODE: ``` @greater(item()?['Due'], item()?['Paid']) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Distinguished Name with Comma Format DESCRIPTION: Shows how to properly format distinguished names that contain commas by using double quotes. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/activedirectory.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: LDAP CODE: ``` CN="Varga, Norbert",DC=contoso,DC=com ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Event Value Retrieval with MOVE Function DESCRIPTION: Returns the value of an event based on a specified offset relative to the current event. Used for calculating metrics across sequential events in a case. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/other-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` SUM(MOVE(2, eventCost, 0) + MOVE(1, eventCost, 0)) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: String Expression for Dataverse Notes Attachment DESCRIPTION: Expression to convert non-Dataverse attachments to string format when adding rows to the Notes table. Used specifically when handling email attachments within an Apply to each loop. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/dataverse/known-issues.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: expression CODE: ``` string(triggerOutputs()?['body/attachments']) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Calculating Path Durations using SOURCE() in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: Calculates the sum of the duration of the initial event in a path (retrieved using `SOURCE(Duration())`) and the duration of the path itself (`Duration()`). The `SOURCE()` operation changes the context to the starting event of the path. This metric is applicable on the process map within the edge (path) context. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/other-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: dsl CODE: ``` SUM(SOURCE(Duration())+Duration()) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Desktop Flow Connection API Request DESCRIPTION: HTTP PUT request to create a Power Automate desktop flow connection with run owner configuration SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/set-runowner-desktopflowconnection.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: HTTP CODE: ``` PUT https://[ENVIRONMENT_ID_URL].environment.api.powerplatform.com/connectivity/connectors/shared_uiflow/connections/[CONNECTION_ID]?api-version=1 Content-Type: application/json Host: [ENVIRONMENT_ID_URL].environment.api.powerplatform.com Accept: application/json Authorization: Bearer eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJu... ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Getting the Duration of the Last Event in a Case using LASTEVENT() DESCRIPTION: Calculates the duration of the very last event within each case. The `LASTEVENT()` operation changes the context of the `Duration()` calculation to the last event of the current case. This metric is applicable on the case overview statistics screen within the case context. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/other-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: dsl CODE: ``` LASTEVENT(Duration()) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Distinguished Name Format for Users DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the format for specifying a user's distinguished name in Active Directory, using example username 'nvarga'. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/activedirectory.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: LDAP CODE: ``` CN=nvarga,CN=Users,DC=contoso,DC=demo ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Retrieving Cloud Flows with Owner Information in Microsoft Fabric DESCRIPTION: SQL query that returns all solution-based cloud flows with their owner information from Dataverse. Joins the workflow table with systemuser to provide comprehensive flow metadata including creation date, modification date, and owner details. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/automation-analytics-with-fabric-queries.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: sql CODE: ``` SELECT w.name AS 'Cloud flow', w.workflowid AS 'Cloud flow Id', w.createdon AS 'Created on', w.modifiedon AS 'Last modified on', w.clientdata AS 'Script', w.ownerid AS 'Owner Id', s.fullname AS 'Owner name', s.internalemailaddress AS 'Owner email' FROM workflow w JOIN systemuser s ON w.ownerid = s.systemuserid WHERE w.category = 5; -- Only consider solution-cloud flows (category 5) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Exporting User Custom Connector Permissions using PowerShell DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell script retrieves all custom connector role assignments for a specific user identified by their principal object ID. It requires authentication using 'Add-PowerAppsAccount', specifies the target user ID, fetches the permissions using 'Get-AdminConnectorRoleAssignment', converts the output to JSON format, and saves it to a file named 'CustomConnectorPermissions.txt'. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/privacy-dsr-export.md#2025-04-23_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` ```PowerShell Add-PowerAppsAccount #Retrieves all connection permissions for the specified userID Add-PowerAppsAccount $userId = "{userID}" Get-AdminConnectorRoleAssignment -PrincipalObjectId $userId | ConvertTo-Json | Out-File -FilePath "CustomConnectorPermissions.txt" ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Retrieving All Business Process Flow Tables using Web API DESCRIPTION: This HTTP GET request retrieves all business process flow tables in the Dataverse instance by filtering on the IsBPFEntity metadata property. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/developer/business-process-flows-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: HTTP CODE: ``` GET [Organization URI]/api/data/v9.0/EntityDefinitions?$select=SchemaName,LogicalName,DisplayName&$filter=IsBPFEntity eq true HTTP/1.1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Converting Timespan to Total Minutes in Power Automate Expressions DESCRIPTION: Calculates the total duration of a given timespan value, expressed in whole and fractional minutes. The input parameter '[time]' must be of TIME data type, and the function returns a FLOAT. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/date-and-time-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: powerautomate-expression CODE: ``` TOTALMINUTES([time]) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Sending Actionable Email with Voting Options using Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Details the use of the 'Send email with options' action to create actionable emails containing voting buttons within Power Automate. Requires defining voting choices in the 'User Options' field. It is crucial to implement subsequent steps in the flow to capture and store the recipient's voting response (e.g., save to Excel, post to Teams, or email). SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/email-top-scenarios.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Power Automate CODE: ``` Send email with options ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Calculating Average Duration for All Events in View DESCRIPTION: Calculates the average duration across all events within the current view filters using the 'ViewEvents' context. When visualized on the process map, this results in a single, consistent average duration value applicable to all activities and edges within the view. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/calculation-context.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: PowerAutomateExpression CODE: ``` AVG(ViewEvents, DURATION()) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example of formatted start time for a scheduled flow DESCRIPTION: Shows a practical example of a properly formatted start time string for a scheduled flow, including the correct ISO 8601 format with timezone information. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/run-scheduled-tasks.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` 2025-03-24T22:00:00Z ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Disabling UNC Paths in Action Inputs for Power Automate Desktop DESCRIPTION: This registry entry enhances security by disabling UNC paths in module actions for Power Automate Desktop. When set to 1, any action containing a UNC path will result in a runtime error. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/governance.md#2025-04-23_snippet_17 LANGUAGE: registry CODE: ``` HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Power Automate Desktop\DisableUNCPaths ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Finding the Previous Event Matching a Condition using PREVIOUSIF() DESCRIPTION: Searches for the first preceding event within the same case that satisfies the specified condition (`eventCost > 0`). If such an event is found, it returns the value of the specified attribute ('userName') for that event. If no preceding event meets the condition, it returns the specified default value ("n/a"). This metric is applicable in metrics filters. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/other-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: dsl CODE: ``` PREVIOUSIF(eventCost > 0, userName, "n/a") ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using MAX() with an Attribute Name in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: Calculates the maximum value of the 'eventCost' attribute for events within each activity on the process map. Demonstrates direct attribute name usage, which is case-insensitive. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/other-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: dsl CODE: ``` MAX(eventCost) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Parsing Power Automate Connection Creation Success Response DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the JSON format of a successful response received after creating a Power Automate connection via the API. Key fields include the 'name' (Connection ID) and the 'status' within 'properties.statuses', which should be checked to ensure it indicates 'Connected'. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/set-runowner-desktopflowconnection.md#2025-04-23_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "name": "[CONNECTION_ID]", "id": "/providers/Microsoft.PowerApps/apis/shared_uiflow/connections/[CONNECTION_ID]", "type": "Microsoft.PowerApps/apis/connections", "properties": { "statuses": [ { "status": "[CONNECTION_STATUS]" } ], } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Disabling Optional Updates via Windows Registry - Registry DESCRIPTION: Prevents users from manually updating Power Automate for desktop and receiving update notifications by setting the 'DisableOptionalUpdates' DWORD registry value to 1 under the 'SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Power Automate Desktop' key in HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE. Requires administrative access and registry editing privileges. Setting this value disables manual updates and notifications, and improper editing of the registry can cause system issues. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/governance.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: registry CODE: ``` Windows Registry Editor Version 5.00\n\n[HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Power Automate Desktop]\n"DisableOptionalUpdates"=dword:00000001\n ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Deleting Specific User's Connector Role Assignments in PowerShell DESCRIPTION: PowerShell script to delete all connector role assignments for a specific user ID. Requires admin privileges and PowerApps account authentication. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/privacy-dsr-delete.md#2025-04-23_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` Add-PowerAppsAccount $deleteDsrUserId = "{userID}" #Retrieves all custom connector role assignments for the specified userID and deletes them Get-AdminConnectorRoleAssignment -PrincipalObjectId $deleteDsrUserId | Remove-AdminConnectorRoleAssignment ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Retrieving the Next Event's Cost using NEXT() DESCRIPTION: Returns the 'eventCost' attribute value of the event immediately following the current event within the same case. If the current event is the last one in the case (i.e., there is no next event), it returns the specified default value (0). This metric is applicable in filter metrics, implicitly operating within the case context. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/other-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: dsl CODE: ``` NEXT(eventCost, 0) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Calculating Average Event Duration per Activity (Performance View) DESCRIPTION: Calculates the average duration using the 'EventsPerAttribute' context, typically grouping by activity name. This returns the average duration of all events in the view sharing the same activity value, representing the standard 'Mean Duration' metric in the Performance view. It's unavailable for edges. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/calculation-context.md#2025-04-23_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: PowerAutomateExpression CODE: ``` AVG(EventsPerAttribute, DURATION()) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring IMAP Server Settings in Power Automate Desktop DESCRIPTION: Example of IMAP server configuration for the Retrieve emails action in Power Automate Desktop. It shows how to set up server address, port, and security settings. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/email.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` :::image type="content" source="media/email/email-example.png" alt-text="Screenshot of the IMAP server settings of the Retrieve emails action."::: ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using RANGE for Calculating Range in Power Automate Expressions (Pseudo-Expression Language) DESCRIPTION: RANGE returns the difference between the maximum and minimum values for a target attribute or expression in a group. Parameters: [context], [value] (numeric, date, or time). Output is int, float, or time difference. Useful for variability or span calculations in custom KPIs. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/aggregations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: pseudo-expression CODE: ``` RANGE([context],[value]) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using AVG for Calculating Average in Power Automate Expressions (Pseudo-Expression Language) DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the AVG aggregation, which computes the average of values grouped by a given context. Parameters: [context] (aggregation grouping) and [value] (numeric or date/time attribute or expression). Typical input is a metric context and field or nested expression; output is a float, date, or time, depending on the input. No explicit language dependency; designed for in-app metric definition. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/aggregations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: pseudo-expression CODE: ``` AVG([context],[value]) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Customizing Approval Request Options in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Example of how to set up custom response options for an approval request in Power Automate. This snippet shows the configuration for a discount approval scenario with multiple response options. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/approvals-howto.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ![Start and wait for an approval.](media/approvals-howto/start-wait.png) Select as approval type **Custom Responses – Wait for all responses** or **Custom Responses – Wait for one response**, depending on if you need multiple approvers or just one. Add as many **response options** as needed. In this case we are giving four mentioned earlier. Give a **Title** to the approval request, and then list the approvers in **Assigned to**. ![Assigned to.](media/approvals-howto/assigned.png) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Text Value Variable in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create a text value variable using the Set variable action in Power Automate desktop flows. The input parameter is populated with the desired text without any special notation. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/variable-data-types.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: PowerAutomate CODE: ``` Set variable TextVariable to "Hello World" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using MAXVAL for Selecting Value by Maximum Attribute in Power Automate Expressions (Pseudo-Expression Language) DESCRIPTION: MAXVAL selects an item with the highest [value1] in the context and returns its [value2]. Accepts [context], [value1] (numeric or temporal), [value2] (returned attribute/expression). Output matches [value2]'s type. Example: get username associated with the maximum duration per group. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/aggregations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: pseudo-expression CODE: ``` MAXVAL(EventsPerAttribute, Duration(), userName) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Initializing Array Variable with Integers in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Example of how to initialize an array variable containing integers in Power Automate. This snippet shows the JSON structure for setting the name, type, and initial value of an array variable with integer elements. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/create-variable-store-values.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "name": "myArrayVariable", "type": "Array", "value": [1, 2, 3] } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Setting Organization FlowRunTimeToLiveInSeconds using Dataverse Web API DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to use the Dataverse Web API to update the FlowRunTimeToLiveInSeconds value in the Organization table. This setting controls how long FlowRun records are stored before automatic deletion. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/dataverse/cloud-flow-run-metadata.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: dataverse CODE: ``` https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/power-automate-docs-pr/assets/13593424/25bd0eda-0dde-4378-9793-7090fbca5916 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Illustrating SQL Query Error with Single Quotes in Power Automate (SQL) DESCRIPTION: This SQL snippet demonstrates an example query intended for Power Automate that will likely cause an error. The issue arises from using single quotes ('') around the variable placeholder '%value%', which conflicts with how Power Automate identifies variables within SQL statements. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/troubleshoot-sql-queries.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: sql CODE: ``` SELECT * FROM SALES WHERE VALUE = '%value%'; ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Flow Approvals Using Power Platform CLI in PowerShell DESCRIPTION: PowerShell script that uses the Power Platform Command Line Interface (CLI) to install the Microsoft Flow Approvals solution into a specific environment. The script lists environments, filters for a specific environment name, and then installs the msdyn_FlowApprovals application. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/guidance/business-approvals-templates/setup.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` $envs = (pac admin list --json | ConvertFrom-Json) | Where-Object { $_.DisplayName -eq "Your Environment Name" } pac application install --environment $envs[0].EnvironmentId --application-name "msdyn_FlowApprovals" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Exporting Unmanaged Solution using Dataverse SDK for .NET DESCRIPTION: This C# method exports an unmanaged solution using the ExportSolutionRequest. It takes an IOrganizationService and the solution's unique name as parameters, and returns a byte array containing the ZIP file of the solution. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/manage-flows-with-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` public static byte[] ExportSolution( IOrganizationService service, string solutionUniqueName) { ExportSolutionRequest request = new() { SolutionName = solutionUniqueName, Managed = false }; var response = (ExportSolutionResponse)service.Execute(request); return response.ExportSolutionFile; } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Windows Registry for Power Automate Tenant Allowlisting - Registry DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to set or create the 'AllowedRegistrationTenants' string value in the Windows Registry key at 'Computer\\HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SOFTWARE\\WOW6432Node\\Microsoft\\Power Automate Desktop\\Registration' to allowlist one or more tenant IDs. No external dependencies are required, but administrative privileges are necessary to modify HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE. The value must be a comma-separated list of valid tenant ID GUIDs. After configuration, only allowlisted tenants can register or connect with sign-in from the affected machine. Improper registry modification may impact application access. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/allowlist-tenant-for-connect-with-sign-in-and-registration.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: registry CODE: ``` Key: Computer\\HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SOFTWARE\\WOW6432Node\\Microsoft\\Power Automate Desktop\\Registration Value: AllowedRegistrationTenants (String) Example: \"aaaabbbb-0000-cccc-1111-dddd2222eeee\" or \"aaaabbbb-0000-cccc-1111-dddd2222eeee,bbbbcccc-1111-dddd-2222-eeee3333ffff\" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining DURATION() Operation in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: Returns the duration of a process, event, case, or path. Supported in process, event, case, and edge contexts. Output is of TIME data type. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/statistical-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## DURATION() Returns the duration of a process/event/case/path. **Supported context:** process, event, case, edge **Output Data Type**: TIME ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using 'empty' Expression in Power Automate Condition DESCRIPTION: This expression checks if both the Status and Assigned columns are empty. It's used to identify and remove empty rows from an Excel spreadsheet. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/use-expressions-in-conditions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: Power Automate CODE: ``` @and(empty(item()?['Status']), empty(item()?['Assigned'])) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Listening to Events from Power Automate Widget using JavaScript DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript snippet illustrates the general syntax for listening to events emitted by the Power Automate widget. The host application uses the `widget.listen()` method, providing the specific event name (e.g., 'WIDGET_READY', 'GET_ACCESS_TOKEN') as the first argument and a callback function to handle the event as the second argument. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/developer/embed-flow-dev.md#2025-04-23_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` widget.listen("", function() { console.log("The flow widget raised event"); }); ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining JSON Schema for Business Process Flow Data DESCRIPTION: JSON schema definition for parsing business process flow instance data, including properties for workflow logs, instance IDs, entity names, and stage information. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/create-instant-flows.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "type": "object", "properties": { "entity": { "type": "object", "properties": { "FlowsWorkflowLogId": { "type": "string" }, "BPFInstanceId": { "type": "string" }, "BPFInstanceEntityName": { "type": "string" }, "BPFDefinitionId": { "type": "string" }, "BPFDefinitionEntityName": { "type": "string" }, "StepId": { "type": "string" }, "BPFDefinitionName": { "type": "string" }, "BPFInstanceName": { "type": "string" }, "BPFFlowStageLocalizedName": { "type": "string" }, "BPFFlowStageEntityName": { "type": "string" }, "BPFFlowStageEntityCollectionName": { "type": "string" }, "BPFFlowStageTableRowID": { "type": "string" }, "BPFActiveStageId": { "type": "string" }, "BPFActiveStageEntityName": { "type": "string" }, "BPFActiveStageLocalizedName": { "type": "string" } } } } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Disabling Auto-Start Configuration via Windows Registry - Registry DESCRIPTION: Prevents users from manually setting Power Automate for desktop to start automatically (applicable to MSI-installer versions) by setting 'DisableAutoStartConfiguration' (DWORD) to 1 under 'SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Power Automate Desktop' in HKEY_CURRENT_USER. Registry edits require elevated privileges. When enabled, user access to auto-start options in the UI is blocked. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/governance.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: registry CODE: ``` Windows Registry Editor Version 5.00\n\n[HKEY_CURRENT_USER\\SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Power Automate Desktop]\n"DisableAutoStartConfiguration"=dword:00000001\n ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Declaring and Returning Variables in Python DESCRIPTION: Shows how to declare variables and return values using the print function in Python scripts. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/scripting.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Python CODE: ``` variableName = "variableValue" print variableName ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: LDAP Path Format for User Locations DESCRIPTION: Shows how to specify the container and domain controller location for users in Active Directory. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/activedirectory.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: LDAP CODE: ``` CN=Users,DC=contoso,DC=demo ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using COUNTIF for Conditional Counting in Power Automate Expressions (Pseudo-Expression Language) DESCRIPTION: Explains COUNTIF, counting the number of elements in a context that satisfy a boolean condition. Accepts [context] (group), [condition] (boolean), and [default] (return if no items match). Returns integer count. Supports safe handling for empty sets. Common in filtered metric scenarios. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/aggregations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: pseudo-expression CODE: ``` COUNTIF([context],[condition],[default]) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example Cabinet Creation Command DESCRIPTION: Example of invoking the cabinet creation script with specific file paths and names. This demonstrates how to use the script with actual values for creating a cabinet file named MyCustomActions.cab. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/create-custom-actions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_15 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` .\makeCabFile.ps1 "C:\Users\Username\source\repos\MyCustomModule\bin\Release\net472" "C:\Users\Username\MyCustomActions" MyCustomActions.cab ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Moving Mouse to Image Location - Power Automate Actions Reference - Markdown DESCRIPTION: Explains the \"Move mouse to image\" action in Power Automate Desktop for moving the mouse to the position of an image detected on the screen or in the foreground window. Supports detailed parameters for fine-tuned control, including image list, occurrence count, click behavior, fail timeouts, subregion search, offsets, and mouse positioning relative to image. Outputs the coordinates where the image was found (X, Y). Exception handling covers image not found, invalid search, and interaction errors. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/mouseandkeyboard.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: Markdown CODE: ``` ## Move mouse to image\n\nMoves the mouse over an image found on screen or on the foreground window.\n\n### Input parameters\n\n|Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description|\n|-----|-----|-----|-----|-----|\n|Image to move mouse to|No|[List](../variable-data-types.md#list) of [Images](../images.md)||The list of Images to move the mouse to|\n|Mouse movement style|N/A|Instant, With animation (low speed), With animation (normal speed), With animation (high speed)|Instant|Specify the style of movement in which the mouse will move from its previous position to the beginning of the recorded route (or to its final position)|\n|Occurrence|Yes|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)|1|The occurrence of the image found to move the mouse to|\n|Send a click after moving mouse|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|False|Specify whether to send a click after the mouse is positioned over the image|\n|Click type|N/A|Left click, Right click, Double click, Middle click, Left button down, Left button up, Right button down, Right button up|Left click|The mouse click to send to the image|\n|Wait for image to appear|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|True|Choose whether you want the action to wait if the image isn't found on the screen or foreground window|\n|Fail timeout|Yes|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)|0|The fail timeout in seconds|\n|Seconds before click|Yes|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)|0|The number of seconds to wait before sending the click|\n|Image matching algorithm|N/A|Basic, Advanced|Basic|Which image algorithm to use when searching for image|\n|Mouse position relative to image|N/A|top left corner, top center, top right corner, middle left part, center, middle right part, bottom left corner, bottom center, bottom right corner|center|The section of the image the mouse will be moved to|\n|Offset X|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)|0|The pixels to offset the mouse from the position to the right|\n|Offset Y|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)|0|The pixels to offset the mouse from the position down|\n|Tolerance|Yes|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)|10|Specify how much the specified image can differ from the originally chosen image|\n|Search for image on|N/A|Entire screen, Foreground window only|Entire screen|Specify whether to search for the specified Image in the foremost window only, or the entire visible screen. Neither choice will find the image if it isn't clearly visible on the screen|\n|Search mode|N/A|Search whole screen or foreground window, Search on specified subregion of screen or foreground window|Search whole screen or foreground window|Specify whether to scan the entire screen (or window) to find the supplied image or only a subregion of it|\n|X1|Yes|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)||The starting X of the subregion to search in|\n|Y1|Yes|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)||The starting Y of the subregion to search in|\n|X2|Yes|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)||The ending X of the subregion to search in|\n|Y2|Yes|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)||The ending Y of the subregion to search in|\n\n### Variables produced\n\n|Argument|Type|Description|\n|-----|-----|-----|\n|X|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)|The X coordinate of the point where the image is found on the screen. If the image is being searched for on the foreground window, the coordinate returned is relative to the top left corner of the window|\n|Y|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)|The Y coordinate of the point where the image is found on the screen. If the image is being searched for on the foreground window, the coordinate returned is relative to the top left corner of the window|\n\n### Exceptions\n\n|Exception|Description|\n|-----|-----|\n|Image not found on screen|Indicates that the specified image wasn't found on the screen|\n|Can't move mouse in non interactive mode|Indicates a problem moving the mouse in non-interactive mode|\n|Failed to move mouse|Indicates a problem moving the mouse|\n|Invalid subregion coordinates|Indicates that the coordinates of the given subregion were invalid|\n|Not enough Image occurrences found on screen|Indicates that not enough occurrences of the specified Image were found on the screen|\n ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Querying Excel Worksheets via SQL in Power Automate (SQL) DESCRIPTION: This SQL query example demonstrates how to select data from an Excel worksheet named 'Sheet1' when using Excel as a database source in Power Automate. It illustrates the required syntax: enclosing the sheet name in brackets and appending a dollar sign ('[Sheet1$]'), and using double quotes for Power Automate variable placeholders ('"%value%"'). SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/troubleshoot-sql-queries.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: sql CODE: ``` SELECT * FROM [Sheet1$] WHERE Value = "%value%"; ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Deleting User's Connector Role Assignments in PowerShell DESCRIPTION: PowerShell script to delete all connector role assignments for the executing user. Requires PowerApps account authentication. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/privacy-dsr-delete.md#2025-04-23_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` Add-PowerAppsAccount #Retrieves all connector role assignments for the calling user and deletes them Get-ConnectorRoleAssignment | Remove-ConnectorRoleAssignment ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Blank Data Table Input in Power Automate Desktop DESCRIPTION: This snippet outlines the steps to set a data table's default value to Blank in Power Automate Desktop. It involves setting the data type, enabling the 'Mark as optional' control, and clearing the default value using the JSON editor. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/manage-variables.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` - Set the **Data type** property to **Datatable**. - Enable the **Mark as optional** control. - Make sure the **Default value** property is set to **<Blank>**. To achieve this, select **Edit** next to the property and in the **Edit datatable** window, enable the **JSON editor** control. Delete all the contents, and then select **Save**. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Dynamically Modifying Selector with Loop Index DESCRIPTION: Shows the modified part of the UI selector within the 'Text editor'. The static index `tr:eq(0)` (or potentially `li:eq(0)` depending on the actual structure) is replaced with `tr:eq(%LoopIndex%)` to dynamically target the element corresponding to the current iteration of the loop, using the built-in `LoopIndex` variable. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/click-elements-list-links.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: CSS Selector CODE: ``` tr:eq(%LoopIndex%) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Retrieving Active Cloud Flows with Dataverse SDK for .NET DESCRIPTION: This method retrieves the first active cloud flow from Dataverse using the IOrganizationService.RetrieveMultiple method. It queries the workflow table with specific filtering criteria to find flows of category 5 (Modern Flow) that are currently active (statecode = 1). The method outputs various properties of the retrieved flow to the console. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/manage-flows-with-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` /// /// Outputs the first active flow /// /// Authenticated client implementing the IOrganizationService interface public static void OutputFirstActiveFlow(IOrganizationService service) { var query = new QueryExpression("workflow") { ColumnSet = new ColumnSet("category", "createdby", "createdon", "description", "ismanaged", "modifiedby", "modifiedon", "name", "ownerid", "statecode", "type", "workflowid", "workflowidunique"), Criteria = new FilterExpression(LogicalOperator.And) { Conditions = { { new ConditionExpression( "category", ConditionOperator.Equal, 5) }, // Cloud Flow { new ConditionExpression( "statecode", ConditionOperator.Equal, 1) } // Active } }, TopCount = 1 // Limit to one record }; EntityCollection workflows = service.RetrieveMultiple(query); Entity workflow = workflows.Entities.FirstOrDefault(); Console.WriteLine($"category: {workflow.FormattedValues[\"category\"]}") Console.WriteLine($"createdby: {workflow.FormattedValues[\"createdby\"]}") Console.WriteLine($"createdon: {workflow.FormattedValues[\"createdon\"]}") // Description may be null Console.WriteLine($"description: {workflow.GetAttributeValue(\"description\")}") Console.WriteLine($"ismanaged: {workflow.FormattedValues[\"ismanaged\"]}") Console.WriteLine($"modifiedby: {workflow.FormattedValues[\"modifiedby\"]}") Console.WriteLine($"modifiedon: {workflow.FormattedValues[\"modifiedon\"]}") Console.WriteLine($"name: {workflow[\"name\"]}") Console.WriteLine($"ownerid: {workflow.FormattedValues[\"ownerid\"]}") Console.WriteLine($"statecode: {workflow.FormattedValues[\"statecode\"]}") Console.WriteLine($"type: {workflow.FormattedValues[\"type\"]}") Console.WriteLine($"workflowid: {workflow[\"workflowid\"]}") Console.WriteLine($"workflowidunique: {workflow[\"workflowidunique\"]}") } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Silent Machine Registration Command DESCRIPTION: Command to register a machine silently using service principal authentication with optional parameters for environment ID and machine details SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/machines-silent-registration.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: CMD CODE: ``` .\PAD.MachineRegistration.Silent.exe -register -applicationid appid -clientsecret (or -certificatethumbprint thumbprint) -tenantid tenantid -environmentid envid ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining LOOPCOUNT() Operation in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: Counts loops within a case. Supports an optional attribute parameter. Supported in case context. Returns an INT. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/statistical-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## LOOPCOUNT([attributeName]) Returns count of loops within the case. **Supported context:** case **Parameters:** - ***[attributeName]*** - Attribute to calculate repetitions. If none is entered, the default attribute is mining attribute (activity attribute), optional Data type: STRING (only fixed string is allowed) **Output Data Type**: INT ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Markdown Tables for Exception Handling DESCRIPTION: Documentation tables defining possible exceptions and their descriptions for various text operations. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/text.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Exception|Description| |-----|-----| |Start index or length are out of range|Indicates that the start index or length are out of range| |Provided text value can't be converted into a valid number|Indicates that the provided text value can't be converted into a valid number| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Getting String Length in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: The LEN function returns the length of a given string. It takes a single string parameter and returns an integer representing the string's length. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/string-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## LEN([string]) Returns the length of the string. **Parameters:** - **[string]** - input string Data type: STRING **Output Data Type**: INT ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Editing Datetime Variables in Power Automate Desktop Debugger DESCRIPTION: This snippet outlines the process of modifying datetime variables during flow debugging in Power Automate Desktop. It mentions a warning message for invalid input values. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/manage-variables.md#2025-04-23_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` Open the variable that requires editing, place the cursor on the input field and manually edit the datetime value. There's a warning message that appears in the variable viewer if you enter a value that isn't acceptable. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Checking Running Case Status in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: This function is used within custom metrics in Power Automate Process Mining to identify cases categorized as 'Running'. A case is considered 'Running' if it does not satisfy the conditions for being either 'Finished' or 'Stuck'. Returns True if the case is 'Running', False otherwise. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/case-categorization.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Power Automate Process Mining Expression CODE: ``` ISRUNNING() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining FlowsSettings Configuration for Power Automate Widget DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines the structure of the `FlowsSettings` object, typically using TypeScript syntax, which is used to customize the Power Automate widget's behavior related to flows. It includes optional parameters like `createFromBlankTemplateId` (to specify a template GUID for blank flow creation), `flowsFilter` (to filter the displayed flows, e.g., by SharePoint site), and `tab` (to set the default active tab like 'myFlows' or 'sharedFlows'). SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/developer/embed-flow-dev.md#2025-04-23_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: typescript CODE: ``` flowsSettings?: { createFromBlankTemplateId?: string; flowsFilter?: string;sc tab?: string; }; ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Windows Task Scheduler for Power Automate Desktop Flows DESCRIPTION: These snippets show the configuration for triggering Power Automate desktop flows using Windows Task Scheduler, including settings for both MSI and Microsoft Store installations. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/run-desktop-flows-url-shortcuts.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: plaintext CODE: ``` # For MSI installations: Program/script: C:\Program Files (x86)\Power Automate Desktop\PAD.Console.Host.exe Add arguments: ms-powerautomate:/console/flow/run?workflowName=[workflowName] # For Microsoft Store installations: Program/script: C:\WINDOWS\system32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe Add arguments: -Command "Start-Process \"ms-powerautomate:/console/flow/run?workflowName=[workflowName]\"" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Calculating Average Duration for All Elements in View DESCRIPTION: Calculates the average duration across all activities or edges currently within the filtered view using the 'AllInView' context. When visualized, this results in one average value for all activities and potentially a different single average value for all edges within the current view. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/calculation-context.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: PowerAutomateExpression CODE: ``` AVG(AllInView, DURATION()) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Basic LDAP Path Format for Domain Controllers DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the standard LDAP path format for specifying domain controllers in Active Directory connections. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/activedirectory.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: LDAP CODE: ``` LDAP://DC=contoso,DC=demo ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Power Automate Connection (Azure Key Vault Cert Auth) DESCRIPTION: This JSON payload defines the request body for creating a Power Automate connection using Azure Key Vault certificate-based authentication credentials and a specified Run Owner. It requires environment details, display name, credential ID, username environment variable, target group ID, and certificate details for the Run Owner. Note that the 'password' field within 'values' is explicitly set to 'none' for certificate authentication.
