SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/approvals-markdown-support.md#2025-04-23_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: Markdown CODE: ``` Use _emphasis_ in comments to express **strong** opinions and point out ~~corrections~~ **_Bold, italicized text_** **~~Bold, strike-through text~~** ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Retrieving Desktop Flows with Owner Information in Microsoft Fabric DESCRIPTION: SQL query that returns all desktop flows with their owner information from Dataverse. Joins the workflow table with systemuser to provide comprehensive flow metadata including creation date, modification date, and the flow definition script. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/automation-analytics-with-fabric-queries.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: sql CODE: ``` SELECT w.name AS 'Desktop flow', w.workflowid AS 'Desktop flow Id', w.createdon AS 'Created on', w.modifiedon AS 'Last modified on', w.definition AS 'Script', w.ownerid AS 'Owner Id', s.fullname AS 'Owner name', s.internalemailaddress AS 'Owner email' FROM workflow w JOIN systemuser s ON w.ownerid = s.systemuserid WHERE w.category = 6; -- Only consider desktop flows (category 6) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Basic Aggregation - SUM Example DESCRIPTION: Performs simple summation of values within a specified context. Works with numerical and time-based values. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/aggregations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_18 LANGUAGE: Power Automate Expression Language CODE: ``` SUM([context],[value]) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Create HTML Content Action Output Variables Table - Markdown DESCRIPTION: Documents the output variable for the Create HTML Content action as a Markdown table entry. Clearly identifies the HtmlContent text variable as the HTML code generated. Useful for users referencing variables for downstream actions, like sending email. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/text.md#2025-04-23_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: Markdown CODE: ``` |Argument|Type|Description|\n|-----|-----|-----|\n|`HtmlContent`|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)|The HTML code| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Label Action in Power Automate Desktop Flow DESCRIPTION: Example of using a Label action in a Power Automate desktop flow to create a point of reference for the Go to action. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/flowcontrol.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` :::image type="content" source="media/flowcontrol/label-example.png" alt-text="Screenshot of a deployed Label action."::: ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Adding Working Days to a Date in Power Automate Expressions DESCRIPTION: Adds a specified number ('[count]', INT type) of working days to a given '[date]' (DATE type), respecting non-working days defined in the active calendar. Returns the resulting DATE. Note the limitation: calculations are only accurate within a range from 6 months before the process start to 24 months after the process end. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/date-and-time-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: powerautomate-expression CODE: ``` ADDWORKINGDAYS([date],[count]) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Assigning Multiple Approvers in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to assign an approval request to multiple persons in Power Automate, including options for different approval scenarios and how to specify multiple approvers. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/approvals-howto.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ![Approval actions.](media/approvals-howto/approval-actions.png) 2. In the **Assigned to** field, define the list of persons to whom the approval request should be sent. Separate each person with a semicolon (;). ![Assigned to field with multiple persons.](media/approvals-howto/assigned-multiple.png) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing Selector2 Action Selector Class - Power Automate Desktop - C# DESCRIPTION: Implements a selector class for the second variation, displaying both first and last name fields and hiding the age argument. Inherits from ActionSelector and sets property filters accordingly. Intended to shape the action view for scenarios where full name display is needed. Requires SDK and the central action class. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/create-custom-actions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` public class Selector2 : ActionSelector { public Selector2() { UseName("DisplayFullName"); Prop(p => p.Selector).ShouldBe(SelectorChoice.Selector2); ShowAll(); Hide(p => p.Age); } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Converting Excel File to PDF with VBScript - VBScript DESCRIPTION: This VBScript snippet automates the conversion of an Excel file to PDF by opening the specified Excel file, exporting the active sheet as a PDF using Excel's ExportAsFixedFormat method, and closing the application. Dependencies include Microsoft Excel being installed on the machine and the script running in an environment with access to the Excel COM object. The script requires 'ExcelFile' and 'PdfFile' variables to be set externally; these should contain the full paths to the source Excel file and the desired PDF output, respectively. The script outputs a PDF at the target path and overwrites files if they exist. It processes only the active worksheet and requires permissions to open and export the file. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/convert-excel-pdf-vbscript.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: VBScript CODE: ``` Dim Excel\nDim ExcelDoc\n\n'Opens the Excel file'\nSet Excel = CreateObject("Excel.Application")\nSet ExcelDoc = Excel.Workbooks.open("%ExcelFile%")\n\n'Creates the pdf file'\nExcel.ActiveSheet.ExportAsFixedFormat 0, "%PdfFile%" ,0, 1, 0,,,0\n\n'Closes the Excel file'\nExcel.ActiveWorkbook.Close\nExcel.Application.Quit ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using RANGEIF for Conditional Range Calculation in Power Automate Expressions (Pseudo-Expression Language) DESCRIPTION: RANGEIF computes the range (max-min) of [value] satisfying a [condition] within the specified context. Includes [context], [condition], [value], and [default] as parameters. Output matches value type (usually float or time). Useful when variation should be calculated on filtered data sets. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/aggregations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_15 LANGUAGE: pseudo-expression CODE: ``` RANGEIF([context],[condition],[value],[default]) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Importing Solution using Dataverse Web API DESCRIPTION: This HTTP request demonstrates how to import a solution using the ImportSolution Action in the Dataverse Web API. It includes the request and response examples, showing how to send the base64 encoded solution file in the CustomizationFile parameter. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/manage-flows-with-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_15 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` POST [Organization Uri]/api/data/v9.2/ImportSolution OData-MaxVersion: 4.0 OData-Version: 4.0 If-None-Match: null Accept: application/json Content-Type: application/json; charset=utf-8 Content-Length: 4344 { "OverwriteUnmanagedCustomizations": true, "CustomizationFile": "UEsDBBQAAgAIA..." } ``` LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` HTTP/1.1 204 NoContent OData-Version: 4.0 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Azure AD Module and Registering Service Principal in PowerShell DESCRIPTION: PowerShell commands to install Azure AD module and register the Process Insights service principal with a specific AppId. This setup is required for connecting Process Mining with custom Fabric workspace. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/process-mining-fabric-workspace.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: powershell CODE: ``` Install-Module AzureAD ``` LANGUAGE: powershell CODE: ``` Connect-AzureAD ``` LANGUAGE: powershell CODE: ``` New-AzureADServicePrincipal -AppId dad3c6de-ed58-42ef-989f-9c0303aaeedc -DisplayName 'Process Insights Prod' ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Navigate to Installation Directory - CMD DESCRIPTION: Command to change directory to the Power Automate installer location SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/install-silently.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: CMD CODE: ``` cd C:\Users\Admin\Downloads\ ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example Response for BPF Stage Retrieval HTTP DESCRIPTION: This is an example JSON response for the Web API request to retrieve BPF stages. It shows an OData-formatted response containing an array ('value') of process stage objects, each including the stage name ('stagename') and its unique ID ('processstageid'). SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/developer/business-process-flows-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` { "@odata.context": "[Organization URI]/api/data/v9.0/$metadata#processstages(stagename)", "value": [ { "@odata.etag": "W/\"858240\"", "stagename": "S1", "processstageid": "9a9185f5-b75b-4bbb-9c2b-a6626683b99b" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"858239\"", "stagename": "S3", "processstageid": "a107e2fd-7543-4c1a-b6b4-b8060ecb1a1a" }, { "@odata.etag": "W/\"858238\"", "stagename": "S2", "processstageid": "19a11fc0-3398-4214-8522-cb2a97f66e4b" } ] } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Displaying Trigger Conditions in Power Automate Copilot DESCRIPTION: This HTML snippet shows an image of the trigger conditions in Power Automate's Copilot designer. It's used to guide users on how to check and modify trigger conditions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/triggers-troubleshoot.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: html CODE: ``` :::image type="content" source="./media/triggers-introduction/copilot-trigger-conditions.png" alt-text="Screenshot that shows trigger conditions in Copilot."::: ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Displaying Get Password from CyberArk Action in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to include an image of the 'Get password from CyberArk' action in the documentation using Markdown syntax. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/cyberark.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` :::image type="content" source="media/cyberark/get-password-cyberark-action.png" alt-text="Screenshot of the Get password from CyberArk action."::: ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining CASECOUNT() Operation in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: Returns the number of cases in a process. Supported only in process context. Output is of INT data type. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/statistical-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## CASECOUNT() Returns number of the cases in the process. **Supported context:** process **Output Data Type**: INT ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Active Directory and Workstation Module List in PowerShell DESCRIPTION: PowerShell script that creates a list containing Active Directory and Workstation modules for DLP policy configuration. The script filters desktop flow modules and creates custom objects with module properties. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/prevent-data-loss.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: powershell CODE: ``` $desktopFlowModulesToAddToPolicy = @() $activeDirectoryModule = $desktopFlowModules | where {$_.properties.displayName -eq "Active Directory"} $desktopFlowModulesToAddToPolicy += [pscustomobject]@{ id=$activeDirectoryModule.id name=$activeDirectoryModule.Properties.displayName type=$activeDirectoryModule.type } $clipboardModule = $desktopFlowModules | where {$_.properties.displayName -eq "Workstation"} $desktopFlowModulesToAddToPolicy += [pscustomobject]@{ id=$clipboardModule.id name=$clipboardModule.Properties.displayName type=$clipboardModule.type } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Power Automate Flow via Copilot based on Email Folder DESCRIPTION: This Copilot prompt defines a Power Automate flow that activates when a new email arrives specifically in the 'Sync Issues' folder. The flow then proceeds to send a push notification to the user's configured device and marks the incoming email as read. This relies on Power Automate, an email connection (like Outlook) configured to monitor the specified folder, and the push notification service. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/email-triggers.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` When I receive an email in Sync Issues folder, send me a push notification and mark the email as Read. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Date Component Extraction Functions DESCRIPTION: Functions for extracting specific components from date objects. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/date-and-time-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` DATE([date]) DAY([date]) DAYOFWEEK([date]) DAYOFYEAR([date]) HOUR([date]) MILLISECOND([date]) MINUTE([date]) MONTH([date]) QUARTER([date]) SECOND([date]) TIMEOFDAY([date]) WEEKOFYEAR([date]) YEAR([date]) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Deleting User's Own Connections in Power Automate using PowerShell DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell script allows a user to delete all Power Automate connections they have created. It first authenticates the user using `Add-PowerAppsAccount`, then retrieves all connections associated with the calling user using `Get-AdminPowerAppConnection` and pipes them to `Remove-Connection` for deletion. Requires the Power Apps Admin PowerShell module. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/privacy-dsr-delete.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` ```PowerShell Add-PowerAppsAccount #Retrieves all connections for the calling user and deletes them Get-AdminPowerAppConnection | Remove-Connection ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Deleting User's Own Shared Connection Permissions in Power Automate using PowerShell DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell script allows a user to remove their own role assignments (permissions) from shared Power Automate connections. After authenticating with `Add-PowerAppsAccount`, it fetches all connection role assignments for the current user using `Get-ConnectionRoleAssignment` and removes them using `Remove-ConnectionRoleAssignment`. Requires the Power Apps Admin PowerShell module. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/privacy-dsr-delete.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` ```PowerShell Add-PowerAppsAccount #Retrieves all connection role assignments for the calling user and deletes them Get-ConnectionRoleAssignment | Remove-ConnectionRoleAssignment ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Documenting Exceptions for PDF Extraction Action - Markdown DESCRIPTION: This Markdown table catalogs the possible exceptions encountered during the PDF pages extraction process in Power Automate. It describes each exception type and the related error, such as invalid passwords, file absence, out-of-range pages, incorrect selection, and extraction failure. This information is vital for users to troubleshoot and handle errors within their automations. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/pdf.md#2025-04-23_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Exception|Description|\n|-----|-----|\n|Invalid password|The given password is invalid|\n|PDF file doesn't exist|File doesn't exist on the given path|\n|Page out of bounds|Indicates that one or more pages are out of bounds of the PDF file|\n|Invalid page selection|Indicates that the given pages aren't valid for the PDF file|\n|Failed to extract new PDF |Indicates that an error occurred while trying to extract new PDF | ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Filtering Events with Positive Duration (Generic Metric) in Process Mining Expression DESCRIPTION: This expression provides an alternative method to filter events with positive duration using the generic `Duration()` metric. It achieves the same goal as comparing 'End' and 'Start' attributes but offers potentially better performance and portability across different contexts (like case overview, root cause analysis) as it relies on a pre-calculated metric. This expression evaluates at the event level. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/custom-metrics-advanced-examples.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Process Mining Expression CODE: ``` Duration() > 0 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining PARALLELUTILIZATION() Operation in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: Returns the cumulative case utilization, which can exceed 1 due to parallel events. Supported only in case context. Output is of FLOAT data type. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/statistical-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## PARALLELUTILIZATION() Returns the cumulative case utilization (a number from 0 to 1 to N). A value above 1 is due to parallel events that last longer than the case itself. **Supported context:** case **Output Data Type**: FLOAT ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a Self-Signed Certificate with PowerShell DESCRIPTION: PowerShell script to create a self-signed certificate for signing custom action DLLs. The script creates the certificate, exports it as both PFX and CER files, and requires setting a password for the certificate. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/guidance/how-to/build-custom-action/buildcustomaction.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: powershell CODE: ``` $certPFXFileName="C:\PADCustomAction\PADCustomActionCert.pfx"; $certCERFileName="C:\PADCustomAction\PADCustomActionCert.cer"; $certStoreLocation="Cert:\LocalMachine\AuthRoot"; $certname = "PADCustomActionSelfSignCert" ##Create certificate $cert = New-SelfSignedCertificate -CertStoreLocation Cert:\CurrentUser\My -Type CodeSigningCert -Subject "CN=$certname" -KeyExportPolicy Exportable -KeySpec Signature -KeyLength 2048 -KeyAlgorithm RSA -HashAlgorithm SHA256 $mypwd = ConvertTo-SecureString -String -Force -AsPlainText ##Export certificate $certPFXFile = Export-PfxCertificate -Cert $cert -FilePath $certPFXFileName -Password $mypwd $certCERFile = Export-Certificate -Cert $cert -FilePath $certCERFileName -Type CERT -Verbose -Force ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example Response for BPF Instance Deletion HTTP DESCRIPTION: This describes the expected HTTP response upon successfully deleting a BPF instance. A status code of '204 No Content' indicates that the deletion was successful. If the specified BPF instance ID does not exist, a '404 Not Found' status will be returned instead. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/developer/business-process-flows-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` If the row exists, you’ll get a normal response with status 204 to indicate the delete was successful. If the table isn’t found, you’ll get a response with status 404. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Case Information Export Steps in Markdown DESCRIPTION: Step-by-step instructions for exporting case information from the Case overview screen in Power Automate Process Mining SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/case-overview-statistics.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` 1. In the open view, select **Export** on the left panel. 1. In the **Export type** dropdown menu, select **Cases**. 1. Verify that the **Export as** selection is **CSV** and the **Delimiter** field is a comma. 1. Select statistics to be exported. 1. Select **Export**. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Including Preview Features Definition in Markdown DESCRIPTION: This is a Microsoft Docs specific Markdown directive used to include content from another file. It inserts the standard definition or disclaimer text related to preview features from the specified 'includes' file into the current document. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/faqs-generative-actions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` [!INCLUDE[cc_preview_features_definition](includes/cc-preview-features-definition.md)] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Checking String Starts With Value in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: The STARTSWITH function checks if a string starts with a specific value. It returns TRUE if the string starts with the given value, FALSE otherwise. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/string-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## STARTSWITH([string],[value]) returns TRUE if string starts with the given value, else returns FALSE **Parameters:** - **[string]** - input string Data type: STRING - **[value]** - value to be matched Data type: STRING **Output Data Type**: BOOL ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Azure Service Principal for Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Azure CLI command to create a service principal for Power Automate Hosted Machine Groups using a specific application ID. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/hosted-machine-groups.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` az ad sp create --id 51699864-8078-4c9e-a688-09a1db1b2e09 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Opening an FTP Connection in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use the 'Open FTP connection' action in Power Automate. It shows the configuration of host, port, credentials, and timeout settings. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/ftp.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` :::image type="content" source="media/ftp/open-ftp-connection-example.png" alt-text="Screenshot of the Open FTP connection action."::: ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Sending Email from Shared Mailbox using Power Automate Outlook Connector DESCRIPTION: Explains how to use the 'Send an email from a shared mailbox (V2)' action in Power Automate. This action requires specifying the address of the shared mailbox from which the email should be sent. Crucially, the user running the flow must have been granted permissions by the distribution list admin to send from the specified shared mailbox in Outlook. Emails sent using this action will appear in the Sent Items folder of the shared mailbox. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/email-top-scenarios.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Power Automate CODE: ``` Send an email from a shared mailbox (V2) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Remove XML Element Attribute in Power Automate Desktop Flows DESCRIPTION: This action removes an attribute from an XML element. It requires an XML document and the name of the attribute to remove. An optional XPath query can be provided to locate the specific element. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/xml.md#2025-04-23_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: XML CODE: ``` |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |XML document|No|[XML node](../variable-data-types.md#xml)||The XML document or XML element to remove its attribute| |XPath query|Yes|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The XPath expression to locate the subelement and remove its attribute| |Attribute name|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The name of the attribute to remove| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Renaming Files - Power Automate Actions - Markdown DESCRIPTION: Documents the parameters and operation details for the 'Rename File(s)' action in Microsoft Power Automate. Lists required and optional arguments, the types of file sources accepted, the different rename schemes supported, and specific exception cases. The content is structured as markdown tables, suitable for inclusion in Power Automate Docs, and does not represent executable code but rather structured configuration references. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/file.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Markdown CODE: ``` ### Input parameters\n\n|Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description|\n|-----|-----|-----|-----|-----|\n|File to rename|No|[List](../variable-data-types.md#list) of [Files](../variable-data-types.md#files-and-folders)||The file(s) to rename. This value can be a file path, or a variable containing a file, a list of files, a text path, or a list of text paths. Use the 'Get files in folder' action to populate a variable with a list of files.|\n|Add number to|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|True|Specifies whether to add the number to the existing file name(s) or a new name|\n|Rename scheme|N/A|Set new name, Add text, Remove text, Replace text, Change extension, Add datetime, Make sequential|Set new name|Specifies how to rename the file(s)|\n|New file name|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The new name of the file(s)|\n|New extension|Yes|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The text to add as the new extension for the file(s)|\n|New file name|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The new name of the file(s)|\n|Add number to|N/A|After name, Before name|After name|Specifies whether to add the number before or after the original name(s) or a new base name|\n|Text to add|Yes|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The text to add to the original file name(s)|\n|Text to remove|Yes|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The text to remove from the original file name(s). This rename scheme searches each file name, and removes the entered text anywhere in the name, each time it occurs.|\n|Text to replace|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The text to replace in the original file name(s). This rename scheme searches each file name, and replaces the entered text anywhere in the name, each time it occurs|\n|Use custom datetime|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|False|Specifies whether to use a custom datetime|\n|Datetime to add|N/A|Current datetime, Creation time, Last accessed, Last modified|Current datetime|Specifies what datetime value to add to the file name(s)|\n|Keep extension|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|True|Specifies whether to include the previous extension with the file name(s). Disable this option to add the extension to the file(s) manually.|\n|Replace with|Yes|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The text to replace the original text with|\n|Start numbering at|No|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)||The starting number value|\n|Add text|N/A|After name, Before name|After name|Specifies whether to add the text before or after the original name(s)|\n|Custom datetime|No|[Datetime](../variable-data-types.md#dates-and-time)||The datetime to add to the file name(s)|\n|Increment by|No|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)||The number to increment the starting value by|\n|Add datetime|N/A|After name, Before name|After name|Specifies whether to add the datetime before or after the original name(s)|\n|Separator|N/A|Nothing, Space, Dash, Period, Underscore|Space|Specifies what to use to separate the original file name and the number added, including the option to not use a separator|\n|Separator|N/A|Nothing, Space, Dash, Period, Underscore|Space|Specifies what to use to separate the original file name and the datetime value added, including the option to not use a separator|\n|Use padding|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|False|Specifies whether to use padding|\n|Datetime format|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)|yyyyMMdd|The format of the datetime value to add to the file name, such as MM/dd/yyyy for date, and hh:mm:sstt for time|\n|Make each number at least|Yes|[Numeric value](../variable-data-types.md#numeric-value)|3|The minimum length for each number added|\n|If file exists|N/A|Do nothing, Overwrite|Do nothing|Specifies what to do if a file with the same name already exists in the folder|\n\n### Variables produced\n\n|Argument|Type|Description|\n|-----|-----|-----|\n|RenamedFiles|[List](../variable-data-types.md#list) of [Files](../variable-data-types.md#files-and-folders)|The renamed file(s) as a list of files|\n\n### Exceptions\n\n|Exception|Description|\n|-----|-----|\n|Directory not found|Indicates that the directory wasn't found|\n|File not found|Indicates that the file doesn't exist|\n|Can't rename file|Indicates a problem renaming the file| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Running Subflow in Power Automate Desktop Flow DESCRIPTION: Demonstration of using the Run subflow action to execute a separate subflow within the main flow. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/flowcontrol.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` :::image type="content" source="media/flowcontrol/subflows-example.png" alt-text="Screenshot of the deployed Run subflow action."::: ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Automation Kit Installation Steps in Markdown DESCRIPTION: A numbered list of steps required to install the Automation Kit scheduler, including enabling the Power Apps component framework, installing the Creator Kit, and importing the managed solution. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/guidance/automation-kit/setup/scheduler.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` 1. Ensure the Power Apps component framework is enabled by following the steps in [Enable the Power Apps component framework feature](/power-apps/developer/component-framework/component-framework-for-canvas-apps#enable-the-power-apps-component-framework-feature"). 1. Install the [Creator Kit](https://appsource.microsoft.com/product/dynamics-365/microsoftpowercatarch.creatorkit1) from App Source into the target environment. 1. In the **Assets** section in the latest GitHub release of the [automation kit](https://github.com/microsoft/powercat-automation-kit/releases) file, download **AutomationKitScheduler_*_managed.zip** by selecting it. 1. Import the downloaded AutomationKitScheduler_*_managed.zip file. To learn how to import, go to [Import solutions](/power-apps/maker/data-platform/import-update-export-solutions). ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Event Level Aggregation (View) Custom Metric Formula DESCRIPTION: This custom metric calculates the total duration of events in the current view. It uses the SUM function to aggregate the Duration attribute across all events in the view. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/custom-metrics-beginner-examples.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` :::image type="content" alt-text="Screenshot of an expression in a custom metric formula." source="media/01-event-level-view.png"::: ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Duration and Retention Limits Tables DESCRIPTION: Markdown tables showing the duration limits for flow runs and retention limits for different flow states. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/limits-and-config.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` | Name | Limit | Notes | |------|-------|-------| | Run duration | 30 days | Run duration is calculated using a run's start time and includes flows with pending steps like approvals. After 30 days, any pending steps time out.| | Run retention in storage | 30 days | Run retention is calculated using a run's start time. | | Minimum recurrence interval | 60 seconds | | Maximum recurrence interval | 500 days | | Minimum postpone interval | 5 seconds for Low, 1 second for all other performance profiles | ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Average Value of a Case Attribute (e.g., PriceUSD) - Metric Formula DESCRIPTION: Calculates the mean value of a case-level attribute (e.g., PriceUSD) in a statistics metric, using case context and aggregation. Cannot reference event-level attributes. Input is all cases and their PriceUSD attributes; output is the average price value. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/requirements-for-application.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: pseudo-code CODE: ``` AVG(CaseEvents, PriceUSD) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Unhiding Excel Worksheets with VBScript DESCRIPTION: VBScript code that opens an Excel file, iterates through all worksheets to make them visible, and saves the changes. The script uses Excel automation objects to manipulate the workbook and requires a file path variable named 'ExcelFile'. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/unhide-excel-worksheets-vbscript.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: VBScript CODE: ``` 'Opens the Excel file' Set objExcel = CreateObject("Excel.Application") Set objWorkbook = objExcel.Workbooks.Open("%ExcelFile%") objExcel.Application.Visible = True 'Unhides all the worksheets of the Excel file' For i=1 To objWorkbook.Sheets.Count objWorkbook.Sheets(i).Visible = True Next 'Saves and closes the Excel file' objWorkbook.Save objWorkbook.Close SaveChanges = True ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using STDEV for Standard Deviation Calculation in Power Automate Expressions (Pseudo-Expression Language) DESCRIPTION: STDEV computes the standard deviation of a given attribute, nested operation, or expression, grouped by context. Inputs: [context] and [value] (numeric, date, or time). Outputs: float or time. Effective for quantifying variability or spread within event, process, or case groups. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/aggregations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_16 LANGUAGE: pseudo-expression CODE: ``` STDEV([context],[value]) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Firefox Configuration Command DESCRIPTION: Command to access Firefox configuration settings to disable tab modal prompts for optimal Power Automate functionality SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/install-browser-extensions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: text CODE: ``` about:config ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Important Note About Boolean Columns DESCRIPTION: Markdown note explaining the behavior of required boolean columns in business process flows. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/create-business-process-flow.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` > [!NOTE] > > * If you set a two-option boolean column as **Required**, users can't continue unless the column value is **Yes**. The user is required to mark the column as completed before moving to the next stage. > * If either **Yes** or **No** are acceptable column values, then you should make the column a choice instead of a two-option boolean column. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Performance Profile License Plans Table DESCRIPTION: Markdown table showing the mapping between performance profiles and associated license plans in Power Automate. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/limits-and-config.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` | Performance profile | Plans | |---------------------|-------| | Low | - Free
- Microsoft 365 plans
- Power Apps Plan 1, Per App plans
- Power Automate Plan 1
- All license trials
- Dynamics 365 Team Member
- Microsoft Power Apps for Developer | | Medium | - Power Apps triggered flows, manual flows, child flows, Power Apps Plan 2, Power Apps per user plan
- Power Automate Plan 2, Power Automate Premium (previously Power Automate per user), Power Automate Premium plans (previously Power Automate per user with Attended RPA plans)
Dynamics 365 Enterprise plans, Dynamics 365 Professional plans
- [Dynamics 365 non-licensed users, application users, users with special free licenses](/power-platform/admin/api-request-limits-allocations#non-licensed-usersapplication-usersusers-with-special-free-licenses)| | High | Power Automate Process plan, Power Automate per flow plan | | Unlimited Extended | Pay-as-you-go flows, Dynamics in context flows running under service principal ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Querying Application Insights Log Analytics in Azure DESCRIPTION: Azure CLI query to retrieve trace data from Application Insights over the last 30 days, including timestamp, message, severity level, and various client and operational parameters. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/process-mining-templates.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: azurecli CODE: ``` traces | where timestamp > ago(30d) | project timestamp, message, severityLevel, operation_Name, operation_Id, session_Id, user_Id, client_Type, client_City, client_StateOrProvince, client_CountryOrRegion, client_Browser, appId, customDimensions ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Checking String Ends With Value in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: The ENDSWITH function checks if a string ends with a specific value. It returns TRUE if the string ends with the given value, FALSE otherwise. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/string-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## ENDSWITH([string],[value]) Returns TRUE if string ends with the given value, else returns FALSE. **Parameters:** - **[string]** - input string Data type: STRING - **[value]** - value to match end of input string Data type: STRING **Output Data Type**: BOOL ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using Custom Metrics in Subprocess Filter Expressions in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to incorporate custom metrics into the subprocess filter expressions. It references the custom metrics documentation for more detailed information on creating and using custom metrics in filter criteria. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/subprocess-filter.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` You can also select **fx** to use [custom metrics](custom-metrics.md). ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Executing PowerShell Installation Script DESCRIPTION: Commands to navigate to the installation directory and run the automation kit installation script. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/guidance/automation-kit/setup/command-line-install.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: cmd CODE: ``` cd AutomationKitInstall powershell Install_AutomationKit.ps1 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Hyperlinks in Power Automate Approval Markdown DESCRIPTION: Creates text hyperlinks using standard markdown link syntax. Links use square brackets for the link text followed by parentheses containing the URL. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/approvals-markdown-support.md#2025-04-23_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: Markdown CODE: ``` [Power Automate](https://make.powerautomate.com) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating an Acronym Logger Adaptive Card with JSON Schema DESCRIPTION: This JSON code defines an Adaptive Card form with input fields for collecting acronyms and their definitions. The card features a title, two text input fields (one for the acronym abbreviation and one multiline field for the definition), and a submit button. The inputs are identified by the IDs 'acAcronym' and 'acDefinition', which can be referenced as outputs in Power Automate flows. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/acronym-sample.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "$schema": "http://adaptivecards.io/schemas/adaptive-card.json", "type": "AdaptiveCard", "version": "1.0", "body": [ { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Acronym Logger", "id": "Title", "spacing": "Medium", "horizontalAlignment": "Center", "size": "ExtraLarge", "weight": "Bolder", "color": "Accent" }, { "type": "Container", "items": [ { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Acronym", "wrap": true, "spacing": "Medium" }, { "type": "Input.Text", "id": "acAcronym", "placeholder": "Enter the abbreviation for the acronym" }, { "type": "TextBlock", "text": "Definition", "wrap": true }, { "type": "Input.Text", "placeholder": "Enter a definition of the acronym above", "id": "acDefinition", "isMultiline": true } ] } ], "actions": [ { "type": "Action.Submit", "title": "Submit", "id": "btnSubmit" } ] } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Execute XPath Expression in Power Automate Desktop Flows DESCRIPTION: This action extracts values from an XML document using an XPath query. It requires an XML document as input and an XPath expression to execute. The action can return either the first matching value or all matching values. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/xml.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: XPath CODE: ``` |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |XML document to parse|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The XML as text or a previously defined variable that contains the XML document to parse| |XPath query|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The XPath expression to execute against the XML document| |Get first value only|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|False|Specifies whether to retrieve a single value (the first value only) or all the values that match the provided XPath expression| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Tables in Power Automate Approval Markdown DESCRIPTION: Creates tables using pipe characters to separate cells and hyphens to create the header row separator. Tables organize structured data with headers and aligned columns. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/approvals-markdown-support.md#2025-04-23_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: Markdown CODE: ``` | Heading 1 | Heading 2 | Heading 3 | |-----------|-----------|-----------| | Cell A1 | Cell A2 | Cell A3 | | Cell B1 | Cell B2 | Cell B3 | ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Unregistering Plugin DLL - PowerShell DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell command unregisters the specified DLL related to UI automation for Power Automate Desktop's RDP DVC Plugin. It is necessary when troubleshooting or reinstalling the plugin on virtual desktop environments. Dependency: regsvr32 must be available on the system, and the DLL path must be correct. Input: DLL file name; Output: Unregisters the COM server DLL. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/troubleshoot.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` regsvr32 /u .\\Microsoft.Flow.RPA.Desktop.UIAutomation.RDP.DVC.Plugin.dll ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Quantitative Edge Counting per Country DESCRIPTION: Alternative approach that counts total number of C->C edges per country rather than just cases containing such edges. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/custom-metrics-advanced-examples.md#2025-04-23_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: process-mining-expression CODE: ``` SUM(CasesPerAttribute(), COUNTIF(Edge(), STARTACTIVITY() = "C" AND ENDACTIVITY() = "C")) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Generating Base64 Encoding for PFX Certificate using PowerShell DESCRIPTION: This PowerShell script reads a PFX certificate file from the specified path, converts its content to a Base64 encoded string, and outputs the result. This encoded string is required for the 'pfx' value in JSON payloads for certificate-based connection creation. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/set-runowner-desktopflowconnection.md#2025-04-23_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: powershell CODE: ``` $filePath = "C:\path\to\your\certificate.pfx" $bytes = [System.IO.File]::ReadAllBytes($filePath) $base64String = [System.Convert]::ToBase64String($bytes) $base64String ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Wildcard Endpoint Allowlist (Configuration) DESCRIPTION: This wildcard endpoint pattern represents the default public endpoint that administrators need to authorize to permit Power Automate desktop flow runs. It covers all Azure Service Bus namespaces used by the service. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/limits-and-config.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: plaintext CODE: ``` *.servicebus.windows.net ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Workflow Condition Types Table DESCRIPTION: Markdown table defining different types of conditions available in background workflow processes, including Check Condition, Conditional Branch, Default Action, and Wait Condition types. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/configure-workflow-steps.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Condition Type|Description| |--------------------|------------------| |**Check Condition**|A logical "if \ then" statement.| |**Conditional Branch**|A logical "else-if-then" statement.| |**Default Action**|A logical "else" statement.| |**Wait Condition**|Enables a background workflow to pause itself until criteria are met.| |**Parallel Wait Branch**|Defines an alternative wait condition with corresponding steps.| |**Custom Step**|Developers can create custom background workflow steps that define conditions.| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Decrypt to File with AES in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: This action decrypts a string and saves the result to a file using AES decryption with specified parameters. It supports various encoding formats, key sizes, and optional salt and initialization vector usage. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/cryptography.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## Decrypt to file with AES Decrypt a string to a file with AES based on a specified key and an encoding format. ### Input parameters |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |Encoding|N/A|System default, ASCII, Unicode, Big-endian Unicode, UTF-8|Unicode|The encoding of the text to decrypt| |Text to decrypt|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The text to decrypt in the form of a base64 string| |Decryption key|No|Direct encrypted input or [Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The decryption key to use| |Decrypt to file|No|[File](../variable-data-types.md#files-and-folders)||The file to save the decrypted text into| |If file exists|N/A|Overwrite, Don't decrypt to file, Add sequential suffix|Add sequential suffix|Specifies what to do in case the destination file already exists| |Padding|N/A|None, PKCS7, Zeros, ANSIX923, ISO10126|PKCS7|The padding to use for the selected decryption algorithm| |Key size|N/A|128 bits, 192 bits, 256 bits|256 bits|The size of the key in bits to use for decryption| |Use salt|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|False|Specifies whether to use salt for decryption| |Salt|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The salt to use for decryption in the form of a base64 string| |Use initialization vector|N/A|[Boolean value](../variable-data-types.md#boolean-value)|False|Specifies whether to use an initialization vector. Enter the initialization vector in the form of a base64 string| |Initialization vector|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The initialization vector to use for decryption| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Including Footer Banner DESCRIPTION: Markdown syntax for including a footer banner in the documentation. Extracting Left Substring in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: The LEFT function extracts a specified number of characters from the left side of a string. It takes the input string and the number of characters to extract as parameters. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/string-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## LEFT([string],[count]) Extracts a given number of characters from the left side of a supplied text string. **Parameters:** - **[string]** - input string Data type: STRING - **[count]** - number of characters Data type: INT **Output Data Type**: STRING ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Markdown Tables for Data Type Conversion Parameters DESCRIPTION: Documentation tables defining parameters and outputs for converting between text, numbers, and datetime values. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/text.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Argument|Type|Description| |-----|-----|-----| |TextAsNumber|[Numeric value]|The new numeric value| |FormattedNumber|[Text value]|The formatted number as text| |TextAsDateTime|[Datetime]|The datetime value| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Power Automate Mobile Client for US Government DESCRIPTION: Steps to configure the Power Automate mobile client for signing in to the US Government Cloud. This process involves changing the region settings to use the GCC (Government Community Cloud). On the sign-in page, select ![Wifi icon with a gear sign.](media/us-govt/icon-wifi-gear.png) (a wifi icon with a gear sign) in the upper-right corner. 2. Select **Region settings**. 3. Select GCC: US Government GCC 4. Select OK. 5. On the sign-in page, select **Sign in**. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Extracting Substring in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: The SUBSTRING function extracts a portion of a string based on a starting position and length. It takes the input string, start position, and count of characters as parameters. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/string-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## SUBSTRING([string],[start],[count]) Returns substring from the specified start position and by the specified number of characters. **Parameters:** - **[string]** - input string Data type: STRING - **[start]** - start position of substring Data type: INT - **[count]** - length of substring Data type: INT **Output Data Type**: STRING ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Building a Cabinet File for Custom Action with PowerShell DESCRIPTION: PowerShell command to build a cabinet file (.cab) for packaging the custom action. This uses a BuildCAB.ps1 script to create the package that will be uploaded to Power Automate. Uses both DURATION and aggregate AVG functions, requiring explicit scoping. Input is individual case duration and global average duration; output is the duration ratio. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/requirements-for-application.md#2025-04-23_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: pseudo-code CODE: ``` DURATION()/AVG(ViewCases,DURATION()) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using Markdown for Formatting Approval Requests in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use Markdown to format the text in an approval request's Details field. This allows for better presentation of information to approvers. The `` element lacks the `useDefaultCredentials="True"` attribute (or it could be explicitly set to `False`). The `proxyaddress` attribute within the `` tag specifies the proxy server's address and port, and `bypassonlocal="True"` is included. This configuration is intended for scenarios where proxy authentication requires specific credentials or methods not covered by default credentials, possibly relying on other mechanisms like interactive prompts or specific service account configurations. Apply this to the relevant `.config` files. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/proxy-settings.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: xml CODE: ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining SELFLOOPCOUNT() Operation in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: Counts self-loops within a case. Supports an optional attribute parameter. Supported in case context. Returns an INT. If none is entered, the default attribute is mining attribute (activity attribute), optional Data type: STRING (only fixed string is allowed) **Output Data Type**: INT ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Entity Relationship Table for Other Entities DESCRIPTION: Table defining additional helper entities used in the semantic model. It requires environment details, display name, credential ID, environment variables for username/password, target group ID, and certificate details for the Run Owner. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/set-runowner-desktopflowconnection.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "properties": { "environment": { "id": "/providers/Microsoft.PowerApps/environments/[ENVIRONMENT_ID]", "name":"[ENVIRONMENT_ID]" }, "displayName": "[DISPLAY_NAME]", "credentialId": "[CREDENTIAL_ID]", "connectionParametersSet": { "name":"azureRelayRunOwner", "values": { "username":{"value":"@environmentVariables(\"[ENVIRONMENT_VARIABLE_USERNAME]\")"}, "password":{"value":"@environmentVariables(\"[ENVIRONMENT_VARIABLE_PASSWORD]\")"}, "targetId":{"value":"[GROUP_ID]"}, "tokenRunOwnerCert:clientId":{"value":"[APP_ID]"}, "tokenRunOwnerCert:clientCertificateSecret": { "value": { "pfx":"[PFX]", "password":"[PASSWORD]" } } } } } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Adding Working Minutes to a Date in Power Automate Expressions DESCRIPTION: Adds a specified number ('[count]', INT type) of working minutes to a given '[date]' (DATE type), respecting the working hours and non-working days defined in the active calendar. Returns the resulting DATE. Note the limitation: calculations are only accurate within a range from 6 months before the process start to 24 months after the process end. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/date-and-time-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: powerautomate-expression CODE: ``` ADDWORKINGMINUTES([date],[count]) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating Power Automate Connection (Cyber Ark Auth) DESCRIPTION: This JSON payload defines the request body for creating a Power Automate connection using Cyber Ark authentication credentials and a specified Run Owner. It requires environment details, display name, credential ID, username environment variable, target group ID, and certificate details for the Run Owner. The 'password' field within 'values' is set to 'none'. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/how-to/set-runowner-desktopflowconnection.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "properties": { "environment": { "id": "/providers/Microsoft.PowerApps/environments/[ENVIRONMENT_ID]", "name":"[ENVIRONMENT_ID]" }, "displayName": "[DISPLAY_NAME]", "credentialId": "[CREDENTIAL_ID]", "connectionParametersSet": { "name":"azureRelayRunOwner", "values": { "username":{"value":"@environmentVariables(\"[ENVIRONMENT_VARIABLE_USERNAME]\")"}, "password":{"value":"none"}, "targetId":{"value":"[GROUP_ID]"}, "tokenRunOwnerCert:clientId":{"value":"[APP_ID]"}, "tokenRunOwnerCert:clientCertificateSecret": { "value": { "pfx":"[PFX]", "password":"[PASSWORD]" } } } } } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Process Deletion Navigation Code DESCRIPTION: Code reference showing the breadcrumbs navigation pattern for process deletion interface. Requires prior authentication via `Add-PowerAppsAccount` and appropriate administrative permissions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/how-tos-bulk-resubmit.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: powershell CODE: ``` $tenantSettings = Get-TenantSettings ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Documenting PDF Merge Action Parameters - Markdown DESCRIPTION: This Markdown table details the required and optional input parameters for merging PDF files using Power Automate. It includes how to list multiple files, specify the merged file path, handle pre-existing files, provide passwords for protected PDFs, and declare delimiters for passwords. Users are guided on correct list formatting and delimiter usage. There are implications of dependencies on proper types and formats. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/pdf.md#2025-04-23_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description|\n|-----|-----|-----|-----|-----|\n|PDF files|No|[List](../variable-data-types.md#list) of [Files](../variable-data-types.md#files-and-folders)||The files to merge. Enclose multiple files in double quotes (") and separate them by a delimiter, or use a list of files|\n|Merged PDF path|No|[File](../variable-data-types.md#files-and-folders)||The path to store the merged PDF|\n|If file exists|N/A|Overwrite, Don't overwrite, Add sequential suffix|Add sequential suffix|Specifies what to do in case the destination file already exists|\n|Passwords|Yes|Direct encrypted input or [Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The delimited passwords. The order should be the same as the order of the input PDFs. Leave this blank if the PDFs aren't password protected|\n|Delimiter|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)|,|A custom password delimiter. This delimiter shouldn't be part of any of the passwords| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring FetchXML Expression in Power Automate Flow DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to set up an expression in a Power Automate flow condition to check the status of a background operation. It uses the outputs from a previous 'Perform a background operation' step to access the operation status code. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/dataverse/data-retention-flow.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Power Automate CODE: ``` outputs('Perform_a_background_operation_(preview)')?['body/backgroundOperationStatusCode'] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Logical Operators in Power Automate Expression Language DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the use of logical operators (AND, OR, NOT) in Power Automate expressions for implementing complex conditional logic. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/variable-manipulation.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Power Automate Expression Language CODE: ``` %Index = 1 OR Index = 2% %Index = 4 AND Text = "Four"% %NOT(4 <> 4)% ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Send Email Action for Validation Failure in Power Automate DESCRIPTION: Describes configuring the 'Send an email' action within the 'If no' branch of a condition in Power Automate. This action is triggered when the SAP validation check fails (as determined by the Condition action), notifying the relevant user about the issue before the flow terminates. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/guidance/rpa-sap-playbook/data-pre-validation-SAP-ERP.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: plaintext CODE: ``` Action: Send an email (within 'If no' branch) To: [Recipient Email Address] Subject: [Error Subject, e.g., SAP Validation Failed] Body: [Email content detailing the failure] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Aggregating Flow Session Status Counts with FetchXML DESCRIPTION: This FetchXML query is designed to be used within the Dataverse 'List rows' action in Power Automate. It aggregates the count of flow sessions (`flowsessionid`) from the `flowsession` entity, grouping them by their status code (`statuscode`). The query filters for sessions completed within the last month (`last-x-months`). The result provides a count for each distinct status code (e.g., failed, succeeded) for flows run in the specified period. This example corresponds to a Copilot query like 'how many failed vs succeeded flows did we have last month?'. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/use-copilot-to-analyze-desktopflow-activity.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: xml CODE: ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Markdown Front Matter Configuration DESCRIPTION: YAML front matter configuration for the documentation page, specifying metadata like title, description, author, and other document properties. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/guidance/automation-kit/control-center-overview.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` --- title: Overview of the Control Center description: Learn how control fits with your environment and within the Automation Kit suite: flow documentationcenter: na author: Grant-Archibald-MS editor: '' ms.custom: guidance ms.topic: conceptual ms.tgt_pltfrm: na ms.workload: na ms.date: 08/04/2023 ms.author: grarchib ms.reviewer: angieandrews --- ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Input Parameters for Subtract Dates Action DESCRIPTION: This markdown table defines the input parameters for the 'Subtract dates' action, including the dates to subtract and the unit to express the difference in. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/datetime.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |From date|No|[Datetime](../variable-data-types.md#dates-and-time)||The datetime to subtract the first datetime from. This will be the base datetime, so generally put the later date/time in this attribute| |Subtract date|No|[Datetime](../variable-data-types.md#dates-and-time)||The datetime to subtract| |Get difference in|N/A|Seconds, Minutes, Hours, Days|Days|The unit of time to express the difference in| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Navigating to Plugin Directory with PowerShell - PowerShell DESCRIPTION: This snippet uses PowerShell to change the current directory to where the DVC Plugin for Power Automate Desktop is installed. It is a prerequisite step for running DLL registration commands for the agent used in virtual desktops. The main parameter is the destination path which should be adjusted if Power Automate Desktop is installed elsewhere. Input: directory path. Output: changes current working directory. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/troubleshoot.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` cd "C:\\Program Files (x86)\\Power Automate Desktop\\RDP\\DVCPlugin\\x64" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Service Bus Namespace Endpoints Table DESCRIPTION: Table containing Azure Service Bus namespace endpoints with their geographic locations and status flags. Each entry includes the full namespace URL and regional information. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/limits-and-config.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` | prdwestusmmrns-V2-35-9yojrmcrrhkvb3kgvbwdgcz6rxzi4.servicebus.windows.net | United States | No | | prdwestusmmrns-V2-36-ygezplol2wtqo6r23n0pn10t0sr6c.servicebus.windows.net | United States | No | ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Importing a Certificate to the Certificate Store with PowerShell DESCRIPTION: PowerShell command to import a certificate into the certificate store. This step is necessary after creating the certificate to make it available for signing custom actions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/guidance/how-to/build-custom-action/buildcustomaction.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: powershell CODE: ``` ##Import certificate Import-Certificate -CertStoreLocation $certStoreLocation -FilePath $certCERFile ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using COUNTUNIQUEIF for Conditional Distinct Counting in Power Automate Expressions (Pseudo-Expression Language) DESCRIPTION: Describes COUNTUNIQUEIF, enabling the counting of unique attribute values matching a specific condition in a given context. Parameters are [context], [condition] (boolean), [value] (attribute/expression), and [default]. Output depends on value/input type. Useful for analytics where uniqueness must also match a filter; supports complex metric logic. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/aggregations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: pseudo-expression CODE: ``` COUNTUNIQUEIF([context],[condition],[value],[default]) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Calculating Average Duration for All Cases in Process DESCRIPTION: Calculates the average duration across all cases within the entire process, irrespective of view filters, using the 'ProcessCases' context. When visualized on the process map, this yields a single, uniform average duration value applicable to all activities and edges. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/calculation-context.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: PowerAutomateExpression CODE: ``` AVG(ProcessCases, DURATION()) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Calculating Relative Activity Duration with a Power Automate Metric Formula DESCRIPTION: This example formula demonstrates how to calculate the relative duration of an activity in Power Automate Process Mining. It computes the average duration for the current context (`AVG(DURATION())`) and divides it by the average duration across all cases in the view (`AVG(VIEWCASES, DURATION())`), providing a ratio. It utilizes the `AVG` aggregation function and the `DURATION` scalar function. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/general-information.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: CustomFormula CODE: ``` AVG (DURATION()) / AVG (VIEWCASES, DURATION()) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Calculating Average Ratio of Invoice Amount to Case Duration (Pseudocode) DESCRIPTION: This example elaborates a specific formula to compute the average of the ratio of invoice total (excluding VAT) to the total hours spent per case. It uses the pseudocode operators 'Avg', 'ViewCases' for the data scope, multiplication/conversion to float, and a TOTALHOURS function. Dependencies include defined metric fields and calculation functions within the Process Mining app. 'ViewCases' specifies context (all cases in view), 'InvoiceTotalAmountWithoutVAT' is the numerator attribute, and 'Duration()' is wrapped with 'TOTALHOURS' for denominator. Output is the calculated average over all cases; inputs must be numeric and temporally convertible. Results depend on accuracy of field mappings and data completeness. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/custom-metrics-how-to.md#2025-04-23_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Pseudocode CODE: ``` Avg(ViewCases,\u00a01.0 *\u00a0InvoiceTotalAmountWithoutVAT\u00a0/\u00a0TOTALHOURS(Duration()))\u200b ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Counting User Changes per Edge in Process Mining Expression DESCRIPTION: This expression calculates the number of user changes occurring on each unique path (edge) between consecutive events. It defines a helper metric `UserChanged` which checks if the 'User' attribute differs between the source event (`SOURCE(User)`) and the target event (`TARGET(User)`) of an edge. It then uses `COUNTIF()` to aggregate the count of edges where `UserChanged` is True. The result is per unique edge type and is used in Process Map edges, Statistics edges, and Edge conditional filters. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/custom-metrics-advanced-examples.md#2025-04-23_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: Process Mining Expression CODE: ``` COUNTIF(UserChanged, UserChanged == True) where UserChanged = (TARGET(User) != SOURCE(User)) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Registering Process Mining Service Principal in PowerShell DESCRIPTION: PowerShell command to register the process mining service principal in Azure Active Directory. This command creates a new service principal with the specified application ID and display name. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/process-mining-pbi-workspace.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: PowerShell CODE: ``` New-AzureADServicePrincipal -AppId dad3c6de-ed58-42ef-989f-9c0303aaeedc -DisplayName 'Process Insights Prod' ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Timestamp Format Error Display DESCRIPTION: Code showing the interface element for displaying timestamp format errors in the process mining setup. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/process-mining-troubleshoot.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: plaintext CODE: ``` :::image type="content" source="media/process-mining-troubleshoot/timestamp-error.png" alt-text="Screenshot of errors in StartTimestamp."::: ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: HTTP Response for Creating a Cloud Flow - Web API - HTTP DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows the expected HTTP response after successfully creating a cloud flow via the Web API. A 204 No Content status is returned, and the OData-EntityId response header contains the unique URL of the created workflow. The workflow ID can be extracted for further operations. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/manage-flows-with-code.md#2025-04-23_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` HTTP/1.1 204 No Content\nOData-Version: 4.0\nOData-EntityId: [Organization URI]/api/data/v9.2/workflows(00aa00aa-bb11-cc22-dd33-44ee44ee44ee) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Central Custom Action with Boolean Selector and Its Selectors - Power Automate Desktop - C# DESCRIPTION: Implements a custom action class that switches between two behaviors using a boolean input property ('TimeExpired'). The action prepares a message based on elapsed or remaining time, and presents only the relevant fields using selector classes. The boolean property is decorated with a default value and is used to activate either the NoTime or ThereIsTime selectors, which control property visibility. Dependencies: System.ComponentModel, Power Automate Desktop SDK and ActionSelectors classes. Inputs are boolean and strings for times; output is a message. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/create-custom-actions.md#2025-04-23_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: csharp CODE: ``` using System.ComponentModel; using Microsoft.PowerPlatform.PowerAutomate.Desktop.Actions.SDK; using Microsoft.PowerPlatform.PowerAutomate.Desktop.Actions.SDK.ActionSelectors; using Microsoft.PowerPlatform.PowerAutomate.Desktop.Actions.SDK.Attributes; namespace Modules.CustomModule { [Action] public class CentralCustomActionWithBoolean : ActionBase { #region Properties [InputArgument, DefaultValue(true)] public bool TimeExpired { get; set; } [InputArgument] public string ElapsedTime { get; set; } [InputArgument] public string RemainingTime { get; set; } [OutputArgument] public string DisplayedMessage { get; set; } #endregion #region Methods Overrides public override void Execute(ActionContext context) { DisplayedMessage = TimeExpired ? $"The timer has expired. Elapsed time: {ElapsedTime}" : $"Remaining time: {RemainingTime}"; } #endregion } public class NoTime : ActionSelector { public NoTime() { UseName("TimeHasExpired"); Prop(p => p.TimeExpired).ShouldBe(true); ShowAll(); Hide(p => p.RemainingTime); } } public class ThereIsTime : ActionSelector { public ThereIsTime() { UseName("TimeHasNotExpired"); Prop(p => p.TimeExpired).ShouldBe(false); ShowAll(); Hide(p => p.RemainingTime); } } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining QUANTILE() Operation in Power Automate Process Mining DESCRIPTION: Calculates the approximate q-th quantile of values grouped by a defined context. Supports process, case, event, and edge contexts. Takes context, value, q, and optional compression parameters. Returns various data types. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/statistical-operations.md#2025-04-23_snippet_22 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` ## QUANTILE([context],[value],[q],[compression]) Calculates the approximate q-th quantile of values grouped according to defined context. The q-th quantile of a data set is defined as that value where a q fraction of the data is below that value and (1-q) fraction of the data above that value. **Supported context:** process, case, event, edge **Parameters:** - ***[context]*** - defines the context in which the operation is calculated Data type: STRING (only fixed string is allowed) - ***[value]*** - value for evaluation Data type: INT, FLOAT, DATE, TIME - ***[q]*** - quantile to compute, must be between 0 and 1 inclusive. Data type: FLOAT (only constant value is allowed) - ***[compression]*** - controls the estimation accuracy and memory utilization. High compression values increase the accuracy of estimation but make the operation slower. The value must be between 20 and 1000, the default value is 200. Data type: FLOAT **Output Data Type**: INT, FLOAT, DATE, TIME ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Input Parameters for Active Directory Actions in Markdown DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to create a table of input parameters for an Active Directory action using Markdown. It includes details such as argument names, whether they're optional, accepted data types, default values, and descriptions. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/desktop-flows/actions-reference/activedirectory.md#2025-04-23_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: markdown CODE: ``` |Argument|Optional|Accepts|Default Value|Description| |-----|-----|-----|-----|-----| |Parent directory entry|No|[Active Directory entry](../variable-data-types.md#active-directory)||The parent entry of the Active Directory server| |Distinguished name|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The distinguished name of the Active Directory entry| |Move to location|No|[Text value](../variable-data-types.md#text-value)||The location for the object to be moved to| ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: HTTP Response for Deleting a Cloud Flow - Web API - HTTP DESCRIPTION: This HTTP response represents the outcome of a successful DELETE operation on a workflow in the Web API, returning a 204 NoContent status and OData-Version header. No response body is expected, confirming the resource has been deleted. Prerequisites: data fields and calculation functions such as AVG and case duration must be available in the Process Mining environment. Inputs include the data scope and a calculation expression; output is a single aggregated value. This formula must be adapted with real attribute names and calculation logic for specific use cases. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/custom-metrics-how-to.md#2025-04-23_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Pseudocode CODE: ``` Aggregation([Data filtration/scope],\u00a0calculation)\u200b ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Filtering Cases with Positive Duration in Process Mining Expression DESCRIPTION: This expression filters entire cases based on their overall duration. It uses the `Duration()` operator applied at the case level to calculate the total duration of each case. Cases with a duration greater than zero evaluate to True. This is useful for removing cases with zero or negative duration, often indicating invalid data. The result is available in case-level views like Case metric filter, Statistics case overview, and Root cause analysis. SOURCE: https://github.com/microsoftdocs/power-automate-docs/blob/main/articles/minit/custom-metrics-advanced-examples.md#2025-04-23_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: Process Mining Expression CODE: ``` Duration() > 0 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Deleting User's Custom Connectors in PowerShell DESCRIPTION: PowerShell script to delete all custom connectors created by the executing user.
